questions.text: You’re in the histopathology lab examining slides freshly dissected from the neck of a cadaver. A new slide showing a type of cartilage has been obtained. Which of the following parts could be having this cartilage?
questions.solution:
The given histology figure shows elastic cartilage. It is made of type II collagen. Chondrocytes of elastic cartilages are organized within the elastic matrix. In the larynx, elastic cartilages are found in the epiglottis, apex of the arytenoids, corniculate cartilages, and cuneiform cartilages.

Incorrect options:
Option B) Thyroid cartilage is an unpaired cartilage of the larynx. Histologically, it is made up of hyaline cartilage.

Option C) Cricoid cartilage is an unpaired cartilage of the larynx. It is made up of hyaline cartilage and not elastic cartilage.
Option D) Trachea and the bronchi are parts of the lower respiratory tract. They are both made up of hyaline cartilage.

questions.text: 35-year-old Jenny presented with complaints of refractory vasomotor rhinitis, which is not better with medications and lifestyle modifications. The condition is affecting her day-to-day life and also causing complications like nasal polyps. After much implications, a surgical procedure called Vidian Neurectomy was considered. Anatomically, through which of the following foramina of the skull does the Vidian nerve pass?
questions.solution:
The Vidian nerve is the nerve formed at the junction of the greater and deep petrosal nerve. The Vidian nerve and arteries pass through the foramen lacerum.

Foramen lacerum is located between the sphenoid bone, the temporal bone, and the occipital bone of the skull. It may also be appropriately called sphenopetroclival synchondrosis. It is a part of the middle cranial fossa and lies behind the foramen ovale. The lower half of the fossa is covered with fibrocartilage usually. The upper half contains a laceral branch of the internal carotid artery. Structures passing through the foramen are- the Vidian nerve and vessels, the end branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery, and some emissary's veins.

Incorrect options: 

Option A) The foramen rotundum, a circular hole is a part of the middle cranial fossa. The maxillary nerve passes through it.

Option B) The foramen ovale lies in the middle cranial fossa. It is through this foramen that the mandibular nerve passes.

Option D) Foramen spinosum lies posterolateral to the foramen ovale. The middle meningeal artery and veins pass through it.

questions.text: Anjali presented to the orthopedics OPD with complaints of tingling sensations and numbness in the inner aspect of her forearm and hand for 3 weeks. A defect in one of her vertebrae is suspected to be the cause of her symptoms. To which landmark does the vertebra that is most likely to be the cause of symptoms corresponds?
questions.solution:
From the given symptoms and clinical history, the likely diagnosis is a Cervical rib. A cervical rib is a bony growth arising from the C6/C7 vertebra, and this bone attaches itself to the 1st rib. If the bone growth is greater than 5cm, it may impact the brachial plexus and subclavian artery, causing the above-mentioned symptoms. The C6 vertebra usually corresponds to the cricoid cartilage as a landmark and site marking on the human body. Therefore, option B is correct.
Incorrect options:
Option A) The hyoid bone corresponds to the C3 vertebra. A cervical rib is not known to grow from the C3 vertebra.
Option C) The landmark corresponding sternal angle of Louis is also known as the thoracic plane or the plane of Ludwig. It corresponds to the T4 vertebra.
Option D) The xiphi-sternal joint, where the body of the sternum and the xiphoid process meets, corresponds to the T9 vertebra.

questions.text: It has been one week since Ajmal underwent shoulder surgery. He presented to the OPD on an urgent basis now with complaints of transient pain in the wrist region. On examination, he was found to have weakness in the flexors of the thumb, index, and middle finger. Which could be the likely nerve affected?

choices.text: Deep branch of the radial nerve

questions.solution:
Ajmal is experiencing Anterior Interosseus syndrome, which is a rare complication after shoulder surgery due to pressure on the forearm after immobilization. It is likely transient, inflammatory neuritis. The anterior interosseus nerve is a branch of the median nerve and supplies the Flexor digitorum profundus (I & II), flexor pollicis longus, and the pronator quadratus in the upper limb; hence, the injury causes the defect in motor functions of these muscles.
Incorrect options:
Option B) The posterior interosseous nerve supplies muscles in the dorsum of the hand, i.e., the extensor digitorum, extensor digiti minimi, and extensor carpi ulnaris. It also supplies some of the deep muscles of the forearm and hand, like the supinator, Abductor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor pollicis longus, and extensor indicis.
Option C) The radial nerve, supplies the brachioradialis and Extensor carpi radialis longus before splitting.
Option D) The deep branch of the radial nerve supplies the superficial muscle Extensor carpi radialis brevis in the dorsum of the hand.

questions.text: You are in the anatomy museum studying a dissected heart. Which of the following is not a tributary/inlet of the right atrium?
questions.solution:
The left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs through the 4 pulmonary veins. On the other hand, the right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the rest of the body, which is pumped to the lungs via the right ventricle.
The tributaries/inlets of the right atrium are:

  • Superior vena cava
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Coronary sinus
  • Anterior cardiac veins
  • Venae cordis minimi (thebesian veins)
  • Occasionally, the right marginal vein

 
Incorrect Choices:
Option A. The thebesian veins, also known as the venae cordis minimi, drain into the right atrium. They are the smallest veins in coronary circulation. They drain blood from the heart’s myocardium.
Option B: Coronary sinus drains into the right atrium. It is the largest vein the cardiac circulation and drains more than 50% of blood in cardiac circulation into the right atrium.
Option C: The anterior cardiac vein ultimately drains into the right atrium. They collect blood from the anterior right ventricle and drain it back into the anterior right atrium.

questions.text:
50-year-old, previously diagnosed with Glioblastoma multiforme, now presented with some new symptoms. He has been experiencing memory loss along with unusual and unpredictable mood swings. The structure highlighted in the below figure is suspected to be involved. What type of fibre does this part categorize into?


Figure 1: Reference: https://human-memory.net
questions.solution:
The highlighted structure is the fornix of the brain, a white matter bundle. It is located in the mesial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres. As lesions in the fornix cause anterograde and retrograde memory loss along with mood changes. 
The fornix is a type of association fibre. It links the hippocampus with distal brain sites. Since this site is a midline tract, it is susceptible to tumor involvement, as well as rotational shearing injuries causing diffuse axonal injuries.
Incorrect choices:
Option B) Fornix is not a type of commissural fibre. Corpus callosum, anterior commissure, hippocampal commissure, posterior commissure, and habenular commissure all fall in this category.
Option C) Fornix is not a type of projection fibre. The fibres in the internal capsule and cerebral cortex are projection fibres. The fibres connect the cerebral cortex to the lower regions of the brain and the spinal cord. 
Option D) Habenular commissure is a type of commissural fibre. It is located between the habenulae and the small protuberance of the thalamus. It contains tectohabenular fibres and commissural fibres.

questions.text: A 45-year-old unidentified was the victim of a hit-and-run case. The patient was in hypotensive shock when he was brought to the hospital. After initial attempts at resuscitation, an X-ray venogram revealed a laceration of the Azygos vein. Where does this vein receive drainage from?
questions.solution:
Laceration of the azygos vein is a rare but fatal injury. The azygos vein is a part of the azygos vein system and drains the thoracic wall and upper lumbar region. The vein also functions as a channel between the superior and inferior vena cava. It also connects the portal venous system and the caval venous system.

Incorrect choices:

Option B) Venous blood of the neck does not drain into the azygos venous system. It drains into the anterior jugular vein.
Option C) The blood in the pelvic region drains into the Common iliac and internal iliac veins.
Option D) The axillary vein drains the blood in the upper limbs and shoulders. The axillary vein then drains into the subclavian vein.

questions.text: The glands in the human body can be divided into multiple types based on their mechanism of secretion. The given figure shows the histology of a part of the body. The pink arrows indicate a mechanism of secretion of the gland. What type of gland secretes contents in this manner?
questions.solution:
The given picture histologically represents the mechanism of secretion of an apocrine gland. An example of this method of secretion is the mammary gland. The pink arrows point to the apical part of the cells being removed during secretion. The apical cytoplasm that is pinched off contains secretions. Hence, it is classified as an apocrine gland. The secretions are then released into the duct, and so the apocrine gland is a type of exocrine gland.

Incorrect choices:
Option A) The sebaceous gland in the skin is an example of a holocrine gland. It is not represented in the given picture. The cells usually fill with secretory products, after which the whole cell disintegrates and releases the secretions.
Option C) Endocrine gland is a type of gland and not a mechanism of secretion. These glands secrete directly into the interstitial fluid through which it enters the circulation.
Option D) Although the given structure falls under the general category of the exocrine gland, the exocrine gland is a type of gland and not a mechanism of secretion. Therefore, it is not the right answer. The different processes of secretion of exocrine glands are merocrine, apocrine, and holocrine.

questions.text: John is an athlete who is very active professionally. Lately, however, he has been experiencing severe pain and numbness in his buttock region, radiating to his legs. It is often exacerbated in the sitting position and while running. After a detailed evaluation, he was diagnosed to have Piriformis syndrome. Which nerve is affected by this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Piriformis syndrome is a rare condition where the piriformis muscle causes entrapment compression of the sciatic or pudendal nerve. The condition causes pain in the buttock region, which is often worse when sitting. The sciatic nerve passes below the piriformis muscle, and it is compressed when the muscle shortens or spasms. Therefore, option A is correct. 
Learning the anatomy of the muscle and the course of the nerve is necessary from the clinical and surgical aspects. MRI may show hypertrophy or atrophy of the muscle, as studies indicate that either of these can cause these symptoms. Treatment is usually by bed rest, NSAIDS, and physiotherapy.
Incorrect choices:
Option A) It is the main nerve of the pelvis. It runs between the pelvic floor muscles and can never be symptomatic in piriformis syndrome.
Option B) The superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1) leaves via the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis. It then runs between the gluteus medium and minimal.
Option D) The inferior gluteal nerve passes through the greater sciatic foramen and mainly supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It runs anterior to the piriformis muscle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old had an untreated tooth infection of an upper molar. The infection has now spread to his neck, leading to cellulitis of the space within the cervical sheath. Which of the following structures is not a structure inside the sheath?
questions.solution:
Cellulitis of the neck spaces can be very dangerous, as the infection can easily spread to the mediastinum and through the contents of the cervical sheath. It is a bacterial infection characterized by redness, swelling, and so on. Aetiology is usually an infected dental abscess. In the given case scenario, the 60-year-old had an untreated tooth infection that was followed by cellulitis of the space within the cervical sheath (carotid sheath)
The anterior jugular vein is not a content of the carotid sheath. The upper part of the anterior jugular vein and the jugular venous arch lies in the investing layer of deep cervical fascia. Therefore, option D is correct.

Incorrect choices:

Option A) The common carotid artery and the internal carotid artery are the contents of the carotid sheath. The covering of the sheath is thicker around the arteries.

Option B) The vagus nerve passes through the carotid sheath.

Option D) The Ansa cervicalis is located within the carotid sheath. The vein in the carotid sheath is the internal jugular vein.

questions.text: A head-and-neck oncology surgeon is doing a wide-radical neck dissection. She is focused on dissecting one of the anterior triangles. This particular triangle contains branches of the facial nerve, the submandibular gland anteriorly, and the lower part of the parotid gland posteriorly. Which muscle forms the floor of the triangle?
questions.solution:
The given question indicates that the triangle is a part of the anterior triangle. The anterior triangle is subdivided into the digastric, submental, muscular, and carotid. The clue that the triangle contains both the submandibular gland and a part of the parotid gland indicates that the triangle is the digastric triangle. The mylohyoid muscle and the hyoglossus form the floor of the digastric triangle. Hence, option A is the right answer.

Incorrect choices:
Option B: The scalenus medius, the serratus anterior, and the first rib form the floor of the supraclavicular triangle. The supraclavicular triangle is one of the posterior triangles of the neck.
Option C:  The inferior pharyngeal constrictor muscle, the middle pharyngeal constrictor muscle, the thyrohyoid, and the hyoglossus form the floor of the carotid triangle. It is the most surgically important triangle, containing the common carotid artery and its 2 divisions.
Option D:  The floor of the posterior triangle of the neck is made of the splenius capitis, levator scapulae, and scalene muscles, over which lies the prevertebral fascia. The question specifically mentions that the surgeon is dissecting the anterior triangle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presented with acute ataxia. Cerebellar tests like finger-nose and Romberg’s tests all indicated a cerebellar lesion. If the dorsal spinocerebellar tract is involved, which of the following statements are right about the tract?

choices.text: The 1st neuron of the tract arises from the dorsal root ganglion.
They cross over in the lateral column of the spinal cord.
The 3rd neuron fibres relay at the posterolateral ventral nucleus of the thalamus.
The fibres relay pain and temperature.

questions.solution:
The first neuron fibres of the dorsal spinocerebellar tract originate at the dorsal root ganglia. They then relay to the dorsal nucleus, which is also known as Clark’s column. The 2nd neuron fibres arise from here and ascend to the medulla oblongata.

Dorsal (Direct) Spinocerebellar tract

  • Fibers of the dorsal spinocerebellar tract originate from the cells of Clarke's column at the base of the posterior horn.
  • The axons ascend ipsilaterally to enter the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.
     

Incorrect choices:

Option B: The dorsal spinocerebellar tract is uncrossed and relays to the cerebellum on the ipsilateral side.
Option C: The dorsal spinocerebellar tract has only 2 nerve fibres. The 3rd nerve fibres of the lateral spinothalamic tract relay at the posterolateral ventral nucleus of the thalamus.
Option D: The fibres relay reflex proprioceptive sensations, touch, and unconscious proprioceptive impulses. They are tested by cerebellar tests like finger nose test, heel-knee test, Romberg’s sign, and dysdiadochokinesia.

questions.text: The juxtaglomerular cells, given in the diagram below, produce an enzyme (x) that plays a vital role in blood pressure control by the kidney. It (x) helps control aldosterone production and regulates blood pressure. Which of the options below does not stimulate the enzyme ‘x’?

choices.text: Increased sympathetic activity via renal nerve

questions.solution:
• The juxtaglomerular cells are present in the media of the afferent arteriole when they enter the glomeruli of the nephron. The juxtaglomerular cells produce Renin (x). Renin plays a crucial role in blood pressure management and is part of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Angiotensin II inhibits renin production, as an increase in Angiotensin II will decrease renin production.

Incorrect choices:

  • Option A: Increased sympathetic activity in the renal nerve stimulates renin production. This increase is mediated by circulating catecholamine and norepinephrine.
  • Option B: Increased circulating catecholamines are detected in the blood, stimulating the JG cells to increase renin production. Catecholamines act on β1-adrenergic receptors on JG cells.
  • Option D: Both COX-1 and COX-2-derived prostaglandins increase the production of renin.

questions.text: Mammalian nerve fibers are divided into A, B, and C groups and are further subdivided based on their characteristics. Usually, the smaller axons serve pain and temperature sensations and autonomic functions. Which of the following nerve fibres function to recognise pain and temperature?
questions.solution:
• The Aδ mammalian nerve fiber is a subtype of the A group of nerves. It functions to recognise pain and temperature. It is thin with a fiber diameter of 2-5 micrometres. Its conduction velocity is around 12-30 m/s.

Incorrect choices:

Option B: The sympathetic fibers of C function as postganglionic sympathetic fibers. Its diameter is 0.3-1.3 micrometre. On the other hand, the dorsal root of the C fiber functions to recognise pain and temperature.

Option C: The B fibers function as preganglionic autonomic. Its fiber diameter is <3 micrometre.

Option D: The Aγ nerve fibers function as motor to muscle spindles. Its fiber diameter is 2-6 micrometres.

questions.text: A patient presented with head trauma and was found to have features suggestive of increased intracranial pressure. As part of the emergency treatment, 1000 mg of mannitol injection is given. Assume around 20% of it is excreted out. If the plasma concentration is around 3.2 mg/100 ml at equilibrium, what is the ECF volume?
questions.solution:
A prescription medication called mannitol IV treats elevated intracranial or intraocular pressure signs and symptoms. The question asks to calculate the ECF volume, which is the volume of distribution. It is calculated using the formula below.
Volume of compartment = Amount injected – Amount excreted/Concentration
Here, the amount injected is 1000 mg, and 20 % is excreted, which is 200 mg
Hence, the amount of mannitol left in the system is 800 mg in the ECF volume(x), which needs to be calculated.
If 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, then x = 800 x 100 
  3.2
  = 25000 ml
  = 25 L

Incorrect choices: 
Option B: 12 L is not the correct ECF volume.
Option C: 10 L is not the correct ECF volume.
Option D: 50 L is not the correct ECF volume.

questions.text: An experiment is conducted to check the excitability of neurons. The effect of changing the concentration of different ions on excitability is noted. Among the following options, the change in concentration in which of the following ions affects the excitability of cells to the maximum limit?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ca2+

  • Ca2+ ions are generally maintained at an extremely low concentration in intracellular fluid (ICF), about 10,000 times less than extracellular fluid (ECF) concentration; when extracellular Ca2+ increases, the excitability of cells decreases.
  • Effects of ion concentration change on membrane potential:
    • Hypercalcemia: Increased extracellular Ca2+ concentration can stabilize the membrane by decreasing excitability.
    • Hypocalcemia: Calcium ion is a membrane stabilizer. A decrease in extracellular Ca2+ concentration increases the nerve's excitability by decreasing the depolarization necessary to produce the action potential. Hyperexcitability is seen.

Option A: K+

  • When extracellular K+ concentration increases by a certain amount, the excitability of cells is higher because the resting potential shifts towards a higher equilibrium potential of K+, causing depolarization.
  • K+ ions would be moving out of the cells, while Na+ and Cl- ions would be moving into the cell.
  • At the resting state, the cell is mainly permeable to K+. This exerts the most significant influence on the resting membrane potential out of the three ions.

Option B: Na+

  • Generates action potential (AP), the amplitude of AP decreases in hyponatremia, and severe hyponatremia – conduction may stop.

Option C: Cl-

  • Most prevalent anions in ECF.
  • It moves relatively easily between ECF and ICF because most plasma membranes contain Cl- leakage channels and antiporters.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female athlete complains of muscle weakness and fatigue during exercise. She reports that she has been training intensively for the upcoming marathon for the past 3 months. A muscle biopsy is performed, and the results show a predominance of Type I muscle fibers. Which of the following statements best explains the muscle weakness and fatigue seen in this patient?

choices.text: Type I muscle fibers are predominantly used for anaerobic exercise and are prone to fatigue.
Type I muscle fibers have a low oxidative capacity and are prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.
Type I muscle fibers have a high oxidative capacity and are more resistant to fatigue than Type II fibers.
Type I muscle fibers have a high glycolytic capacity and are more resistant to fatigue than Type II fibers.

questions.solution:
• Type I muscle fibers, also known as slow-twitch fibers, have a high oxidative capacity due to the abundance of mitochondria and myoglobin. This makes them well-suited for endurance exercise, such as marathon running. However, they have a lower glycolytic capacity and rely primarily on oxidative metabolism for energy production. This means that during prolonged exercise, Type I fibers are prone to fatigue when energy demands exceed the capacity of oxidative metabolism.
  • In contrast, Type II muscle fibers, also known as fast-twitch fibers, have a higher glycolytic capacity and rely more heavily on anaerobic metabolism for energy production. This makes them well-suited for high-intensity, short-duration exercise, such as sprinting or weightlifting. However, they have a lower oxidative capacity and are more prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.
  • The predominance of Type I fibers in this patient's muscle biopsy is consistent with her endurance training regimen. However, the low oxidative capacity of Type I fibers makes them prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise, which may explain the muscle weakness and fatigue she is experiencing. 

Incorrect options:

Option A:  This statement is incorrect. Type I muscle fibers are predominantly used for aerobic exercise, which relies on oxidative metabolism for energy production. Type I fibers are also less prone to fatigue than Type II fibers during prolonged exercise due to their higher oxidative capacity.

Option C:  This statement is incorrect. Type I muscle fibers have a high oxidative capacity; they are less resistant to fatigue than Type II fibers. Type II fibers have a higher glycolytic capacity and are better suited for high-intensity, short-duration exercise but are more prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.

Option D:  This statement is also incorrect. Type I muscle fibers have a lower glycolytic capacity than Type II fibers and rely more heavily on oxidative metabolism for energy production. Additionally, as mentioned earlier, Type II fibers are better suited for high-intensity, short-duration exercise but are more prone to fatigue during prolonged exercise.

questions.text: Which of the following organs is not involved in calcium homeostasis?
questions.solution:
• Ca2+ homeostasis is achieved by 3 hormones:
    1. PTH,
    2. Calcitonin, and
    3. Vitamin D.
  • Ca2+ levels are regulated from 3 tissues:
    1. Bone,
    2. Intestine, and
    3. Kidneys.
  • The skin has the precursor for Vitamin D synthesis.
  • Vitamin D is involved in Ca2+ absorption from G.I.T.

questions.text: At which of the following blood pressure readings will the the baroreceptors be inactive?
questions.solution:
Option D: 180 mm Hg

  • This patient, a pregnant lady, at the 28th week of gestation, with a blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg, severe headaches and increased fetal movements, is diagnosed with pre-eclampsia.
  • Baroreceptors (BRs) are mechanosensitive nerve endings in carotid sinuses and aortic arches that function as arterial blood pressure (BP) sensors.
  • The range for baroreceptor function is 60-180 mm Hg.
  • The standard set point for baroreceptors is 100 mm Hg.
  • At 100 mm Hg, there is a steady impulse discharge from baroreceptors to the VMC.
  • When BP increases → impulse discharge increases; when BP decreases → impulse discharge decreases.
  • Thus, impulse discharge will be maximum at 180 mm Hg.

 

Option A: 60 mm Hg

  • The lowest impulse discharge frequency is 60mmhg.

Option B: 100 mm Hg

  • The standard set point for baroreceptors is 100 mm Hg. It is not the highest impulse discharge frequency noted by baroreceptors.

Option C: 150 mm Hg

  • 150mm Hg is not the highest impulse discharge frequency noted from baroreceptors.

questions.text:
55-year-old patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath. An electrocardiogram showed ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, indicating a likely myocardial infarction. The patient was immediately started on thrombolytic therapy, and his symptoms improved within a few hours.

Which of the following changes would be expected in the patient's cardiac cycle following the myocardial infarction and subsequent thrombolytic therapy?
questions.solution:
• Myocardial infarction (MI) is a serious condition that can cause damage to the heart muscle, impacting the cardiac cycle. Thrombolytic therapy is an intervention to dissolve blood clots that can cause MIs.
  • During the cardiac cycle, the isovolumetric relaxation time (IVRT) is the period between the end of ejection and the beginning of filling, during which all four heart valves are closed. In a healthy individual, this phase is relatively short, as the heart quickly relaxes and begins to fill with blood. However, the IVRT can be prolonged in patients with MI due to damage to the myocardium and subsequent impairment of diastolic function.
  • Thrombolytic therapy can help dissolve the clot causing the MI, but it cannot reverse the damage that has already occurred to the heart muscle. Therefore, while the patient's symptoms may improve following thrombolytic therapy, the underlying damage may still affect the cardiac cycle. Specifically, the IVRT is likely to be prolonged, as the damaged myocardium cannot relax and fill as efficiently as before.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: End-diastolic volume is the amount of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole, just before ventricular contraction (systole) begins. However, this option is unlikely because the damaged myocardium may lead to impaired filling and increased end-diastolic volume instead.

Option B: Stroke volume is the amount of blood ejected from the heart with each contraction. However, this option is unlikely because the damaged myocardium may lead to decreased contractility and stroke volume instead.

Option D: Ejection time is the time it takes for the left ventricle to eject its stroke volume. However, this option is unlikely because the damaged myocardium may lead to decreased contractility and a longer ejection time instead.

questions.text: Which of the following are the actions/effects of endothelin-1?
questions.solution:
• One of the most potent vasoconstrictor agents is Endothelin-1, is produced by the endothelial cells. Endothelin-1 (ET-1), endothelin -2 (ET-2), endothelin – 3 (ET-3) are encoded by different genes but are members of a family of three similar 21-amino acid polypeptides.
  • Endothelin is a peptide that is released by damaged vascular endothelial cells of the kidneys, as well as by other tissues.
  • It causes bronchoconstriction and not bronchodilatation.

Biologic effects of endothelins:
  • Hemodynamic effects:
  • Contracts vascular smooth muscle; veins more sensitive than arteries.
  • Cardiac effects:
  • Positive inotropic and chronotropic effects on the myocardium.
  • Intense vasoconstriction of coronary arteries
  • Neuroendocrine effects:
  • Increased plasma levels of ANP, renin, aldosterone, and catecholamines
  • Modulates synaptic transmission
  • Renal effects:
  • Increases renal vascular resistance
  • Decreases GFR, renal blood flow
  • Increases Na+ reabsorption through hemodynamic actions, but decreases Na+ reabsorption through inhibition of Na+-K+ pump.

questions.text: A 62-year-old female presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. Upon examination, it is found that she has an irregular heartbeat and a grade III/VI systolic murmur. Further investigation revealed an enlarged left atrium and left ventricle with mitral valve regurgitation. A prominent third heart sound was heard during auscultation, followed by a fourth one. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's third and fourth heart sounds?

choices.text: S3 is caused by left ventricular hypertrophy, while a stiff left ventricle causes S4 due to ischemic heart disease.
S3 is caused by increased atrial pressure, while a stiff left ventricle causes S4 due to hypertension.
S3 is caused by rapid ventricular filling, while S4 is caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle.
S3 is caused by decreased ventricular compliance, while S4 is caused by atrial contraction against a hypertrophied ventricle.

questions.solution:
• S3 is a third heart sound that occurs in early diastole, after the second heart sound (S2). It is caused by rapid ventricular filling due to increased volume or pressure overload of the ventricle. This is commonly seen in heart failure, mitral or tricuspid regurgitation, and ventricular septal defect.
  • S4 is a fourth heart sound in late diastole, just before the first heart sound (S1). It is caused by atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle, commonly seen in conditions such as hypertension, aortic stenosis, and ischemic heart disease.
  • In the given scenario, the patient has an enlarged left atrium and left ventricle with mitral valve regurgitation. This suggests increased volume or pressure overload of the left ventricle, leading to S3. Mitral valve regurgitation can cause increased blood flow back into the left atrium during ventricular systole, leading to increased volume or pressure overload of the ventricle during diastole, contributing to S3.
  • A grade III/VI systolic murmur also suggests mitral regurgitation. Additionally, the patient has an irregular heartbeat, which could be due to atrial fibrillation. Atrial fibrillation can cause a stiff left atrium, increasing pressure in the left atrium and contributing to S3.
  • The prominent fourth heart sound (S4) in this patient suggests a stiff left ventricle, which could be due to hypertension. Hypertension can cause the left ventricle to become stiff and non-compliant, making it harder for the ventricle to fill with blood during diastole. This can cause the atria to contract more forcefully to fill the ventricle, leading to S4.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: Left ventricular hypertrophy does not typically lead to S3. S3 is caused by rapid ventricular filling in conditions such as heart failure, mitral or tricuspid regurgitation, and ventricular septal defect. Additionally, S4 is not typically associated with ischemic heart disease but with conditions such as hypertension, aortic stenosis, and a stiff left ventricle.

Option B:  S3 is not caused by increased atrial pressure but rather by rapid ventricular filling. Additionally, while hypertension can lead to a stiff left ventricle and S4, it does not cause S3.

Option D: While a hypertrophied ventricle can lead to decreased ventricular compliance, it is not the cause of S3. Additionally, S4 is not typically associated with a hypertrophied ventricle but with conditions such as hypertension, aortic stenosis, and a stiff left ventricle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the pulmonary function tests in interstitial lung disease?
questions.solution:
Option B: Reduced FEV1/FVC ratio

Interstitial lung disease causes

  • Defective exchange of gases at the alveolar epithelium, i.e., reduced diffusion capacity
  • Restrictive pathology of lungs had to reduced VC, reduced TLC
  • However, FEV1 / FVC = INCREASE: Since FVC is reduced or unchanged in ILD.
  • Thus, FEV1 / FVC ratio = increases in restrictive lung disease result in a loss of FVC w/o loss in FEV1 / FVC.

Note:

Restrictive lung disease: Maximum expiratory flow volume (MEFV) curve begins and ends at abnormally low lung volumes. The flow rates are higher than normal at any given lung volume.

Option A: Reduced vital capacity

  • In restrictive lung disease, vital capacity is reduced.
  • This is due to a decrease in inspiratory reserve volume and total lung capacity

Option C: Reduced diffusion capacity

  • Due to defects in the interstitial component of the respiratory membrane, the diffusion of gases is largely reduced.
  • This results in reduced diffusion capacity

Option D: Reduced total lung capacity

  • Because the recoil force of the lung is increased in restrictive lung disease and expansion of the lungs is limited, TLC decreases.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient was diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder that affects the function of the Golgi apparatus. The Golgi apparatus is an essential organelle involved in the modification and sorting of proteins and lipids. The patient presents with symptoms such as impaired secretion of digestive enzymes, abnormal glycosylation of proteins, and reduced formation of lysosomes. Which of the following is the most likely underlying molecular defect in the patient's Golgi apparatus?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C.

  • Impaired function of mannosidase II would affect the processing of N-linked oligosaccharides on glycoproteins. This defect would lead to the accumulation of immature glycoproteins in the Golgi, resulting in abnormal glycosylation of proteins. This option could be the underlying molecular defect in the patient's Golgi apparatus.


Incorrect Choice: 

  • Option A: Mutation in the COP-II complex is involved in vesicular transport from the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to the Golgi apparatus. This defect would cause a disruption in the ER-to-Golgi transport and would not affect the Golgi's processing and sorting functions.
  • Option B: Defective COPI-mediated retrograde transport is responsible for vesicular transport from the Golgi to the ER. This defect would affect the retrograde transport of proteins and lipids and would not affect the Golgi's processing and sorting functions.
  • Option D: Abnormal function of trans-Golgi network (TGN) would affect the sorting and packaging of proteins and lipids into transport vesicles. This defect would lead to the accumulation of proteins and lipids in the TGN and would not affect the Golgi's processing and modification functions.

questions.text: A patient presents with extremely high LDL cholesterol levels in their blood, despite being on a low-cholesterol diet and taking a statin medication. Further investigation reveals the patient’s genetic mutation in the LDL receptor gene encoding. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism responsible for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Reduced activity of HMG-CoA reductase leading to decreased cholesterol synthesis.
Increased cholesteryl ester transfer protein (CETP) activity leads to increased LDL cholesterol levels.
Decreased hepatic lipase activity leads to decreased clearance of LDL cholesterol.
Decreased expression or activity of LDL receptors leads to decreased LDL cholesterol clearance.

questions.solution:
• In a normal individual, LDL cholesterol is primarily cleared from the bloodstream by LDL receptors on the liver cells’ surface. These receptors bind to LDL particles and internalize them, allowing the liver to break down the cholesterol for use in various cellular processes. However, if the gene encoding the LDL receptor is mutated, the expression or activity of these receptors may be reduced, resulting in decreased clearance of LDL cholesterol from the bloodstream. As a result, individuals with this genetic mutation can have extremely high LDL cholesterol levels in their blood, even if they are on a low-cholesterol diet or taking cholesterol-lowering medications like statins.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: HMG-CoA reductase is the enzyme responsible for the rate-limiting step in cholesterol synthesis. If its activity is reduced, less cholesterol would be synthesized, which would not lead to the blood's observed high LDL cholesterol levels.

Option B: CETP is a protein that transfers cholesterol esters between lipoproteins, but it primarily affects HDL cholesterol levels, not LDL cholesterol levels.

Option C: Hepatic lipase is an enzyme that helps to clear triglycerides from the bloodstream, but it does not play a major role in the clearance of LDL cholesterol.

questions.text:
A researcher has isolated a liver cell from a fasting individual and analyzed the levels of various metabolites involved in gluconeogenesis. Which of the following is most likely to be observed in this cell?


	
		
			Metabolite    
			Fasting levels
			 Levels during gluconeogenesis
		
		
			Pyruvate        
			↓ 
			↑
		
		
			Acetyl-CoA 
			↓ 
			↑
		
		
			Oxaloacetate
			↓ 
			↑
		
		
			Fumarate
			↑
			↓
questions.solution:
During fasting, the body must maintain glucose homeostasis to ensure a constant supply of glucose to the brain and other glucose-dependent organs. One of the mechanisms by which the body achieves this is through the process of gluconeogenesis, which occurs primarily in the liver. Gluconeogenesis involves the synthesis of glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors, such as lactate, glycerol, and amino acids.
In the liver cell of a fasting individual, the levels of pyruvate, normally produced by glycolysis, would be expected to be decreased, as the liver would be using it for gluconeogenesis rather than producing it. On the other hand, acetyl-CoA levels would be increased as fatty acids would be metabolized to produce acetyl-CoA, which can then be used as a precursor for gluconeogenesis. Oxaloacetate, another precursor for gluconeogenesis, would also be increased as it combines with acetyl-CoA to form citrate, which can then be converted back into oxaloacetate and acetyl-CoA to generate glucose. Finally, the level of fumarate, a metabolite involved in the citric acid cycle, would be decreased as the cycle is slowed down during gluconeogenesis.

  • In Fed state, insulin activates PDH complex
    • Pyruvate → acetyl co-enzyme A → Fat synthesis
  • In fasting state, oxidation of folic acid which leads to Increase in acetyl co-enzyme A.

 


  

Incorrect Choice: 


Option A: Pyruvate ↓, Acetyl-CoA ↓, Oxaloacetate ↑, Fumarate ↑

  • Fumarate levels are not expected to increase during gluconeogenesis. Fumarate is an intermediate of the citric acid cycle, and its levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as the intermediates are used to generate glucose.
  • Acetyl-CoA levels are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis as acetyl-CoA is a precursor of oxaloacetate, which is needed for gluconeogenesis.
  • Pyruvate levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as pyruvate is being used to generate glucose.
  • Oxaloacetate levels are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis as oxaloacetate is the starting material for gluconeogenesis.

Option B: Pyruvate ↓, Acetyl-CoA ↑, Oxaloacetate ↓, Fumarate ↑

  • The levels of oxaloacetate are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis, not decrease, as oxaloacetate is the starting material for gluconeogenesis.
  • Acetyl-CoA levels are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis as acetyl-CoA is a precursor of oxaloacetate, which is needed for gluconeogenesis.
  • Pyruvate levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as pyruvate is being used to generate glucose.
  • Fumarate levels are not expected to increase during gluconeogenesis. Fumarate is an intermediate of the citric acid cycle, and its levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as the intermediates are used to generate glucose.

Option D: Pyruvate ↑, Acetyl-CoA ↓, Oxaloacetate ↑, Fumarate ↓

  • Pyruvate levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as pyruvate generates glucose, not increase.
  • Acetyl-CoA levels are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis as acetyl-CoA is a precursor of oxaloacetate, which is needed for gluconeogenesis, not decrease.
  • Oxaloacetate levels are expected to increase during gluconeogenesis as oxaloacetate is the starting material for gluconeogenesis.
  • Fumarate levels are not expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis. Fumarate is an intermediate of the citric acid cycle, and its levels are expected to decrease during gluconeogenesis as the intermediates are used to generate glucose.

questions.text: A new drug is developed to target an enzyme involved in a critical metabolic pathway. In laboratory studies, the drug was found to inhibit the enzyme's activity by binding to a site that is not the active site but is close to it. Moreover, the drug's inhibition is not overcome in the presence of high substrate concentrations. Which type of inhibition does the drug exhibit?
questions.solution:
• Non-competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to an allosteric site on an enzyme, which is not the active site, and inhibits the enzyme's activity by changing its conformation. This type of inhibition is not affected by changes in substrate concentration because the inhibitor does not compete with the substrate for binding to the active site.
  • In the scenario described in the question, the drug inhibits the enzyme's activity by binding to an allosteric site close to the active site, suggesting non-competitive inhibition. The fact that the inhibition is not overcome at high substrate concentrations further supports this conclusion. Competitive inhibitors can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration, but non-competitive inhibitors cannot.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Competitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to the active site of the enzyme, competing with the substrate. This type of inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration. In the scenario described in the question, the drug was found to bind to a site that is not the active site, and therefore cannot be classified as competitive inhibition.

Option C: Uncompetitive inhibition occurs when an inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, preventing the release of the product. There is no mention of an inhibitor binding to the enzyme-substrate complex in the scenario described in the question, making this option incorrect.

Option D: Mixed inhibition occurs when an inhibitor can bind to both the enzyme and the enzyme-substrate complex, but has a different affinity for each. The scenario described in the question does not mention any differences in affinity, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a rare genetic disorder characterized by an increased sensitivity to ultraviolet radiation and a high risk of developing skin cancer. Which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is most likely impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is a DNA repair mechanism that recognizes and removes bulky DNA lesions caused by environmental factors such as ultraviolet (UV) radiation, as well as chemicals such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) and platinum-based chemotherapy drugs. NER is a complex process involving multiple proteins that recognize and remove the damaged DNA strand and then synthesize and ligate a new strand to complete the repair.
In individuals with defects in NER, such as those with xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), the ability to repair DNA damage caused by UV radiation is impaired, leading to an increased risk of skin cancer, particularly in sun-exposed areas of the skin. Other symptoms of XP can include photophobia (sensitivity to light), dry skin, and premature aging.
It's worth noting that defects in NER can also cause other health issues beyond skin cancer, including neurological abnormalities and developmental delays. Therefore, accurate diagnosis and management of NER defects are important for overall patient care.

Incorrect choices:
Option A. Base excision repair (BER) repairs DNA damage caused by reactive oxygen species and alkylating agents, not UV radiation. Defects in BER are associated with increased susceptibility to certain types of cancer but not with increased sensitivity to UV radiation.

Option B. Mismatch repair (MMR) corrects errors that occur during DNA replication and recombination, not DNA damage caused by environmental factors such as UV radiation. Defects in MMR are associated with an increased risk of hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and some other types of cancer, but not with increased sensitivity to UV radiation.

Option D. Transcription-coupled repair (TCR) specifically repairs damage in actively transcribed DNA regions but is not involved in repairing DNA damage caused by environmental factors such as UV radiation. Defects in TCR are associated with a rare genetic disorder called Cockayne syndrome, characterized by growth failure, neurodegeneration, and premature aging.

questions.text: A patient presents with a high level of acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate in the blood. Further examination reveals that the patient has been fasting for 72 hours. Which of the following enzymes would be activated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
During fasting, the body transitions from using glucose as the primary energy source to storing fats. In the liver, fatty acids are broken down into acetyl-CoA through β-oxidation, which can then be used to generate energy through the citric acid cycle and oxidative phosphorylation. However, the brain cannot use fatty acids as an energy source, so the liver must also produce ketone bodies, such as acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate, which the brain can use as an alternative fuel source.
Hormone-sensitive lipase is an enzyme activated during fasting and breaks down stored triglycerides in adipose tissue into fatty acids and glycerol. These fatty acids can then be transported to the liver for β-oxidation to generate energy and produce ketone bodies.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Acetyl-CoA carboxylase enzyme is involved in fatty acid synthesis, not the breakdown of stored triglycerides for energy during fasting. In fact, acetyl-CoA carboxylase is inhibited during fasting to conserve energy and prevent unnecessary fatty acid synthesis.

Option C. Carnitine palmitoyltransferase 1 (CPT-1): Although CPT-1 is involved in transporting fatty acids into the mitochondria for β-oxidation, it is not directly involved in the breakdown of stored triglycerides in adipose tissue.

Option D. Malonyl-CoA decarboxylase: This enzyme is not known and is not involved in the metabolism of fats or carbohydrates.

questions.text:
Glycogen Storage Disorders are a group of genetic diseases resulting from malfunctioning enzymes involved in glycogen metabolism. Von Gierke's disease is one such disorder that occurs due to the deficiency of a specific enzyme. Consider the following statements regarding Von Gierke's disease and choose the correct option(s):

I. Von Gierke's disease is also known as Type I Glycogen Storage Disease.
II. The disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
III. The deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease converts glucose to glucose-6-phosphate.
IV. Von Gierke’s disease symptoms include hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia.

choices.text: Statements I and III are true.
Statements I and IV are true.
Statements II and III are true.
Statements III and IV are true.

questions.solution:
I. Von Gierke's disease is also known as Type I Glycogen Storage Disease. It is one of the most common types of Glycogen Storage Disorders (GSDs) and is caused by a deficiency in the glucose-6-phosphatase (G6Pase) enzyme. Thus, the statement I is correct.

II. Von Gierke's disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. This means the disease occurs only when parents carry a defective gene and pass it on to their children. Thus, statement II is incorrect.

III. The deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease is glucose-6-phosphatase (G6Pase), which converts glucose-6-phosphate (G6P) to glucose. This conversion occurs mainly in the liver and kidneys. Thus, statement III is incorrect.

IV. Symptoms of Von Gierke's disease include hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), hypoglycemia (low blood sugar levels), lactic acidosis (buildup of lactic acid in the body), and hyperuricemia (high levels of uric acid in the blood). Thus, statement IV is correct.


Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Statements I and III are true: This option is partially correct. Statement I is true, which states that Von Gierke's disease is also known as Type I Glycogen Storage Disease. However, statement III is false. The deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease is not involved in converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate but in the reverse reaction of converting glucose-6-phosphate to glucose.


Option C. Statements II and III are true: This option is incorrect. Statement II is false. Von Gierke's disease is not inherited in an autosomal dominant manner but in an autosomal recessive manner. Statement III is also false. The deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease is glucose-6-phosphatase, which is involved in the reverse reaction of converting glucose-6-phosphate to glucose.

Option D. Statements III and IV are true: This option is partially correct. Statement III is false, which describes the deficient enzyme in Von Gierke's disease, which is glucose-6-phosphatase, involved in the reverse reaction of converting glucose to glucose-6-phosphate. Statement IV is true, which lists the symptoms of Von Gierke's disease, which include hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia.

questions.text: Lysosomal Storage Disorders (LSDs) are a group of rare genetic disorders caused by defective lysosomal function, accumulating specific substances in various tissues and organs. Which of the following statements regarding LSDs is false?

choices.text: Krabbe disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in various tissues and organs
Tay-Sachs disease is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons.
Gaucher disease is caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase, leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various tissues and organs
Hunter syndrome is caused by a deficiency of iduronate-2-sulfatase, leading to the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate in various tissues and organs

questions.solution:
Fabry disease is caused by a deficiency of alpha-galactosidase A, leading to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide in various tissues and organs, including the kidney, heart, and nervous system. It is an X-linked disorder that mainly affects males. Symptoms include skin lesions, pain in the extremities, gastrointestinal problems, and cardiovascular disease.

However, Krabbe disease is caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency, leading to galactocerebroside and psychosine accumulation in neurons. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that affects people of all ethnicities. Symptoms include developmental delay, irritability, and seizures.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option B: Tay-Sachs disease is a rare autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase A, which leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons. 

Option C: Gaucher disease is a rare autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase, which leads to the accumulation of glucocerebroside in various tissues and organs, including the spleen, liver, and bone marrow. 

Option D: Hunter syndrome is a rare X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme iduronate-2-sulfatase. This leads to dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate accumulation in various tissues and organs.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the emergency department with weakness, fatigue, and dizziness symptoms. His medical history includes obesity, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Laboratory investigations reveal high levels of ketone bodies in the blood and urine and low glucose levels. A diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is made, and the patient is admitted to the hospital for treatment. Which enzymes are responsible for the rate-limiting step in fatty acid oxidation?
questions.solution:
• Fatty acid oxidation is the process by which fatty acids are broken down to generate energy. The process involves a series of enzymatic reactions in the cells’ mitochondria. The rate-limiting step in fatty acid oxidation is the transfer of fatty acids into the mitochondria. This process is catalyzed by the enzyme carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT-I).
  • In the case of the patient presented in the question, the high levels of ketone bodies in the blood and urine indicate increased fatty acid oxidation, which occurs when glucose is unavailable as an energy source. In diabetic ketoacidosis, there is a lack of insulin, which normally promotes glucose uptake and metabolism. As a result, the body shifts to using fatty acids for energy, leading to increased fatty acid oxidation and the production of ketone bodies.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is an enzyme that catalyzes the first step in the β-oxidation pathway of fatty acid oxidation. In this step, acyl-CoA molecules are converted to trans-2-enoyl-CoA by the removal of a hydrogen atom from the acyl-CoA molecule. While this step is important in the overall process of fatty acid oxidation, it is not the rate-limiting step.

Option C: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase II (CPT-II) is an enzyme located on the inner mitochondrial membrane that catalyzes the transfer of acyl groups from acyl-carnitine back to acyl-CoA, allowing for further oxidation of fatty acids. CPT-II is also regulated by malonyl-CoA, which inhibits the transfer of acyl-carnitine into the mitochondrial matrix.

Option D: β-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase is an enzyme that catalyzes the third step in β-oxidation, which involves the conversion of β-hydroxyacyl-CoA to β-ketoacyl-CoA. This step is important in the overall process of fatty acid oxidation but is not the rate-limiting step.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient presents with a history of unexplained weight loss, fatigue, and decreased appetite. Laboratory tests reveal high levels of lactate and pyruvate and low levels of ATP and NADH in his blood. Further investigation reveals that the patient has a genetic defect in one of the Krebs cycle enzymes. Which enzyme is most likely affected, and how does its dysfunction affect the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Succinyl-CoA synthetase, leading to decreased energy production
Citrate synthase, leading to the accumulation of citrate
Isocitrate dehydrogenase, leading to decreased NADH production
Fumarase, leading to the accumulation of fumarate

questions.solution:
• The Krebs cycle, or the TCA or citric acid cycle, is a series of reactions in eukaryotic cells’ mitochondria. These reactions generate energy in the form of ATP, NADH, and FADH2, important electron carriers in cellular respiration.
  • TCA cycle is amphibolic cycle (having both anabolic and catabolic roles) 
  • Isocitrate dehydrogenase is an enzyme that catalyzes the third step of the Krebs cycle, converting isocitrate to alpha-ketoglutarate while producing NADH. A defect in this enzyme can lead to decreased NADH production, which can impair the ability of the electron transport chain to generate ATP.
  • When isocitrate dehydrogenase is not functioning properly, the flow of carbon through the Krebs cycle is disrupted, and the intermediates levels can accumulate. However, this accumulation is not typically the cause of the patient's symptoms. Instead, the lack of NADH production can lead to an impaired electron transport chain, resulting in decreased ATP production and the symptoms of weight loss, fatigue, and decreased appetite. The high levels of lactate and pyruvate in the patient's blood are likely due to the decreased ability of the electron transport chain to utilize these substrates.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: Succinyl-CoA synthetase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate, producing ATP in the process. A defect in this enzyme would lead to decreased energy production but would not necessarily result in the specific symptoms described in the question.

Option B: Citrate synthase is an enzyme that catalyzes the first step of the Krebs cycle, converting acetyl-CoA and oxaloacetate to citrate. While a defect in this enzyme could lead to citrate accumulation, it would not necessarily lead to the specific symptoms described in the question.

Option D: Fumarase is an enzyme that catalyzes the conversion of fumarate to malate. A defect in this enzyme could lead to the accumulation of fumarate, but it would not necessarily lead to the specific symptoms described in the question.

questions.text: Cardiac biomarkers are important diagnostic tools for evaluating patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS). Which of the following biomarkers is not specific to myocardial damage and may also be elevated in conditions such as renal failure and pulmonary embolism?
questions.solution:
• Myoglobin is a heme-containing protein that is found in skeletal and cardiac muscle. It is released into the bloodstream following muscle injury and can be used as an early biomarker of myocardial damage. However, myoglobin is not specific to cardiac muscle and may also be elevated in conditions such as rhabdomyolysis, renal failure, and pulmonary embolism. Therefore, myoglobin is not a specific biomarker for myocardial infarction (MI) and should be used in conjunction with other biomarkers such as troponin I and CK-MB.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: Creatine kinase-MB (CK-MB) is an isoenzyme of creatine kinase found primarily in cardiac muscle. It is released into the bloodstream following myocardial injury. CK-MB levels rise within 4-6 hours of the onset of symptoms and peak within 12-24 hours. CK-MB is less specific than troponin I, but it is still a useful biomarker for the diagnosis of MI.

Option C: B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) is a biomarker of heart failure and is elevated in patients with left ventricular dysfunction. BNP is released by cardiac myocytes in response to increased wall stress and is a useful biomarker for diagnosing and managing heart failure. Elevated levels of BNP are also seen in patients with the acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and can provide additional prognostic information.

Option D: C-reactive protein (CRP) is an acute-phase protein the liver produces in response to inflammation. It is not a specific biomarker for myocardial damage but may be used as a marker of inflammation in patients with ACS. Elevated levels of CRP are associated with an increased risk of adverse cardiovascular events, including MI.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue, fever, and sore throat for the past two weeks. He mentions that he has been feeling weak and has lost a few pounds. Upon physical examination, the doctor notes that the patient has enlarged tonsils with white patches, and tender lymph nodes in his neck. Blood tests reveal an elevated white blood cell count with atypical lymphocytosis. The doctor orders a heterophile antibody test, which comes back negative. What other tests can be ordered to confirm the diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: A throat culture to rule out bacterial pharyngitis
A rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
A viral capsid antigen (VCA) test for EBV
A complete blood count (CBC) with differential

questions.solution:
• The viral capsid antigen (VCA) test is a highly specific test for detecting antibodies to EBV. In infectious mononucleosis, the VCA test is often positive, even if the heterophile antibody test is negative. Therefore, if a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of infectious mononucleosis and has a negative heterophile antibody test, the VCA test can be ordered to confirm the diagnosis. 

Incorrect options:

Option A: Bacterial pharyngitis, or strep throat, can present with symptoms similar to infectious mononucleosis, such as sore throat, fever, and fatigue. However, strep throat is treated with antibiotics, whereas infectious mononucleosis is a viral infection that does not respond to antibiotics. Therefore, it is important to differentiate between the two. A throat culture can help rule out strep throat by identifying the presence of Streptococcus bacteria. However, this test does not confirm the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis, so it is not the best choice.

Option B: The rapid antigen detection test (RADT) for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a quick test that can detect the presence of EBV antigens in a patient's blood. However, this test is not as sensitive as other tests for EBV, such as the viral capsid antigen (VCA) test. Therefore, while the RADT can be useful as a quick screening test for infectious mononucleosis, it is not the most reliable test for confirming the diagnosis.

Option D: A complete blood count (CBC) with differential is a routine blood test that measures the levels of different types of blood cells, including white blood cells. In infectious mononucleosis, the white blood cell count is often elevated, and atypical lymphocytes may be present. However, this test is not specific for infectious mononucleosis and can be seen in other viral infections as well.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with symptoms of jaundice, fatigue, and shortness of breath. Laboratory investigations reveal anemia, elevated bilirubin levels, and reticulocytosis. The peripheral blood smear given below. Family history reveals that her brother has a similar condition. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary spherocytosis is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder that affects the red blood cell membrane, leading to the formation of spherocytes. Spherocytes are small, round red blood cells that lack the normal biconcave shape and are more prone to hemolysis.
  • The symptoms of hereditary spherocytosis include jaundice, fatigue, shortness of breath, and anemia. The peripheral blood smear typically shows spherocytes, and laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin levels and reticulocytosis. Family history is also an important clue, as hereditary spherocytosis is an inherited condition. Thus, the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms is Hereditary spherocytosis.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that affects red blood cell metabolism and can lead to hemolysis in certain situations, such as exposure to certain medications or infections. However, it does not typically cause spherocytosis.

Option C: Sickle cell disease is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder that affects the structure of hemoglobin, leading to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells. While sickle cell disease can cause hemolysis and anemia, it does not typically cause spherocytosis.

Option D: Thalassemia is a group of inherited blood disorders that affect the production of hemoglobin, leading to anemia. While thalassemia can cause anemia and reticulocytosis, it does not typically cause spherocytosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with symptoms of fever, chills, and severe abdominal pain. Her medical history reveals that she recently traveled to a rural area in Africa. Upon examination, the physician notes that the patient has an enlarged spleen and liver. Culture is done and colonies image is given below. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Salmonella typhi is a Gram-negative rod-shaped bacterium that causes typhoid fever. It is typically transmitted through contaminated food or water in areas with poor sanitation. Symptoms of typhoid fever include fever, chills, abdominal pain, and enlarged spleen and liver. Thus, Salmonella typhi is responsible for the patient’s symptoms.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Escherichia coli is a Gram-negative bacterium that is commonly found in the gut and can cause a range of infections, including urinary tract infections and gastroenteritis. However, it is not typically associated with the symptoms described in the question.

Option C: Vibrio cholerae is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes cholera, a severe diarrheal disease. While cholera can cause abdominal pain and fever, it is not typically associated with splenomegaly or hepatomegaly.

Option D: Yersinia pestis is a Gram-negative bacterium that causes bubonic and pneumonic plague. While it can cause fever and abdominal pain, it is not typically associated with splenomegaly or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy living in rural India had a history of cowpox infection. His sister's rash on the skin turned into a fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center. On history taking, the patient says it was just nausea, vomiting, and fever in the beginning. Later, she started having ulcers in the mouth and a rash that turned into blisters. The doctor suspected it was a contagious viral infection. The strange thing, in this case, is that the boy who is her brother, despite coming in contact with his sister multiple times, was not infected. The boy's protection from this disease by the previous infection is due to the?
questions.solution:
Option A: Antigenic cross-reactivity

The protection against smallpox by previous infection with cowpox represents antigenic cross-reactivity.

  • The above given is a case of smallpox. The fluid-filled blister with a dent in the center is characteristic of smallpox.
  • The initial mouth ulcer followed rash; eventually, blisters are a classical pattern for smallpox.
  • Antigenic cross-reactivity- Sometimes single antigen stimulates the production of various antibodies that more or less resemble the correct fit for the antigen.
  • Each of these antibodies may attack different antigens that more or less resemble one another.
  • Cross Reactivity: The ability of an individual antibody combining site to react with more than one antigenic determinant.
  • The ability of a population of antibody molecules to react with more than one Ag.

Option B: Activation Of B cell

  • Lymphocytes are part of the adaptive immune system.
  • Both T lymphocytes and B lymphocytes come under the same banner of the adaptive immune system.
  • Activation of B lymphocytes by T-lymphocytes leads to maturation of B-cell into plasma cells and antibodies formation from plasma.

Option C: Passive immunity

  • This immunity is conferred by the transfer of serum or lymphocytes from a specifically immunized individual.

Option D:Innate immunity

  •  It is the resistance that an individual possesses by birth.
  • It is not specific and is the first line of defense against pathogens.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with a history of a dirty wound on his foot. Laboratory investigations showed an elevated white blood cell count and presence of atypical lymphocytes. The smear findings are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the mode of action of the causative agent?

choices.text: Tetanus caused by Clostridium tetani, which releases tetanospasmin
Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus, which infects B lymphocytes
Tetanus caused by Clostridium botulinum, which releases botulinum toxin
Mononucleosis caused by cytomegalovirus, which infects T lymphocytes

questions.solution:
• On gram stained smear form culture shows atypical gram positive bacilli with drumstick appearance, along with a history of a dirty wound, is highly suggestive of tetanus. Clostridium tetani is an anaerobic, spore-forming bacterium that commonly resides in soil and animal feces. The spores can enter the body through puncture wounds or cuts, and under anaerobic conditions, they germinate and produce the tetanus toxin (tetanospasmin), which travels to the central nervous system and interferes with the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters, leading to muscle spasms and rigidity.

Incorrect options

Option B: Infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus typically presents with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy, along with atypical lymphocytes on peripheral smear. Mononucleosis is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, which infects B lymphocytes and leads to the proliferation of atypical lymphocytes. Muscle spasms and rigidity are not typical findings in mononucleosis.

Option C: Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which presents with muscle weakness and paralysis, not muscle spasms and rigidity. Clostridium botulinum produces botulinum toxin, which blocks the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis.

Option D: Cytomegalovirus typically causes a mild flu-like illness, and atypical lymphocytes are a common finding, but muscle spasms and rigidity are not seen in cytomegalovirus infection. Cytomegalovirus infects T lymphocytes and can cause a range of symptoms, including fever, sore throat, and fatigue. However, muscle spasms and rigidity are not typically seen in cytomegalovirus infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent fatigue and intermittent fevers. Laboratory investigations reveal a positive heterophile antibody test, elevated liver enzymes, and atypical lymphocytosis. A bone marrow biopsy is performed, which shows an increased number of reactive lymphocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Infectious mononucleosis, also known as glandular fever, is a viral infection caused by the Ebstein-Barr Virus (EBV). Symptoms of infectious mononucleosis include fever, fatigue, and atypical lymphocytosis. The heterophile antibody test is a common diagnostic test for infectious mononucleosis and is positive in approximately 80% of cases.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Hodgkin's lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that arises from specific types of lymphocytes. It typically presents with swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Atypical lymphocytosis may be seen, but a positive heterophile antibody test is not typical.

Option C: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is a type of blood cancer that arises from immature lymphocytes. It typically presents with symptoms of anemia, such as fatigue and weakness, as well as symptoms related to organ infiltration by cancer cells. Atypical lymphocytosis may be seen, but a positive heterophile antibody test is not typical.

Option D: Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a type of blood cancer that arises from mature lymphocytes. It typically presents with symptoms of anemia, such as fatigue and weakness, as well as symptoms related to organ infiltration by cancer cells. Atypical lymphocytosis may be seen, but a positive heterophile antibody test is not typical.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a high-grade fever, headache, and confusion. His medical history is significant for recent travel to Southeast Asia. MRI of the brain shows hyperintense signals in the basal ganglia. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals elevated protein levels and pleocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Japanese encephalitis (JE) is a viral infection caused by the Japanese encephalitis virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes in Southeast Asia. Symptoms of JE include fever, headache, confusion, and neurological symptoms such as tremors and seizures. MRI of the brain may show hyperintense signals in the basal ganglia. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis may reveal elevated protein levels and pleocytosis. Thus, the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms is  Japanese encephalitis virus.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is an infectious virus that can cause encephalitis. However, HSV encephalitis typically presents with focal neurological deficits and temporal lobe involvement in imaging. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis may also show elevated white blood cell counts.

Option B: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) can also cause encephalitis. However, VZV encephalitis typically presents with rash and cranial nerve palsies. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis may also show elevated white blood cell counts.

Option D: Rabies virus can cause encephalitis. However, rabies encephalitis typically presents with hydrophobia, aerophobia, and autonomic dysfunction. The cerebrospinal fluid analysis may also show elevated white blood cell counts. MRI findings in rabies encephalitis are typically nonspecific.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the hospital with a fever, headache, and a maculopapular rash on her wrists and ankles. She reports that she recently went on a camping trip in a rural area.Upon physical examination, the patient has a temperature of 101.2°F and an enlarged spleen. Laboratory investigations reveal thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test, and what is the recommended treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
• Rickettsial infections are caused by various species of bacteria that are transmitted by ticks, fleas, or mites. These infections can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fever, headache, rash, and organ dysfunction. The diagnosis of rickettsial infection is based on clinical presentation, epidemiological history, and laboratory investigations.
  • The most sensitive and specific laboratory test for rickettsial infection is PCR (polymerase chain reaction) test for Rickettsia spp. This test detects the DNA of the bacteria in blood or tissue samples and can identify the specific species of Rickettsia causing the infection. PCR testing is highly sensitive and specific and can detect the bacteria even in early stages of the disease.
  • The recommended treatment for rickettsial infection is azithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic that is effective against many species of Rickettsia. Doxycycline is an alternative antibiotic that is also effective against rickettsial infections but is contraindicated in pregnant women and young children due to its potential for tooth discoloration. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are not effective against rickettsial infections.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Blood culture is not a reliable diagnostic test for rickettsial infections because the bacteria are difficult to culture and may not grow in culture media. Doxycycline is a recommended treatment for rickettsial infections, but blood culture is not the appropriate diagnostic test. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Serological testing for Rickettsia spp. involves detecting antibodies to the bacteria in the patient's blood. This test may not be reliable in the early stages of the disease and may produce false-negative results. Moreover, ceftriaxone is not effective against rickettsial infections. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option D: Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) test for Rickettsia spp. involves staining the bacteria in clinical specimens with fluorescent antibodies. This test may not be reliable in the early stages of the disease and may produce false-negative results. Moreover, vancomycin is not effective against rickettsial infections. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the hospital with a high-grade fever, severe headache, myalgia, and eschar on the left side of the chest. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. Serological testing shows positive IgM antibodies against Orientia tsutsugamushi. Which of the following is a common complication associated with scrub typhus infection that can present similarly to infectious mononucleosis, and how can it be differentiated?

choices.text: Hemolytic anemia; by detecting the presence of autoantibodies against red blood cells
Guillain-Barré syndrome; by performing nerve conduction studies and cerebrospinal fluid analysis
Encephalitis; by performing a lumbar puncture and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain
Mononucleosis syndrome; by ruling out other etiologies of infectious mononucleosis and performing serological testing for Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

questions.solution:
• Scrub typhus is an acute febrile illness caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi, which is transmitted by the bite of infected chiggers (larval mites). Scrub typhus typically presents with symptoms such as high-grade fever, headache, myalgia, lymphadenopathy, eschar, and elevated liver enzymes, thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis. Mononucleosis syndrome is a common complication associated with scrub typhus infection and can present similarly to infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The differential diagnosis of mononucleosis syndrome includes other etiologies such as cytomegalovirus (CMV), toxoplasmosis, HIV, and viral hepatitis. Therefore, ruling out other etiologies of infectious mononucleosis is essential. Serological testing for EBV can help differentiate between scrub typhus-associated mononucleosis syndrome and EBV-associated infectious mononucleosis.
  • Hemolytic anemia is a rare complication of scrub typhus, and it presents with symptoms such as jaundice, dark urine, and pallor. The diagnosis can be made by detecting the presence of autoantibodies against red blood cells.
