Option C: A GCS score of 6 indicates moderate head injury, and the patient requires observation and serial neurological assessments. This option is incorrect. A GCS score of 6 indicates severe head injury, and these patients require urgent neurosurgical intervention.

Option D: A GCS score of 6 indicates no head injury; the patient can be discharged after observation. This option is incorrect. A GCS score of 6 indicates severe head injury, and these patients require urgent neurosurgical intervention.

questions.text: A community health worker reports that in a village, the number of maternal deaths in a year was 150. If the number of infants born in that year was 750, calculate the maternal mortality rate per 1,00,000.
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
In the village, the number of maternal deaths = 150
Number of infants born = 750
We use,
Maternal mortality ratio 

= 20,000
Therefore, the answer is 20,000.
Incorrect choices:
Option A: 2000. Since the maternal mortality rate per 1,00,000 is 20,000, it is an incorrect option.
Option B: 200. Since the maternal mortality rate per 1,00,000 is 20,000, it is an incorrect option.
Option D: 0.2. Since the maternal mortality rate per 1,00,000 is 20,000, it is an incorrect option.

questions.text: A public health researcher is studying the relationship between physical activity and cardiovascular disease risk among adults aged 40-60 years. She collects data on the physical activity level (measured in minutes per week) and cardiovascular disease risk (measured using a standardized score) from a random sample of 200 individuals in the population. She calculates the mean physical activity level as 120 minutes per week and the standard deviation as 30 minutes per week. She also calculates the mean cardiovascular disease risk as 3.5 and the standard deviation as 0.5. Using this information, calculate the standard error of the mean for the physical activity level and cardiovascular disease risk.

choices.text: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.035.
The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071.
The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.035.
The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071.

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The Standard error of the mean (SEM) is defined as the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the mean. It indicates how much the sample mean deviates from the true population mean. 
  • The formula to calculate SEM is: the standard deviation of the population ÷ square root of the sample size. 
  • In this scenario, the sample size is 200 individuals, and the mean physical activity level is 120 minutes per week with a standard deviation of 30 minutes per week.
  • Therefore, the SEM for physical activity level can be calculated as 30 ÷ √200 = 2.12 minutes per week. 
  • Similarly, the mean cardiovascular disease risk is 3.5 with a standard deviation of 0.5. Hence, the SEM for cardiovascular disease risk can be calculated as 0.5 ÷ √200 = 0.035.


Incorrect Choices:

Option A: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, risk is 0.035. This option is incorrect. The SEM for physical activity level is much larger than 0.25, which indicates a large sampling error. Additionally, the SEM for cardiovascular disease risk is much smaller than 0.035, which indicates a small sampling error.

Option B: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 2.12, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071. This option is incorrect. The SEM for physical activity level is correctly calculated as 2.12. However, the SEM for cardiovascular disease risk is not correctly calculated, as it is much larger than 0.071.

Option D: The standard error of the mean for physical activity is 0.25, and for cardiovascular disease, the risk is 0.071. This option is incorrect. The SEM for physical activity level is much larger than 0.25, which indicates a large sampling error. Additionally, the SEM for cardiovascular disease risk is much larger than 0.071, which indicates a large sampling error.

questions.text: What is the failure rate of male Condoms with typical use?
questions.solution:
Option A: 10-14/HWY

The failure rate of condom with

  • Perfect use is 2-3/HWY
  • Typical use is 10-14/HWY

Option B: 5-21/HWY

  • When using female condoms, this failure rate happens.
  • The failure rate of female condoms in pearl index is 5-12/HWY

Option C: 0.1-2/HWY

  • This least rage of failure occurs in OCP.
  • The failure rate of OCPs in pearl index is 0.1-2/HWY

Learning Objective

PEARL INDEX OF DIFFERENT CONTRACEPTION:

  • Male condoms: 2-14/HWY [14- best answer]

More effective method of sterilization is vasectomy > tubectomy.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the psychiatric outpatient department due to low mood for 5 weeks. It is associated with a lack of energy and appetite, poor concentration, and weight loss. She also reports suicidal intent. She is diagnosed with a case of major depressive disorder. She is to be started on fluoxetine. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of fluoxetine?

choices.text: Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake
Inhibition of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine catabolism
Inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake

questions.solution:
Option A: Inhibition of serotonin reuptake

  • Medical treatment for major depressive disorder includes:
    • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs)
    • Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs)
    • Tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs)
    • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOs)
    • Norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake inhibitors
    • Mixed action agents
    • Pre- and postsynaptic active agents
  • SSRIs include citalopram, escitalopram, fluoxetine, paroxetine, sertraline, fluvoxamine, and vilazodone.
  • SSRIs act by inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin from the synaptic clefts. Thus, increasing its levels in the clefts improves symptoms of depression.
  • SSRIs are FDA-approved for major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, post traumatic stress disorder, social anxiety disorder, bulimia nervosa, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder.
  • They are also used for anorexia nervosa, obesity, premature ejaculation, paraphilias, and autism.
  • Adverse reactions include anorgasmia, inhibited orgasm, decreased libido, nausea, diarrhoea, anorexia, flatulence, dyspepsia, prolonged QT interval, headaches, somnolence, insomnia, emotional blunting, vivid dreams or nightmares, anticholinergic effects, and serotonin syndrome.
  • The abrupt discontinuation of SSRI use, especially with a shorter half-life such as paroxetine or fluvoxamine, has been associated with withdrawal syndrome that may include dizziness, insomnia, nausea, headache, rebound depression, anxiety, poor concentration, upper respiratory symptoms, paresthesias, and migraine-like symptoms.

Option B: Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake

  • SSRIs block the reuptake of serotonin only.
  • Inhibition of serotonin and norepinephrine is the mechanism of action of SNRIs and TCAs.
  • SNRIs include venlafaxine, duloxetine, and desvenlafaxine.
  • TCAs include amitriptyline, nortriptyline, and imipramine.

Option C: Inhibition of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine catabolism

  • SSRIs block the reuptake of serotonin.
  • MOA inhibitors block the catabolism of serotonin, dopamine, and norepinephrine.
  • MOA inhibitors include phenelzine and isocarboxazid.

Option D: Inhibition of dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake

  • SSRIs block the reuptake of serotonin selectively.
  • Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake are inhibited by bupropion.

questions.text: A 22 years old male is brought to the hospital by his parents with complaints of a change of behaviour. He is experiencing decreased sleep, increased sexual activity and enormous excitement. His parents say he has been spending excessively for 8 days and started gambling. During talks with the patient, the flight of ideas is noticeable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Mania

  • The symptomatic profile of this patient suggests the diagnosis of mania.
  • Characteristic features of mania are:
    • Elation of Mood
    • Delusion of Grandeur
    • Increased psychomotor activity (usually goal-oriented)
    • More talkative
    • Pressurized speech, use playful language
    • Flight of ideas
    • Reduced sleep
  • Overactivity and poor judgment – this person is involved in high-risk activities like reckless driving, foolish business investments, and distributing money to unknown persons.
  • Pharmacotherapy for acute mania includes mood stabilizers such as lithium, valproate, and second-generation antipsychotics.

Option A: Post-traumatic stress disorder

  • Post-traumatic stress disorder is characterized by nightmares, flashbacks, fear, horror, and distress.
  • Elated symptoms are rare in this condition.

Option C: Schizophrenia

  •  Symptoms of schizophrenia are-
    • positive symptoms- hallucinations, delusions, bizarre behavior
    • negative symptoms- flat affect, apathy, social withdrawal
    • cognitive symptoms- reduced ability to understand or memory

Option D: Delusion​​​​​​​

  • A false idiosyncratic belief is present in the patient even after contradictory evidence in the patient with delusion.
  • Although grandiosity is common in mania and delusions, flight of ideas is not seen in delusions.

questions.text: Mrs. X, a 28-year-old female, presents to the psychiatry outpatient department with a complaint of persistent feelings of emptiness, identity disturbance, and difficulty in maintaining stable relationships for the past five years. She has a history of impulsive behaviors such as binge-eating, substance abuse, and sexual promiscuity. She also reports a history of physical and emotional abuse during childhood. On examination, she appears anxious, avoids eye contact, and exhibits self-injurious behaviors. She is diagnosed with a personality disorder. Which of the following personality disorders is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient's symptoms are consistent with Borderline personality disorder (BPD), which is characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, as well as marked impulsivity. The patient reports a history of impulsive behaviors such as binge-eating, substance abuse, and sexual promiscuity. Moreover, the patient has difficulty in maintaining stable relationships and reports persistent feelings of emptiness and identity disturbance. These symptoms are consistent with BPD.
  • Additionally, the patient reports a history of physical and emotional abuse during childhood, which is a common risk factor for developing BPD. Furthermore, the patient exhibits self-injurious behaviors, which is a common feature of BPD.

Incorrect options: 
Option B: Histrionic personality disorder is characterized by a pattern of excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. It is unlikely to be the diagnosis in this case, as the patient's symptoms are not primarily related to seeking attention.

Option C: Narcissistic personality disorder is characterized by a grandiose sense of self-importance, a preoccupation with fantasies of unlimited success, and a lack of empathy for others. It is unlikely to be the diagnosis in this case, as the patient's symptoms are not primarily related to a grandiose sense of self-importance.

Option D: Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive disregard for the rights of others, as well as a pattern of deceit and manipulation. While the patient's history of substance abuse and sexual promiscuity are consistent with antisocial personality disorder, her symptoms are not primarily related to a disregard for the rights of others.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female with a history of severe depression, suicidal ideation, and multiple failed medication trials presents to the psychiatric hospital for electroconvulsive therapy (ECT). She has undergone ECT in the past with some improvement in her symptoms but has not had a treatment in over a year. On examination, she appears disheveled, and her affect is constricted. She reports feeling hopeless and has lost interest in her usual activities. Her laboratory workup is unremarkable. What are the indications for ECT in the treatment of depression, and what are the potential adverse effects of ECT?

choices.text: ECT is indicated for treatment-resistant depression, and adverse effects include memory impairment, headache, and nausea.
ECT is indicated for moderate to severe depression, and adverse effects include cardiac arrhythmias, hypertension, and seizures.
ECT is indicated for severe depression with psychosis, and adverse effects include hypotension, bradycardia, and anemia.
ECT is indicated for mild to moderate depression, and adverse effects include increased appetite, weight gain, and hyperactivity.

questions.solution:
• The patient presents with a history of severe depression, suicidal ideation, and multiple failed medication trials, which are indications for ECT in the treatment of depression. ECT has been shown to be effective in treating treatment-resistant depression, severe depression with psychosis, and other psychiatric conditions such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. The potential adverse effects of ECT include memory impairment, headache, and nausea, among others. Memory impairment is the most common side effect, and it may be transient or persistent, with the risk of persistent memory impairment increasing with the number of ECT treatments.

Indications of ECT 

  • Severe Depressive disorders not responding to medication
  • Psychosis
  • Suicidal plans/attempts
  • Schizophrenia Psychosis
  • When medication are not tolerated 
  • Medical conditions that do not allow for conventional treatment 

Incorrect Choice: 

  • Option B) While ECT can cause short-term memory loss, it is typically not permanent, and patients generally recover their memories over time. Long-term memory loss is not a common side effect of ECT.
  • Option C) ECT is not typically used as a first-line treatment for anxiety disorders, as medications and psychotherapy are often more effective in treating these conditions. ECT is typically reserved for individuals with severe or treatment-resistant depression.
  • Option D) While ECT does involve the use of electric currents to induce seizures, the procedure is performed under general anesthesia and muscle relaxants to minimize discomfort and prevent injury. Additionally, modern ECT machines use lower voltages and shorter pulses than earlier machines, reducing the risk of adverse effects. ECT is generally considered a safe procedure when performed by experienced professionals.

questions.text: After 5 days, the search team recovered the body of the 10-year-old boy who had gone missing while swimming in the lake. The skin of the boy showed signs of cutis anserina and the hands were seen clenched with weed and gravel in it. Which of the following findings would also be seen in a case of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • All the mentioned signs suggest signs of antemortem drowning.

Option A: Water in the small intestine

  • The presence of water in the stomach & small intestine is included in the internal finding of antemortem drowning.

Option B: Emphysema aquosum

  • When the person is unconscious at the time of drowning, edema aquosum develops.
  • It is a state of mere flooding of lungs with airless water and no formation of froth.
  • Emphysema aquosum develops only when the conscious victim of drowning struggles for survival.

Option C: Hemorrhage in the middle ear

  • The presence of water and hemorrhage in the middle ear also be seen in the case of antemortem drowning.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of heart disease and diabetes presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. The treating physician fails to order appropriate diagnostic tests and sends the patient home with instructions to take antacids. The patient subsequently suffers a heart attack and dies. Which is the most appropriate legal classification for the physician's actions?
questions.solution:
• Gross negligence is a type of negligence that involves a willful or reckless disregard for the safety or life of another person. In this case, the physician's failure to order appropriate diagnostic tests for a patient with a history of heart disease and diabetes, as well as their decision to send the patient home with instructions to take antacids despite the presence of chest pain and shortness of breath, constitutes a reckless disregard for the patient's life and safety.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option B. Contributory negligence refers to a situation in which the plaintiff's own negligence contributes to their injury or harm. However, in this scenario, there is no indication that the patient's actions contributed to their own harm. The physician's failure to provide appropriate care and treatment is the primary cause of the patient's harm.
  • Option C. Ordinary negligence refers to a situation in which a person fails to exercise reasonable care, harming another person. While the physician's actions in this scenario may be considered negligent, they go beyond ordinary negligence. The failure to order appropriate diagnostic tests and send the patient home with antacids despite symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath could be considered reckless and a disregard for the patient's safety.
  • Option D. Comparative negligence is a legal doctrine that apportions damages based on the degree of fault of each party involved in an incident. However, in this scenario, there is no indication that the patient's actions contributed to their own harm. The physician's failure to provide appropriate care and treatment is the primary cause of the patient's harm, and thus comparative negligence is not an appropriate legal classification in this case.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. He reports that he ate some berries from a plant he found while hiking in the woods earlier that day. The image of the plant is given below. Which of the following is the primary toxin responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Atropa belladonna, or deadly nightshade, contains a number of alkaloids, including atropine, scopolamine, and hyoscyamine. These alkaloids can cause various symptoms, including gastrointestinal upset, hallucinations, delirium, and respiratory depression.
  • However, hyoscyamine is the most abundant alkaloid in Atropa belladonna and is the primary toxin responsible for the patient's vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain symptoms. Hyoscyamine is an anticholinergic agent that can cause gastrointestinal symptoms by inhibiting the action of acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter that regulates the digestive system.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option A. Atropine is an anticholinergic agent found in Atropa belladonna, but it is not the primary toxin responsible for the patient's symptoms in this case. Atropine can cause various symptoms, including dry mouth, blurred vision, tachycardia, and confusion. However, in this case, the patient's primary symptoms are gastrointestinal, which are more consistent with the actions of hyoscyamine.
  • Option B. Scopolamine is another anticholinergic agent found in Atropa belladonna, but it is not the primary toxin responsible for the patient's symptoms in this case. Scopolamine can cause various symptoms, including drowsiness, dizziness, and blurred vision. However, in this case, the patient's primary symptoms are gastrointestinal, which are more consistent with the actions of hyoscyamine.
  • Option D. Solanine is a toxic alkaloid found in some plants, such as potatoes and tomatoes, but it is not found in Atropa belladonna and is not responsible for the patient's symptoms in this case. Solanine can cause various symptoms, including gastrointestinal upset, headache, and dizziness. However, it is irrelevant to this case as the patient ingested Atropa belladonna, which contains different toxic alkaloids.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was involved in a car accident and suffered a blow to the head. CT scan revealed a linear fracture in the left temporal bone, extending to the petrous portion of the temporal bone. Which cranial nerves are most likely to be affected by this fracture?
questions.solution:
• The facial nerve (CN VII) is the most likely to be affected by a linear fracture in the left temporal bone, extending to the petrous portion of the temporal bone. The facial nerve passes through the temporal bone in a narrow canal called the facial canal, and a fracture in this area can compress or damage the nerve, leading to facial weakness or paralysis.


Incorrect Choices:

  • Option A. Optic nerve (CN II): The optic nerve passes through the optic canal in the sphenoid bone, which is not in the vicinity of the temporal bone. Therefore, a linear fracture in the temporal bone extending to the petrous portion is unlikely to affect the optic nerve.
  • Option B. Oculomotor nerve (CN III): The oculomotor nerve passes through the cavernous sinus, which is located in the middle cranial fossa and does not traverse the temporal bone. Therefore, a fracture in the temporal bone extending to the petrous portion is unlikely to affect the oculomotor nerve.
  • Option C. Trochlear nerve (CN IV): The trochlear nerve also passes through the cavernous sinus and does not traverse the temporal bone. Therefore, a fracture in the temporal bone extending to the petrous portion is unlikely to affect the trochlear nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male was brought dead for post-mortem. On examination, he is cyanotic with petechiae in his face and conjunctiva. He had restricted blood flow to the brain and lungs. No toxic substance or presence of foreign object was detected in the airway passage.. What is the most likely cause of his death?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The asphyxia that occurs due to the closure of air passages or blood vessels due to external pressure around the neck is known as strangulation. 
  • Strangulation is the most likely cause of asphyxia in this case. Any external pressure around the neck of a person (maybe by rope) would have compressed the airway and blood vessels, leading to restricted blood flow to the brain and lungs. The cyanosis and petechiae in the face and conjunctiva are typical signs of strangulation. 

Findings are:


  • Face will be intensely congested due to decreased venous return from the head
  • Petechial hemorrhages are seen over face
  • Sub-conjunctival hemorrhages are seen
  • Bleeding from the nose/ ear can also be noted
  • On neck dissection, contusions in the soft tissues of the neck are seen

Incorrect Choices:

Option A Drowning

  • Drowning refers to the inability of a person to inhale or breathe air or oxygen because the person has inhaled water. It does not involve obstruction of the airway by an external force, as seen in strangulation.

Option B Choking

  • Choking involves the obstruction of the airway by a foreign object, such as a piece of food or a small toy. This leads to the inability to breathe and can result in asphyxia. However, in this case, the patient was found with no toxic substance or presence of a foreign object in the airway passage, which suggests choking is not the cause of asphyxia.

Option D Chemical asphyxia

  • Chemical asphyxia is caused by the inhalation of toxic substances, such as carbon monoxide or cyanide, which interfere with the ability of the body to use oxygen. This can result in asphyxia, but it is not the likely cause in this case.

questions.text: A is charged with the murder of B. During the trial, the prosecution produces a letter allegedly written by A, in which A confesses to the murder. A claims that the letter is a forgery and denies writing it. Which of the following sections of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) is applicable in this case?

choices.text: A is charged with the murder of B. During the trial, the prosecution produces a letter allegedly written by A, in which A confesses to the murder. A claims that the letter is a forgery and denies writing it. Which of the following sections of the Indian Evidence Act (IEA) is applicable in this case?

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Section 47 of the Indian Evidence Act states that when the court has to form an opinion as to the handwriting of any person, the opinion of any person acquainted with the handwriting of that person is relevant. In this case, the prosecution has produced a letter allegedly written by A, and A denies writing it. Therefore, the court may require the opinion of an expert in handwriting to determine whether or not A wrote the letter.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option A - Section 45 of the Indian Evidence Act deals with the opinion of experts. It states that when the court has to form an opinion upon a point of science, art, or foreign law, the opinions of persons who are experts in such sciences, arts, or foreign laws are relevant facts. However, this section is not directly relevant to the issue of handwriting in this case.
  • Option C - Section 53A of the Indian Evidence Act deals with the opinion as to electronic records. This section states that if a document is produced as an electronic record, the court may presume that it was duly generated, stored, and transmitted. However, this section is not relevant in this case as the letter in question is not an electronic record.
  • Option D - Section 71 of the Indian Evidence Act deals with proof when attesting witness denies the execution. This section states that if a document is attested and the attesting witness denies or does not remember having attested it, the court may admit the document if it is proved to be in the handwriting of the person who executed it. However, this section is not directly relevant to the issue of whether or not A wrote the letter in question.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of gradual loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. On examination, the patient has elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) in both eyes, with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.6 in both eyes. Gonioscopy shows an open angle in both eyes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Primary Open-Angle Glaucoma (POAG) is the most common type of glaucoma and is characterized by elevated IOP, an open angle on gonioscopy, and a progressive loss of peripheral vision. The cup-to-disc ratio is typically greater than 0.5 in POAG. Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma is characterized by a closed or narrow-angle on gonioscopy and typically presents with acute symptoms such as eye pain, nausea, and vomiting. Secondary glaucoma is caused by another underlying condition, such as uveitis or diabetes, and is typically managed by treating the underlying condition. Normal-Tension Glaucoma is a form of glaucoma in which the IOP is not elevated, but there is still progressive optic nerve damage and visual field loss.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma is an incorrect choice because the patient has an open angle on gonioscopy. Primary Angle-Closure Glaucoma is characterized by a closed or narrow angle on gonioscopy and typically presents with acute symptoms such as eye pain, nausea, and vomiting.

Option B: Secondary Glaucoma is an incorrect choice because there is no underlying condition identified that is causing the elevated IOP. Secondary Glaucoma is caused by another underlying condition, such as uveitis or diabetes, and is typically managed by treating the underlying condition.

Option C: Normal-Tension Glaucoma is an incorrect choice because the patient has elevated IOP. Normal-Tension Glaucoma is a form of glaucoma in which the IOP is not elevated, but there is still progressive optic nerve damage and visual field loss.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with sudden onset of double vision and drooping of the left eyelid. Examination reveals a left hypertropia and left ptosis. The patient is unable to elevate the left eye above the midline. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient's presentation is consistent with a paralytic squint, also known as a paralytic strabismus. The sudden onset of double vision and drooping of the left eyelid suggests an acute onset of weakness of the left superior rectus muscle, which is responsible for elevating the eye. The left hypertropia and left ptosis further support the diagnosis of a left superior rectus palsy.
  • Concomitant esotropia and exotropia are types of non-paralytic strabismus, which are characterized by a constant deviation of the eyes that does not change with gaze direction. Non-paralytic strabismus can be managed with prism glasses or surgery, depending on the severity of the deviation.
  • In contrast, paralytic strabismus results from a weakness or paralysis of one or more extraocular muscles, often due to damage to the oculomotor nerve or its branches. The management of paralytic strabismus depends on the underlying cause, which may require medical or surgical intervention. In this case, further evaluation is warranted to determine the cause of the left superior rectus palsy.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Concomitant Esotropia - Concomitant esotropia is a type of non-paralytic strabismus in which the eyes are turned inward at all times, regardless of gaze direction. It is not consistent with the patient's presentation of a sudden onset of double vision and a left hypertropia, which suggest a paralytic strabismus.

Option B: Concomitant Exotropia - Concomitant exotropia is a type of non-paralytic strabismus in which the eyes are turned outward at all times, regardless of gaze direction. It is not consistent with the patient's presentation of a sudden onset of double vision and left hypertropia, which suggest a paralytic strabismus.

Option D: Non-paralytic Strabismus - Non-paralytic strabismus is characterized by a constant deviation of the eyes that does not change with gaze direction. It is not consistent with the patient's presentation of a sudden onset of double vision and a left hypertropia, which suggest a paralytic strabismus.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of difficulty reading small print and blurred vision. On examination, his visual acuity is found to be 6/60 in both eyes. Snellen's chart is used to assess his visual acuity. What does 6/60 mean on the Snellen's chart?

choices.text: He can read at 6 meters what a person with normal vision can read at 60 meters
He can read at 60 meters what a person with normal vision can read at 6 meters
He can read at 6 feet what a person with normal vision can read at 60 feet
He can read at 60 feet what a person with normal vision can read at 6 feet

questions.solution:
This means that the patient's visual acuity is reduced, and he can read the same line of letters at a distance of 60 meters that a person with normal vision would be able to read at a distance of 6 meters.

In other words, the patient's visual acuity is one-tenth of normal, which is a measure of 0.1 on the Snellen chart. This is considered to be severe visual impairment or low vision. The patient may require corrective lenses or other treatments to improve his visual acuity. It is important to use the correct values and units of measurement when interpreting the results of a Snellen chart test.


Incorrect options:

Option A) This option reverses the values of the numerator and denominator. The numerator indicates the distance at which the patient is standing, while the denominator indicates the distance at which a person with normal vision can read the same line. Therefore, the correct option would be "He can read at 60 meters what a person with normal vision can read at 6 meters."

Option C) This option uses feet instead of meters. The Snellen chart is typically measured in meters or feet, and it is important to use the correct unit of measurement. The correct option would be "He can read at 60 meters what a person with normal vision can read at 6 meters."

Option D) This option also reverses the values of the numerator and denominator, and it uses feet instead of meters. The correct option would be "He can read at 60 meters what a person with normal vision can read at 6 meters."

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty in reading and recognizing faces. On examination, he has a right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing. The most likely location of the lesion is:
questions.solution:
Visual field defects occur due to lesions along the visual pathway. The location of the lesion determines the pattern of visual field defect. In this case, the patient has a right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, which indicates a lesion in the left visual cortex.


Incorrect options:

Option A) A lesion in the left optic nerve would cause complete loss of vision in the left eye, but not a homonymous hemianopia.

Option B) A lesion in the left optic chiasm would affect the crossing fibers from the right eye, leading to a bitemporal hemianopia, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

Option C) A lesion in the left LGN would cause a left homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing. The presence of macular sparing indicates that the lesion is located in the occipital cortex.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man was involved in a road traffic accident and sustained an injury to his right eye. On examination, the patient's visual acuity in the right eye is found to be reduced to 6/36, and there is a large subconjunctival hemorrhage. The patient complains of double vision, and there is an upward deviation of the right eye on attempted adduction. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms of reduced visual acuity, subconjunctival hemorrhage, double vision, and upward deviation of the eye on attempted adduction are indicative of an orbital floor fracture. The fracture can cause a compression of the inferior rectus muscle, which results in the eye being unable to adduct, and the eye may also be displaced downwards due to the lack of support from the orbital floor. Treatment may involve surgery to repair the fracture and restore normal eye movement and visual acuity.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Retrobulbar hemorrhage occurs when there is bleeding behind the eye, which can cause pain, proptosis (bulging of the eye), and vision loss. However, in this case, the patient's symptoms are more consistent with an orbital floor fracture, and retrobulbar hemorrhage would not cause double vision or an upward deviation of the eye on attempted adduction.


Option B) Traumatic optic neuropathy can occur following trauma to the eye or orbit, and it can result in vision loss. However, the patient's symptoms of double vision and upward deviation of the eye are not consistent with this diagnosis, and the presence of a subconjunctival hemorrhage suggests an orbital injury.


Option D) Corneal abrasion is a scratch or scrape on the cornea, which can cause pain, tearing, and sensitivity to light. While corneal abrasions can occur following eye trauma, the patient's symptoms of reduced visual acuity, double vision, and upward deviation of the eye on attempted adduction suggest a more significant injury, such as an orbital floor fracture.

questions.text: A fifty-five years old male presents to your clinic with complaints of decreased vision. He is unable to afford doctor appointments and treatment. His visual problems make it impossible for him to work and earn to feed his family. Visual impairment and blindness significantly impact the socioeconomic development of individuals and societies. For a patient to be labelled with Economic blindness, his visual acuity should be?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vision < 6/60 to 3/60

  • ​​​​​​​Economic blindness defined by national programme for control of blindness (NPCB) is characterised as visual acuity < 6/60 to 3/60.

Option B: Vision < 3/60 to 1/60

  • Social blindness is characterised by visual acuity < 3/60 to 1/60.
  • Economic blindness is characterised as visual acuity < 6/60 to 3/60.

Option C: Vision < 1/60 to perception of light

  • Manifest blindness < 1/60 to perception of light.
  • Economic blindness is characterised as visual acuity < 6/60 to 3/60.

Option D: No perception of light

  • No perception of light is absolute blindness.
  • Economic blindness is characterised as visual acuity < 6/60 to 3/60.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient from a rural area presents with complaints of recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis and visual impairment for the last 5 years. The patient has a history of frequent exposure to dust and flies due to his occupation as a farmer. On examination, follicular conjunctivitis, thickening of tarsal conjunctiva, trichiasis, and corneal opacity are noted in both eyes. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Treatment with topical erythromycin ointment for 6 weeks
Oral azithromycin, along with topical tetracycline ointment for 6 weeks
Topical azithromycin, along with oral doxycycline for 6 weeks
Surgery for trichiasis, along with topical tetracycline ointment for 6 weeks

questions.solution:
Trachoma is a chronic eye infection caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis. The infection spreads through direct contact with eye and nose secretions of infected individuals, as well as through contact with contaminated objects, such as towels or handkerchiefs.

The clinical presentation of trachoma involves conjunctival inflammation, follicular conjunctivitis, thickening of tarsal conjunctiva, trichiasis, and corneal opacity. Trichiasis, which is the inward turning of the eyelashes, can lead to corneal abrasions and scarring, resulting in visual impairment and blindness.

The management of trachoma involves a multifaceted approach that includes the following steps:

Step 1: Antibiotic therapy

The primary goal of antibiotic therapy is to eradicate the infection and prevent recurrence. The antibiotic of choice is azithromycin, which can be given orally as a single dose or in a weekly regimen for 3-6 weeks. Topical tetracycline ointment is also effective in treating trachoma, although it is less commonly used due to the need for frequent application.

Step 2: Surgery for trichiasis

Surgery is indicated for patients with trichiasis, as it helps to prevent corneal scarring and visual impairment. The surgical procedure involves the removal of the misdirected eyelashes and repositioning of the eyelid margin.

Step 3: Hygiene and environmental improvements

Improving personal hygiene and living conditions can help to prevent the spread of trachoma. This includes frequent hand washing, using clean towels and handkerchiefs, and avoiding crowded living conditions.

Incorrect options: 
Option A) Topical erythromycin ointment is an effective treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis. The ointment is applied to the affected eye(s) multiple times a day for 6 weeks. This treatment is usually well-tolerated, but it can cause some mild side effects, such as eye irritation or burning. It is important to complete the full course of treatment to ensure that the infection is fully eradicated.

Option B) Oral azithromycin is another effective treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis. It is a macrolide antibiotic that is taken orally for 1-5 days. When used in combination with topical tetracycline ointment for 6 weeks, it can help to clear the infection and prevent it from recurring. This treatment is usually well-tolerated, but it can cause some side effects, such as stomach upset or diarrhea.

Option C) Topical azithromycin is a newer treatment option for chlamydial conjunctivitis. It is a macrolide antibiotic that is applied to the affected eye(s) multiple times a day for 6 weeks. When used in combination with oral doxycycline for 6 weeks, it can help to clear the infection and prevent it from recurring. This treatment is usually well-tolerated, but it can cause some side effects, such as eye irritation or burning, or stomach upset.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presents with a 2-week history of ocular pain, photophobia, and blurred vision in her right eye. On examination, there is conjunctival injection, a small corneal infiltrate, and anterior chamber cells and flare. A diagnosis of anterior uveitis is made. The patient has a history of anaphylactic reaction to sulfa drugs, and is currently taking a daily dose of 50mg of prednisone for rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with topical prednisolone acetate 1% q1h and atropine sulfate 1% BID
Initiate treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone 1g/day for 3 days

questions.solution:
Anterior uveitis is a type of uveitis that involves inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. Treatment typically involves the use of topical corticosteroids and cycloplegic agents to reduce inflammation and prevent synechiae formation.

In this case, the patient has a history of anaphylactic reaction to sulfa drugs, which rules out the use of systemic sulfonamide antibiotics or sulfasalazine for the treatment of uveitis. The most appropriate management strategy for this patient is to initiate treatment with topical prednisolone acetate 1% q1h and atropine sulfate 1% BID, which will effectively reduce inflammation and prevent the formation of synechiae without the risk of systemic side effects.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Initiate treatment with oral prednisone 1mg/kg/day: This option is not appropriate for this patient because the patient is already taking a daily dose of 50mg of prednisone for rheumatoid arthritis, and adding more systemic corticosteroids may increase the risk of systemic side effects.

Option C) Initiate treatment with oral cyclosporine 2.5mg/kg/day: Oral cyclosporine may be used in cases of chronic uveitis, but it is not typically the first-line treatment for acute anterior uveitis. Furthermore, it may take several weeks for cyclosporine to take effect, and the patient's symptoms require more immediate treatment.

Option D) Initiate treatment with intravenous methylprednisolone 1g/day for 3 days: Intravenous methylprednisolone is typically reserved for severe or sight-threatening cases of uveitis, and is not indicated in this case. The patient's symptoms are not severe enough to warrant such an aggressive treatment, and the risk of systemic side effects is also higher with this option.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents with a history of fever, otalgia, and postauricular swelling for the past 2 days. On examination, the child has a temperature of 101°F, with erythema and tenderness over the right mastoid. The ear canal is inflamed and there is purulent discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
Based on the symptoms and physical examination findings described in the given question, it is likely that the child has acute mastoiditis.
Firstly, the child has a history of fever, otalgia (ear pain), and postauricular swelling (swelling behind the ear), all common symptoms of acute mastoiditis.
Secondly, on physical examination, the child has erythema (redness) and tenderness over the right mastoid, which suggests that the infection has spread to the mastoid bone. In addition, the ear canal is inflamed and there is purulent (pus) discharge, which is also consistent with acute mastoiditis.
Acute mastoiditis is a serious infection that requires hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics. Treatment should be initiated immediately to prevent complications such as meningitis or intracranial abscess. Surgical intervention may be indicated in severe cases or patients who do not respond to antibiotic therapy.

Incorrect Choices:
Option A. Acute mastoiditis is an infection of the mastoid bone, a complication of acute otitis media (AOM). Treatment involves appropriate antibiotics, but oral antibiotics alone are inappropriate for this patient's presentation. Intravenous antibiotics are required for this patient.
Option B. Myringotomy is a surgical procedure in which an incision is made in the tympanic membrane to relieve pressure and drain fluid from the middle ear. This procedure is not indicated in the treatment of acute mastoiditis.
Option C. Mastoidectomy is the surgical removal of the mastoid bone, which may be indicated in patients with chronic mastoiditis or complications of acute mastoiditis. In the acute setting, however, intravenous antibiotics and hospitalization are the first-line treatment.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents a history of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) of the left ear. He has been treated with oral antibiotics several times in the past but has not responded well to treatment. On examination, the left ear drum is not visible due to the discharge, and there is granulation tissue in the ear canal. The patient complains of vertigo and hearing loss in the left ear. Which of the following is the most likely complication of this patient's CSOM?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Labyrinthitis is an inner ear inflammation that can result from an infection of the middle ear. Symptoms include vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus. Labyrinthitis is a potential complication of CSOM, especially if the infection spreads to the inner ear.
Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Tympanosclerosis is the formation of calcified plaques in the middle ear. It can occur due to chronic inflammation and scarring, such as in CSOM. Tympanosclerosis can cause hearing loss but is not typically associated with vertigo.

Option C: Otosclerosis is a condition in which abnormal bone growth in the middle ear can cause hearing loss. It is unrelated to CSOM, although both conditions can cause hearing loss.

Option D: An acoustic neuroma is a benign tumor that grows on the vestibulocochlear nerve, responsible for hearing and balance. While acoustic neuromas can cause symptoms similar to those seen in CSOM, such as hearing loss and vertigo, they are not a complication of CSOM.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with hearing difficulties in both ears. You perform a pure tone audiometry and obtain the following results: Right ear - normal hearing up to 250 Hz, moderate hearing loss at 500 Hz, severe hearing loss at 1 kHz, profound hearing loss at 2 kHz and 4 kHz. Left ear - normal hearing up to 500 Hz, mild hearing loss at 1 kHz, moderate hearing loss at 2 kHz and 4 kHz. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 
This scenario's pure tone audiometry results are consistent with the conductive hearing loss pattern typically seen in otosclerosis. Otosclerosis is a middle ear disorder characterized by abnormal growth of bone in the ear, leading to conductive hearing loss. 
Specifically, the low-frequency hearing loss seen in this scenario is consistent with the bone conduction thresholds being elevated, while the high-frequency hearing loss is consistent with the air conduction thresholds being more elevated.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Acoustic neuroma (also known as vestibular schwannoma) is a type of benign tumor that occurs on the vestibular nerve that connects the ear to the brain. It is typically associated with unilateral hearing loss and tinnitus rather than the bilateral hearing loss present in this scenario. Additionally, the pure tone audiometry results in this scenario are inconsistent with the characteristic high-frequency hearing loss in acoustic neuroma.

Option B. Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear characterized by episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and fluctuating hearing loss, typically affecting one ear initially. The hearing loss seen in Meniere's disease is typically low frequency initially, rather than the high-frequency hearing loss present in this scenario. Meniere's disease is usually associated with unilateral hearing loss, whereas the patient in this scenario has bilateral hearing loss.

Option C. Presbyacusis is age-related hearing loss, typically affecting high-frequency sounds initially. However, this scenario's pure tone audiometry results are inconsistent with the characteristic high-frequency hearing loss seen in presbyacusis. Additionally, this type of hearing loss is typically bilateral and symmetric rather than asymmetric, as seen in this scenario.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a complaint of vertigo that began suddenly while she was turning over in bed. Vertigo is described as a spinning sensation that lasts for a few seconds and is accompanied by nausea. On examination, there is nystagmus that is triggered by a Dix-Hallpike maneuver. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) is the most likely diagnosis in this case. BPPV is a common cause of vertigo that is triggered by positional changes. Vertigo typically lasts for a few seconds and is accompanied by nystagmus. The Dix-Hallpike maneuver is used to diagnose BPPV, and the nystagmus is typically horizontal and torsional.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Vestibular migraine is associated with vertigo, but it usually lasts longer than a few seconds and is not typically triggered by a positional change. Additionally, there is usually a history of headaches and other migraine symptoms.

Option B. Labyrinthitis is an inner ear inflammation that can cause vertigo, but it usually lasts for days to weeks. A positional change does not typically trigger it. Additionally, there may be hearing loss and ringing in the ears.

Option D. Meniere's disease is a disorder of the inner ear that can cause vertigo. However, it typically lasts longer than a few seconds and is not typically triggered by a positional change. Additionally, there may be hearing loss, ringing in the ears, and a feeling of fullness or pressure in the ear.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for amplifying sound waves and improving the sensitivity of the cochlea to high-frequency sounds?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 
Middle ear muscles, specifically the tensor tympani and stapedius muscles, are responsible for amplifying sound waves and improving the sensitivity of the cochlea to high-frequency sounds. The contraction of these muscles reduces the mobility of the ossicles in response to loud sounds, which limits the amount of sound that reaches the inner ear. 
This is known as the acoustic reflex and is important for protecting the inner ear from damage due to loud sounds, which limits the amount of sound that reaches the inner ear. 

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Tectorial membrane is a gelatinous structure in the cochlea that covers the hair cells. It plays a role in the transduction of sound waves into neural signals but does not amplify sound waves or improve the sensitivity of the cochlea to high-frequency sounds.

Option B. Basilar membrane is a flexible cochlea membrane containing hair cells. It is responsible for separating incoming sound waves into different frequencies, but it does not amplify sound waves or improve the sensitivity of the cochlea to high-frequency sounds.

Option C. Oval window is a membrane separating the middle and inner ear. It is responsible for transmitting sound waves from the middle ear to the inner ear, but it does not amplify sound waves or improve the sensitivity of the cochlea to high-frequency sounds.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine hearing test. During the test, otoacoustic emissions are detected. Which of the following best describes otoacoustic emissions?

choices.text: Sounds generated by the inner ear in response to external sounds
Sounds generated by the middle ear in response to external sounds
Sounds generated by the brain in response to external sounds
Sounds generated by the outer ear in response to external sounds

questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Sounds generated by the inner ear in response to external sounds is the correct answer. Otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are sounding the cochlea generates in response to external sounds. When the hair cells in the cochlea are stimulated by sound waves, they produce vibrations that generate OAEs. OAEs can be detected using a specialized microphone placed in the ear canal.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Sounds generated by the middle ear in response to external sounds is incorrect. The middle ear is responsible for transmitting sound waves from the outer ear to the inner ear, but it does not produce sounds in response to external sounds.

Option C.  Sounds generated by the brain in response to external sounds is incorrect. While the brain is responsible for processing and interpreting auditory signals, it does not generate sounds in response to external sounds.

Option D. Sounds generated by the outer ear in response to external sounds is not correct. The outer ear collects sound waves and directs them to the middle ear, but it does not produce sounds in response to external sounds.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of nasal obstruction and anosmia. On examination, he is found to have bilateral nasal polyps. A CT scan of the paranasal sinuses shows extensive involvement of the sinuses with polyps. Which of the following is the best treatment strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
Endoscopic sinus surgery is a treatment option for patients with extensive involvement of the sinuses with polyps or those who do not respond to medical management. The surgery involves removing the polyps and opening the sinuses to improve drainage. This option may be the most appropriate for this patient.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Intranasal corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for mild to moderate nasal polyps. They reduce inflammation and shrink the polyps, improving nasal obstruction and anosmia. However, in this scenario, the patient has extensive involvement of the sinuses with polyps, which may not respond to intranasal corticosteroids alone. Therefore, this option may not be the most appropriate for this patient.

Option C. Oral corticosteroids are reserved for patients with severe nasal polyps or those who do not respond to other treatments. They can reduce inflammation and shrink polyps but have significant side effects and should be used cautiously. This option may be considered if the patient does not respond to other treatments.

Option D. Observation and follow-up may be appropriate for patients with mild nasal polyps or those who do not have significant symptoms. However, in this scenario, the patient has extensive involvement of the sinuses with polyps, which may require intervention.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the clinic with complaints of facial pain, pressure, and congestion for the past week. The patient has a history of allergies and has been using over-the-counter antihistamines without relief. On examination, there is tenderness over the maxillary sinuses. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Order a CT scan of the sinuses

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Saline nasal irrigation is a simple and effective way to manage sinusitis symptoms, as it can help clear mucus and reduce inflammation. It is also a good option for patients who may not want to take medications or are looking for a non-pharmacologic approach. In this scenario, recommending saline nasal irrigation would be a good next step in management.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Antibiotics are not always necessary for treating sinusitis and are typically only prescribed in cases of bacterial sinusitis. In this scenario, the patient's symptoms have only been present for a week, and there is no clear indication of bacterial sinusitis. Therefore, prescribing antibiotics would not be the next best step in management.

Option B. Nasal corticosteroids are a common treatment for sinusitis, as they can reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms such as congestion and facial pain. However, in this scenario, the patient has already been using over-the-counter antihistamines without relief, and there is tenderness over the maxillary sinuses, suggesting a more severe sinusitis. Therefore, prescribing a nasal corticosteroid may not be enough to manage the patient's symptoms.

Option D. CT scans can be helpful in diagnosing sinusitis and determining the severity of the condition. However, they are not typically ordered as a first-line diagnostic test, as they are expensive and expose patients to radiation. In this scenario, there is already a strong suspicion of sinusitis based on the patient's symptoms and physical examination findings. A CT scan may not be necessary at this time.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is scheduled for elective knee replacement surgery. Her comorbidities include Rheumatoid arthritis, depression, and dyslipidaemia. Which of the following medications should not be had on the day of the surgery and should be discontinued more than 48 hours before?
questions.solution:
• NSAIDs should be withdrawn 24-72 hours before the operation. This is because NSAIDs have reversible antiplatelet effects. Hence, it should be stopped before the surgery so that platelet functions can return to normal. However, COX-2 inhibitors, like celecoxib, have minimal effect on platelet function and may be harmless if continued before surgery.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Oral and inhaled corticosteroids should be continued on the day of the surgery.

Option C: Sudden discontinuation of SSRI may cause dizziness, chills, muscle pain, and anxiety during and after the surgery. Even though SSRIs may be associated with the risk of surgical bleeding, the benefits of continuing the medication outweigh the risk.

Option D: Statins should be continued on the day of the surgery.

questions.text: A 9-month-old child presented to the ER with symptoms of bronchiolitis. On examination, an expiratory stridor and prolonged expiration are found. The decision to perform endotracheal intubation was made to prevent airway obstruction. What should be the length of the endotracheal tube chosen?
questions.solution:
• Between the age group of 3 months-1 year, the recommended size of the endotracheal tube has an internal diameter of 3.5-4.0 cuffed, with a length of 11 cm. A child with intrathoracic airway obstruction has expiratory stridor, and one with extrathoracic airway obstruction has inspiratory stridor.
  • A cuffed tube is advised for cases that are more than 3 months. Uncuffed tubes have a higher risk of laryngospasm and airway trauma. A cuffed tube also allows accurate measurement of end-tidal carbon dioxide.
  • Recommended sizes and distance of insertion of endotracheal tubes and laryngoscope blades in children
Age of patient Internal diameter of the endotracheal tube Size of laryngoscope straight blade Distance of insertion (cm)
Preterm 2.5 uncuffed 0 6-7
Full term 3.0-3.5 uncuffed 0-1 8-10
3 months-1 year 3.5-4.0 cuffed 1 11
2 years 4.5-5.0 cuffed 1-1.5 12
6 years 5.0-5.5 cuffed 1.5-2b 15
10 years 6.0-6.5  2-3 17
18 years  7.0-8.0 cuffed 3 19

Incorrect options

  • Option A: A 6 cm long, uncuffed tube is recommended in preterm babies.
  • Option B:  A 15 cm long, cuffed tube is used in 6-year-olds.
  • Option D: A 19 cm long tube is used in approximately 18-year-olds.

questions.text: A 24 year old is scheduled to have a root canal procedure done for his teeth. A gas in a blue cylinder is brought as the mode of anaesthesia. Considering the physiology of the anaesthetic, which of the following decreases after using the anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
• The blue cylinder given in the picture represents nitrous oxide cylinder. Nitrous oxide elimination can cause a rapid decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen. This is known as the Fink’s effect. This effect can be prevented by administrating oxygen continuously for 10 minutes during the recovery period after anaesthesia. 

Incorrect options:

Option A: Cerebral blood flow increase may be due to the sympathoadrenal stimulating effect of N2O. N2O causes vasodilatory effects. This effect is maximum when N2O is administered alone.

Option B: N2O can cause increase in cerebral metabolic rate. This is proven by recent studies that indicate that when 70% N2O is administered with sevoflurane or propofol, an increase in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen is detected.

Option C: N2O causes increase in intracranial pressure. The most dramatic increase in ICP is when N2O is given alone. N2O rapidly enters closed gas spaces, hence it should be avoided when a closed intracranial gas space may exist or intravascular air is anticipated.

questions.text: A 35 year old has been intubated for an elective surgery. The general anaesthesia was given after proper induction, pre-medication and pre-oxygenation. However, the capnography shows the following pattern. What could be the reason for this pattern?
questions.solution:
The figure represents a faulty inspiratory valve pattern in capnography. Here, the baseline is elevated with an abnormal descending limb of capnogram. This type of ventilation makes the patient rebreathe the exhaled gas.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Spontaneous breath efforts will show clefts in phase III. This may occur when the effect of muscle relaxants wear off.

Option B: If the endotracheal tube is incorrectly places in the oesophagus, only small transient waveforms will be shown in the capnography.

Option C: A faulty expiratory valve will show patterns suggestive of rebreathing of carbon dioxide.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with symptoms of intestinal obstruction. A CT scan was performed, which showed a dilated small bowel with air-fluid levels and a transition point in the distal ileum. A contrast study was performed, which revealed no passage of contrast beyond the transition point. The radiologist then performed a fluoroscopy-guided air-contrast enema and noted no passage of contrast into the colon. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what should be the next step in management?

choices.text: Sigmoid volvulus, immediate surgical intervention is necessary.
Adhesive small bowel obstruction, conservative management is the first step.
Large bowel obstruction, colonoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Small bowel obstruction, exploratory laparotomy is required for definitive diagnosis and management.

questions.solution:
Small bowel obstruction, exploratory laparotomy is required for definitive diagnosis and management. The CT scan and contrast study findings suggest a distal ileal obstruction, and the lack of passage of contrast on the air-contrast enema confirms a small bowel obstruction. 

Exploratory laparotomy is necessary for definitive diagnosis and management. Conservative management may be attempted in selected cases of adhesive small bowel obstruction, but the findings in this case indicate the need for surgical intervention. Sigmoid volvulus typically presents with colonic dilation and a "coffee-bean" sign on abdominal radiographs. Large bowel obstruction may also present with colonic dilation and a transition point, but the lack of passage of contrast on the air-contrast enema rules out this diagnosis. Colonoscopy is not indicated in this case as it may cause perforation in the setting of a complete obstruction.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Sigmoid volvulus is a type of colonic obstruction that occurs when the sigmoid colon twists around itself. It is more common in elderly patients and those with a history of chronic constipation or megacolon. Abdominal radiographs typically show colonic dilation and a "coffee-bean" sign. While sigmoid volvulus can cause small bowel dilation and air-fluid levels on CT scan, the lack of passage of contrast on the air-contrast enema makes this diagnosis less likely. Immediate surgical intervention may be necessary if the patient has evidence of bowel ischemia or perforation.

Option B) Adhesive small bowel obstruction is a common cause of intestinal obstruction that can occur after abdominal surgery or inflammation. It is caused by bands of scar tissue that form between the small bowel loops, leading to obstruction. CT scans typically show dilated small bowel loops with air-fluid levels, and contrast studies may reveal a transition point with no passage of contrast beyond. Conservative management may be attempted with bowel rest, nasogastric suction, and intravenous fluids in selected cases, but surgery may be necessary if the obstruction persists or there is evidence of bowel ischemia or perforation.

Option C) Large bowel obstruction can be caused by various factors, such as tumors, diverticulitis, or volvulus. Abdominal radiographs may show colonic dilation, and CT scans can help identify the underlying cause. However, the lack of passage of contrast on the air-contrast enema makes this diagnosis less likely. Colonoscopy is not indicated in this case as it may cause perforation in the setting of a complete obstruction. If the obstruction is caused by a malignant tumor, surgical intervention may be necessary.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man came to ER with a loss of consciousness. The patient's relative gave a history of RTA. The patient is a known alcoholic and hypertensive. NCCT head was normal. GCS is 8. An urgent MRI is performed. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Diffuse axonal injury

  • MRI image [SWI SEQEUNCE] shows multiple blooming foci noted diffusely involving the bilateral cerebral hemisphere predominantly at the grey-white matter junction.
  • Diffuse axonal injury is the shearing (tearing) of the brain's long connecting nerve fibers (axons) that happens when the brain is injured as it shifts and rotates inside the bony skull.
  • DAI usually causes coma and injury to many different parts of the brain.
  • The changes in the brain are often microscopic and may not be evident in computed tomography (CT scan) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans.

Option A: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy

  • Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is characterized by amyloid beta-peptide deposits within small- to medium-sized blood vessels of the brain and leptomeninges.
  • CAA is an important cause of lobar intracerebral hemorrhage in older adults.
  • In addition to intracerebral hemorrhage, CAA may present with transient neurological symptoms, an inflammatory leukoencephalopathy, as a contributor to cognitive impairment, or with incidental microbleeds or hemosiderosis on magnetic resonance imaging.

Option B: SAH

  • A subarachnoid hemorrhage means that there is bleeding in the space that surrounds the brain.
  • Most often, it occurs when a weak area in a blood vessel (aneurysm) on the surface of the brain bursts and leaks.
  • The blood then builds up around the brain and inside the skull, increasing pressure on the brain.
  • This can cause brain cell damage, life-long complications, and disabilities.

Option D: SDH

  • A subdural hematoma (SDH) is a type of bleeding in which a collection of blood—usually but not always associated with a traumatic brain injury—gathers between the inner layer of the dura mater and the arachnoid mater of the meninges surrounding the brain.
  • It usually results from tears in bridging veins that cross the subdural space.
  • Subdural hematomas may cause an increase in the pressure inside the skull, which in turn can cause compression of and damage to delicate brain tissue.
  • Acute subdural hematomas are often life-threatening. Chronic subdural hematomas have a better prognosis if properly managed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of chronic low back pain presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe back pain after lifting a heavy object. X ray image is given below. The patient was also found to have elevated inflammatory markers. What is the abnormality, and what should be the next step in management?

choices.text: The abnormality is a lytic lesion in the sacrum, and the next step in management is to obtain a CT-guided biopsy of the lesion.
The abnormality is a compression fracture of the L2 vertebral body, and the next step in management is to obtain an MRI of the entire spine.
The abnormality is a vertebral body hemangioma, and the next step in management is to obtain an MRI of the entire spine.
The abnormality is a paraspinal soft tissue mass, and the next step in management is to obtain a CT scan of the chest and abdomen.

questions.solution:
The abnormality on the radiograph is a compression fracture of the L2 vertebral body, which is a common complication of ankylosing spondylitis. The next step in management should be to obtain an MRI of the entire spine to evaluate for additional fractures and other complications of ankylosing spondylitis, such as spinal stenosis or spinal cord compression. Treatment options may include immobilization, pain management, and physical therapy to prevent further complications.

Incorrect options:

Option A) A lytic lesion in the sacrum is not a common finding in ankylosing spondylitis and should raise suspicion for other conditions such as metastatic cancer or osteomyelitis. A CT-guided biopsy may be necessary to further evaluate the lesion.

Option C) A vertebral body hemangioma is a benign lesion that is typically incidental and unrelated to ankylosing spondylitis. MRI may be necessary to evaluate the extent of the hemangioma, but it is not related to the patient's current symptoms.

Option D) A paraspinal soft tissue mass is also an unusual finding in ankylosing spondylitis and should raise suspicion for other conditions such as infection or tumor. A CT scan of the chest and abdomen may be necessary to further evaluate the mass.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents to the emergency department with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. On physical examination, the patient appears to be in respiratory distress with decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. A chest x-ray reveals a possible pneumothorax, but it is difficult to confirm due to the presence of bullae. Which of the following imaging modalities is the most appropriate to confirm the diagnosis of pneumothorax in this patient?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the chest

questions.solution:
Ultrasound is the most appropriate imaging modality for confirming the diagnosis of pneumothorax in this patient. Ultrasound is highly sensitive and specific for detecting pneumothorax and is non-invasive, readily available, and easy to perform at the bedside.

Incorrect options:

Option A) Computed tomography (CT) is an excellent imaging modality for diagnosing pneumothorax. However, it is not the best option in this case because it is more invasive than other modalities and requires the patient to be transported to a separate imaging department.

Option B) Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is not commonly used for diagnosing pneumothorax, as it is not sensitive to the presence of air within the pleural space.

Option D) Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan is not appropriate for diagnosing pneumothorax, as it is used primarily to diagnose pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presented with a low-energy Colle’s fracture of the radius. A DXA scan was done, which showed reduced bone density in the vertebral bodies and neck of the femur. Which of the following conditions is not a secondary cause of this disease?
questions.solution:
The DXA scan in the above question shows reduced bone density and suggests osteoporosis. Also, considering the patient’s age, primary osteoporosis is unlikely. The diagnosis of the given question is secondary osteoporosis. Amongst the given choices, ionizing radiation leads to bone death and is a cause of the osteonecrosis of the bone, not osteoporosis. Radiation is not known to be a secondary cause of osteoporosis.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Glucocorticoid overload or prolonged use of corticosteroids can lead to secondary osteoporosis. Glucocorticoids suppress osteoblast function, cause reduced calcium absorption, increase calcium excretion, and stimulate PTH secretion.

Option B. Thyroid hormone increases the rate of bone turnover, with resorption exceeding formation.

Option C. Increases in chronic alcohol intake can cause osteoporosis in all ages. It also increases the chances of falls. Osteoporosis may be due to decreased calcium absorption, liver failure, and toxic effect on osteoblast function. Alcohol also has a mild glucocorticoid effect.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, who had just given birth 6 weeks ago, presented to the OPD with complaints of pain and paraesthesia in the lateral side of the palmar aspect of the right hand, usually worse at night. These symptoms are sometimes relieved by hanging the arm over the side of the bed. Which nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Option B) is correct.

From the history given in the question, the distal median nerve in the carpal tunnel is most likely to be affected. The likelihood of Carpal tunnel syndrome increases at menopause, in pregnancy, with rheumatoid arthritis and myxoedema. Pain and paraesthesia increase in the distribution of the median nerve in hand, worse in the middle of the night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed or shaking the arm is known to relieve the symptoms.

 

Incorrect choices:

Option A) The anterior interosseus nerve can be rarely compressed by the ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or arch-like origins of either pronator teres or flexor digitorum superficialis. Parsonage-turner syndrome may also cause anterior interosseous nerve syndrome. A patient will have weakness of flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus and will be unable to make the ‘OK’ sign.

Option C) The proximal median nerve is also compressed by the ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or arch-like origins of either pronator teres or flexor digitorum superficialis. Although symptoms are similar to carpal tunnel syndrome, night pain is unusual. The pain associated with the proximal median nerve is usually felt in the forearm.

Option D) The ulnar nerve supplies the medial aspect of the palmar aspect of the hand. It can be compressed within the cubital tunnel. The patient will complain of numbness and tingling in the little and ulnar half of the ring finger.

questions.text: A 35-year-old electrician complains of pain and tenderness over the lateral epicondyle of the elbow. Pain develops gradually and is aggravated by movements like pouring tea and shaking hands. In this condition, the bony insertion of which of the following structures is affected?

choices.text: Insertion of biceps into the bicipital tuberosity of radius

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Pain and tenderness at the lateral epicondyle of the elbow are suggestive of Tennis Elbow/Lateral epicondylitis. It occurs not only in tennis players but also in professions with repetitive movements, such as electricians, carpenters, gardeners, desk-bound jobs, swimming, and baseball. In this condition, the extensor carpi radialis tendon at the insertion of the lateral epicondyle is affected. The test given below will aggravate the symptom and may be used for screening.

Incorrect choices:

Option A) The medial collateral ligament of the elbow is ligament affected in a syndrome known as javelin thrower’s elbow. The over-arm action used by javelin throwers may avulse the tendon at the olecranon. There may also be symptoms of ulnar nerve impairment.

Option B) The pronator origin is affected in the golfer’s elbow/ medial epicondylitis. There may also be ulnar nerve impairment. Golfer’s elbow is a condition that is characterized by pain around the forearm muscle tendons attached to the bony bump on the inside of an elbow.

Option D) Avulsion at the insertion of the biceps into the bicipital tuberosity of radius causes sudden pain and weakness in front of the elbow after vigorous effort.

questions.text: A 10-year-old presented with complaints of severe pain in her knee, associated with fever >100 degree Celsius and malaise. There is tenderness on the knee, and joint movement is restricted due to the pain. An X-ray taken was normal. Treatment was started based on symptoms. However, an X-ray taken 14 days later is given below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
The patient has acute osteomyelitis. Symptoms are severe pain associated with high-grade fever. The restriction of movement is due to severe pain and is known as ‘pseudo paralysis.’ Local redness, swelling, warmth, and oedema are present later when the pus escapes to the exterior of the bone. The first X-ray will almost always be normal. The follow-up X-ray after a week may show an extra-cortical outline due to periosteal new bone formation. In later X-rays, periosteal thickening becomes more obvious.

Incorrect choices:

Option A) It is an infection of a large joint. Symptoms may be similar to osteomyelitis, with acute pain in a single large joint and high-grade fever. An X-ray will show soft tissue swelling, widening of joint space, and slight subluxation of the joint. Late X-rays will have narrowing and irregularity of joint space.

 

Option B) Symptoms will usually be pain, joint swelling, low-grade fever, night sweats, and loss of weight. An X-ray will show soft tissue swelling and peri-articular osteoporosis. There will be erosion on the subarticular bone of both sides of the joint.

Option D) Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is a non-infective joint disease affecting children ages <16 years. Symptoms may be intermittent fever and rashes, with joint swelling occurring weeks or months after onset.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida who just delivered her baby at 37 weeks of gestation by normal vaginal delivery. The baby was vigorous, and after the pediatrician was done with the routine care of the baby, he was handed over to the mother for breastfeeding. The nurse there noticed the mother and how she had used a good method of breastfeeding. The given picture indicates which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: Good attachment

  • Baby’s mouth is wide open with almost the entire areola in his mouth with the everted lower lip, indicating ‘good attachment’ while breastfeeding.
  • Signs of good attachment of a baby to the breast:
    • Baby's mouth is wide open.
    • Entire areola in the baby’s mouth, except a small part of the upper areola, which may be visible.
    • Baby's lower lip everted.
