    • Baby's chin touching the breast.
    • Signs of good positioning while breastfeeding:
    • The body of the baby should be well supported.
    • The occiput, shoulder and buttocks should be in a straight line.
    • The baby should be turned towards the mother.
    • The abdomen of baby should touch the abdomen of the mother.
  • Rooting reflex: During this reflex, not all the signs of good attachment will be present. It will merely present as an opening of the mouth in search of the nipple. In contrast, the above image shows all signs of good attachment.

Option A: Good positioning

  • Good positioning can be done before the rooting reflex.
  • For good positioning;
    • Lie the baby across your lap, facing you.
    • Place the baby’s head on your forearm.
    • Place the baby’s lower arm under yours.

Option B: Rooting reflex

  • The rooting reflex is when the baby opens her mouth and searches for the nipple touching the cheeks.
  • This reflex helps the baby to find the nipple and in proper attachment to the breast.

Option D: Weaning

  • Weaning is the term used when a baby starts to eat food except for milk.
  • Mostly the weaning starts after 6 months of age.

questions.text: A neonate is admitted to NICU after 16 hours of birth with the complaint of yellow skin. Neonate’s palms and soles are yellow. The baby weighs 3.3 kg at birth. Total serum bilirubin test results show a 19.1 mg/dl bilirubin level. Clinical examination and lab results are suggestive of pathological jaundice. Phototherapy is prescribed. Which mechanism in phototherapy is chiefly responsible for the reduction in serum bilirubin?
questions.solution:
Option B: Photo-isomerisation

  • Phototherapy involves exposing the neonate's skin to blue or white fluorescent light. This light is absorbed by the bilirubin in the skin, leading to a structural change in bilirubin molecules. This structural change, called photo-isomerization, converts the bilirubin into a form that is more easily excreted by the liver, making it water-soluble. The isomerized bilirubin can then be eliminated from the body through urine and feces. So, photo-isomerization is the primary mechanism responsible for reducing serum bilirubin levels in neonates with jaundice.

Option A: Photo-oxidation

  • It is the least important mechanism where photo products are excreted in the urine. 
  • This reaction is slow and occurs in small quantities, with dosages in the urine of between 2-9 mg/l.27 

Option C: Structural isomerisation

  • This term is closely related to photo-isomerization and is not a separate mechanism. It refers to the change in the bilirubin molecule's structure caused by phototherapy.

Option D: Conjugation 

  • It is a physiological process that occurs in the liver and converts unconjugated bilirubin into conjugated bilirubin by the enzyme uridine diphosphate glucuronyl transferase (UDP-GT.) 
  • Jaundice can be of both types, with the bilirubin either unconjugated or conjugated

questions.text: At what age will  a child achieve the milestone shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option C: 15 months

  • This is a case of a well-child examination in which a 12-month-old child is brought to the physician by his mother for examination.

  • The child is able to crawl easily and is also able to walk with support.

  • He is also able to copy horizontal and vertical lines. The child doesn’t have any abnormalities.

  • He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities.

  • The given picture shows a child creeping upstairs, that comes at around 15 months of age.

  • So, the child, in this case, still has 3 more months to achieve the milestone shown in the image.

  • Another important milestone that appears at around 15 months of age is Jargon speech.

Option A: 6 months

  • At the age of 6 months, the baby starts to roll from tummy to back.

  • Also, pushes up with straight arms when on the tummy

  • Leans on their hands to support him while sitting.

Option B:  12 months

  • At the age of 12 months, the baby can walk, holding onto objects.

  • Walks like a bear.

  • Picks up a pellet with finger and thumb

Option D: 24 months

  • At the age of 24 months, the child is able to make a tower of 6 cubes, turn the doorknob, and use pronouns like I, me, and you.

  • A child can make a tower of 6 cubes in 2 years.

  • Baby can hold a pencil in mid-shaft with a tripod grasp.

  •  Can sit on a small chair.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl went to the pediatric clinic with concerns about her height. Her parents report that she has always been shorter than her peers and is now being teased at school. On examination, the girl is found to be at the 3rd percentile for height and weight. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her short stature?
questions.solution:
• Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects only girls and is caused by the absence or partial absence of one of the X chromosomes. Girls with Turner syndrome typically have short stature, webbed neck, and gonadal dysgenesis. 
  • Other features may include cardiac defects, hearing loss, and learning disabilities. This option is the most likely cause of short stature in this girl based on her age, gender, and physical examination findings.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Constitutional growth delay is a common cause of short stature in children but is usually not detected until adolescence. Children with constitutional growth delay typically have a delayed growth spurt and eventually reach their target height later than their peers. This option is, therefore, not the most likely cause of short stature in this 10-year-old girl.

Option B: Hypothyroidism can cause growth retardation but is usually associated with other signs and symptoms such as fatigue, constipation, and dry skin. A simple thyroid function test can easily rule out hypothyroidism as the cause of short stature in this girl.

Option D: Growth hormone deficiency is a rare cause of short stature and is usually associated with other signs and symptoms, such as delayed puberty and decreased muscle mass. A growth hormone stimulation test can be done to confirm the diagnosis, but it is not the most likely cause of short stature in this girl.

questions.text: A newborn infant is found to be cyanotic and has respiratory distress. On physical examination, there is a continuous murmur heard over the precordium. Chest X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of a newborn with cyanosis, respiratory distress, and a continuous murmur over the precordium suggests a congenital heart defect. The "snowman" appearance on chest X-ray is a characteristic finding in Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection (TAPVC).
  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) is a congenital heart defect in which all four pulmonary veins fail to connect to the left atrium and instead connect to the right atrium or its tributaries. This results in cyanosis and respiratory distress, and a continuous murmur over the precordium can often be heard. The characteristic "snowman" appearance on chest X-ray is due to the enlarged right atrium and left atrium connected by a vertical vein.

Incorrect Choices:

  • Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart disease characterised by four anatomical abnormalities, including ventricular septal defect (VSD), overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis, and right ventricular hypertrophy. The clinical presentation typically includes cyanosis and dyspnea, but a continuous murmur over the precordium is not a characteristic finding.
  • Option B. Transposition of the great arteries refers to a congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary artery and aorta are switched. The clinical presentation includes cyanosis and respiratory distress, but a continuous murmur over the precordium is not a characteristic finding.
  • Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a congenital heart defect in which the ductus arteriosus fails to close after birth. The clinical presentation may include a continuous murmur, but the characteristic "snowman" appearance on chest X-ray is not seen in PDA.

questions.text: A newborn infant is born at 38 weeks with respiratory distress. The intrapartum course is notable for spontaneous labor, concerns for chorioamnionitis, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, and cesarean delivery for failure to progress. The infant emerged vigorous but has ongoing work of breathing and desaturations, requiring oxygen and CPAP in the delivery room. Which element is included in the score used to assess the distress mentioned above for this neonate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Grunt

 

The Silverman-Anderson Index, also known as the Respiratory Distress Assessment Instrument, is used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in newborn infants. It includes five clinical criteria:

  1. Retractions: Examines the extent of chest wall retractions during inspiration.
  2. Expiratory grunt: Assesses the presence and intensity of an expiratory grunt.
  3. Nasal flaring: Evaluates the degree of nasal flaring during breathing.
  4. Grunting: Considers the presence and frequency of grunting.
  5. Chest movement: Observes chest movement during respiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Heart rate

Option C: Peripheral cyanosis

Option D: Wheeze

The following options does not fall in the Silverman-Anderson Index

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the primary health center by his mother with a complaint that he appears 'swollen' and is highly irritable. On examination, the positive findings are a weight of 11kg, reddish-colored hair, generalized edema, moon facies, abdominal distension, hepatomegaly, and dark, dry skin. The rest of the systemic examination is normal. What complications will develop in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypoglycemia

  • As evident, the patient suffers from severe acute malnutrition. His examination findings of hepatomegaly, moon face, oedema and abdominal distention suggest Kwashiorkor.
  • In severe acute malnutrition, hepatic gluconeogenesis is reduced and energy production from substrates like galactose and fructose is impaired. This increases the risk of hypoglycemia.
  • Intestinal absorption of nutrients and glucose is also markedly reduced in children with or without edematous malnutrition.
  • Blood glucose clearance is reduced along with insulin levels, but these changes do not increase blood glucose levels.
  • Hypoglycemia increases both morbidity and mortality in these patients.

Option B: Hyperthermia

  • The basal metabolic rate in severe acute malnutrition is reduced to 30%.
  • Both generation and heat loss is impaired; thus, the child has hypothermia.

Option C: Neurogenic shock

  • Immune dysfunction and infections are among the most common complications in severely malnourished children.
  • There is an alteration in gut barrier function and mucosal immune function and reduced production of pro-inflammatory cytokines.
  • Lymph nodes, tonsils and thymus are atrophic and they are at increased risk of developing septic shock.

Option D: Hypernatremia

  • Sodium pump activity is reduced at the cellular level.
  • There is increased cellular membrane permeability which results in an increase in intracellular sodium and a decrease in potassium and magnesium.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to the emergency department by his mother due to loose stools for 2 days. The patient passes 6-7 watery stools per day. It is not associated with a fever or vomiting. His mother reports that the child is irritable and only drinks water when given. Physical examination reveals sunken eyes and slow retraction of the skin. Which of the following is the appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre
Start IV fluids and IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.solution:
Option D: ORS with zinc for 14 days

  No Dehydration Some/Mild Dehydration Severe/Serious Dehydration
Consciousness Alert Irritable Lethargic
Eyes Normal Sunken Very sunken
Thirst Normal Drinks eagerly Unable to drink
Buccal mucosa Normal Dry Very dry
Skin pinch Goes back quickly Slowly Very slowly
Tears Present Absent Absent
Treatment Plan A Plan B Plan C
  • The patient presents with irritability, drinking water eagerly, sunken eyes, and slow retraction of skin, suggesting mild (some) dehydration due to diarrhoea.
  • Treatment for some dehydration includes Plan B:
    • Oral fluid resuscitation
    • Zinc for 14 days
  • The daily fluid requirement is calculated as follows:
    • Up to 10 kg = 100 ml/kg
    • 10-20 kg = 50 ml/kg
    • >20 kg = 20 ml/kg
  • Deficit replacement or rehydration therapy calculated as 75 mL/kg of ORS is to be given over 4 hours.
  • Maintenance fluid therapy to replace losses: This phase begins when signs of dehydration disappear. ORS is administered in volumes equal to diarrheal losses, usually to a maximum of 10 ml/kg per stool.

Option A: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre.

  • Urgent referral to the higher centre is made in case of severe dehydration.
  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • The absence of fever or blood in stools makes the bacterial cause less likely.

​​​​​​​Option B:  Give oral antibiotics and ORS.

  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • The absence of fever or blood in stools makes the bacterial cause less likely.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option C: Start IV fluids and IV antibiotics, and refer to higher centre

  • ​​​​​​​Urgent referral to the higher centre is made in case of severe dehydration.
  • Antibiotics are given if the diarrhoea is due to bacterial causes.
  • IV fluids are given in severe dehydration (PLAN C)​​​​​​​​​​​​​​

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant presents with projectile non-bilious vomiting and a palpable olive-shaped mass in the epigastric region. An ultrasound confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). The infant undergoes surgery, and the surgeon is about to make the incision when they realize that an unusually large and prominent duodenal bulb is present. How should the surgeon proceed with the operation to avoid any complications?

choices.text: Abandon the procedure and reschedule the surgery for another day to allow for further investigation.
Make the incision but do not attempt pyloromyotomy until the duodenal bulb can be safely repositioned
Continue with the procedure and attempt to perform pyloromyotomy while being mindful of the presence of the large duodenal bulb.
Convert to an open procedure and resect the entire pyloric region to avoid potential complications.

questions.solution:
• Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) is a common condition in infants characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. Pyloromyotomy, a surgical procedure that involves the division of the hypertrophied pylorus muscle, is the treatment of choice for this condition.
  •  In some cases, however, other anatomical abnormalities may present, such as a large duodenal bulb, which can complicate the procedure. In such situations, the surgeon must be aware of the potential complications and take appropriate measures to avoid them.

 Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Postponing the surgery may delay treatment, which can lead to complications such as dehydration and electrolyte imbalance.

Option B:  Attempting pyloromyotomy while the duodenal bulb is still unfavorable can lead to complications such as injury to the duodenum.

Option D: Resecting the entire pyloric region is unnecessary and can result in long-term complications such as gastric dysmotility and increased risk of gastric cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of liver cirrhosis presents with acute hematemesis. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 beats/min. His laboratory investigations show a hemoglobin level of 8 g/dL and a platelet count of 60,000/mm3. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals the presence of large, grade III esophageal varices with no active bleeding. What would be the best course for treating this case going forward?

choices.text: Administer a bolus of intravenous vasopressin
Transfuse packed red blood cells to maintain hemoglobin level >10 g/dL
Place an esophageal stent to relieve the obstruction

questions.solution:
• The patient presents with acute hematemesis and has a history of liver cirrhosis, a common cause of esophageal varices. On examination, he has signs of hypotension and tachycardia, indicating that he is in hypovolemic shock due to blood loss. The laboratory investigations also show a low hemoglobin level and platelet count, further confirming the presence of bleeding. The endoscopy reveals large, grade III esophageal varices at a high risk of rupture and bleeding.
  • In this situation, the most appropriate next step would be transfusing packed red blood cells to maintain the hemoglobin level above 10 g/dL, the minimum level required for tissue oxygenation. This will help stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and prevent further bleeding.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: Administering a bolus of intravenous vasopressin (option A) is not recommended in this scenario as it can cause vasoconstriction and reduce blood flow to vital organs, worsening the patient's hemodynamic status.

Option B: Performing emergent endoscopic sclerotherapy (option B) may be considered if active bleeding is present, but the varices are not actively bleeding in this case.

Option D: Placing an esophageal stent (option D) is not a recommended treatment for esophageal varices as it can cause further bleeding and is associated with a high rate of complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with a facial droop on the right side of the face. On examination, she has the inability to close her right eye and drooping of the right side of her mouth. The rest of the neurological examination is normal. A diagnosis of Bell's palsy is suspected, and the patient is started on corticosteroids. However, after three weeks of treatment, there is no improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following surgical options is most likely to improve the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Microvascular decompression of the facial nerve.
Selective neurectomy of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve.
Transposition of the temporalis muscle to the upper lip.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Cross-facial nerve grafting: This surgical technique involves taking a nerve from the healthy side of the face and grafting it onto the affected side. This allows the nerve fibers to grow into the paralyzed muscles and restore function. This technique is appropriate for the patient described in the question, as the aberrant nerve fibers can be bypassed using a cross-facial nerve graft. Therefore, this option is correct.

Incorrect option:

Option A: Microvascular decompression of the facial nerve: This surgical technique involves placing a cushioning material between the facial nerve and a nearby blood vessel to prevent compression of the nerve. While this technique is used to treat hemifacial spasms or trigeminal neuralgia, it is not appropriate for the patient described in the question with an aberrant course of the facial nerve. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Selective neurectomy of the zygomatic branch of the facial nerve: This surgical procedure involves cutting the nerve fibers that supply the zygomatic muscles, which are responsible for elevating the corner of the mouth when smiling. While this procedure is used to treat synkinesis, it is not appropriate for the patient described in the question, as the aberrant nerve fibers supply the forehead and eyelid muscles, not the zygomatic muscles. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Transposition of the temporalis muscle to the upper lip: This surgical procedure involves taking a small piece of the temporalis muscle (which is responsible for chewing) and attaching it to the upper lip to provide additional support. While this procedure is used to improve the smile in patients with facial paralysis, it is not appropriate for the patient described in the question, as her facial paralysis is not related to the upper lip. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is responsible for developing peritonitis in an adult with ascites?
questions.solution:
Option C: Group A Streptococci

  • The development of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in the settings of nephrotic syndrome in children is quite common.
    • The presence of ascites provides a natural culture medium for bacterial growth.
    • Using steroids for nephrotic syndrome suppresses the immune system, increasing the risk of catching an infection.
    • Children with nephrotic syndrome lose opsonizing factors in increased amounts, thus increasing their susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections.
    • Reduced serum concentrations of IgG and impaired ability to make specific antibodies contribute to an increased risk of bacterial infections in children with nephrotic syndrome.
    • Group A streptococci are the most common causative microorganisms for primary bacterial peritonitis in children with nephrotic syndrome.

Option A: Escherichia Coli

  • Escherichia coli is the commonest causative pathogen of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in adults, not children.

Option B: Klebsiella pneumoniae

  • Klebsiella pneumoniae is the second most common causative pathogen for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in adults, not children. 

Option D: Bacteroides Fragilis

  • It is very unlikely for Bacteroides fragilis to cause spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in children with nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with septic shock due to a urinary tract infection. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On examination, his mental status is altered, and he has a temperature of 39°C. Calculate the qSOFA and Modified Shock Index (MSI) scores for this patient and interpret the results.

choices.text: qSOFA: 1, MSI: 0.78, suggestive of sepsis-induced hypotension
qSOFA: 2, MSI: 1.05, suggestive of septic shock
qSOFA: 3, MSI: 0.78, suggestive of sepsis-induced hypotension
qSOFA: 2, MSI: 0.5, suggestive of septic shock

questions.solution:
Calculation of the qSOFA and MSI scores for this patient:

  • qSOFA: The patient meets two out of three criteria, including altered mental status and hypotension (systolic blood pressure of 80 mmHg), but the respiratory rate is only 25 breaths per minute, which is less than the cutoff value of 22. Therefore, the qSOFA score is 1.
  • MSI: The patient's heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and the systolic blood pressure is 80 mmHg. The MSI score is calculated by dividing the heart rate by the systolic blood pressure, which gives the value 1.38. However, the modified shock index is a ratio of heart rate to systolic blood pressure, so the correct calculation is 110/80 = 1.375 or 1.05 rounded to two decimal places.
  • Therefore, the correct answer is B) qSOFA: 2, MSI: 1.05, suggestive of septic shock. The patient meets two criteria for qSOFA, including altered mental status and hypotension, indicating a higher risk of mortality in patients with suspected infections outside the ICU. The MSI score is >1, indicating an increased risk of mortality in septic patients. Septic shock is defined as sepsis-induced hypotension persisting despite adequate fluid resuscitation, requiring vasopressors to maintain blood pressure. This patient meets the criteria for septic shock and requires urgent management in the ICU.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: qSOFA: 1, MSI: 0.78, suggestive of sepsis-induced hypotension is incorrect because the MSI score is suggestive of septic shock, but the qSOFA score is only 1, which is not enough to meet the criteria for sepsis.

Option C: qSOFA: 3, MSI: 0.78, suggestive of sepsis-induced hypotension is incorrect because the qSOFA score is 3, which is not possible because the maximum score is 2.

Option D: qSOFA: 2, MSI: 0.5, suggestive of septic shock is incorrect because the MSI score is suggestive of sepsis, but the qSOFA score is 2, which meets the criteria for sepsis-induced hypotension but not septic shock.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypotension. On examination, his respiratory rate is 40 breaths per minute, heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. Breath sounds are absent on the right side of the chest, and tracheal deviation is noted towards the left side. A chest X-ray reveals a large right-sided pneumothorax with a mediastinal shift. An intercostal drain (ICD) is inserted immediately, and the patient's condition stabilizes. However, after a few minutes, the patient's respiratory distress worsens, and his blood pressure drops to 70/30 mmHg. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Repeat chest X-ray to confirm proper placement of the ICD
Administer high-flow oxygen and observe the patient for improvement
Perform a thoracotomy to explore the chest and remove any additional air
Increase the suction on the ICD to remove more air from the pleural space

questions.solution:
• Performing a thoracotomy to explore the chest and remove any additional air is the most appropriate next step in managing the patient. Despite the insertion of an intercostal drain, the patient's respiratory distress has worsened, and his blood pressure has dropped. These signs suggest the possibility of a tension pneumothorax, which occurs when air continues to accumulate in the pleural space despite the presence of an intercostal drain. In such cases, the patient may require immediate intervention, such as a thoracotomy, to relieve the pressure and prevent further deterioration of their condition.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: Repeat chest X-ray to confirm proper placement of the ICD: While it is important to confirm proper placement of the intercostal drain, it is not the most appropriate next step in managing the patient, as the worsening respiratory distress and hypotension suggest the possibility of a tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

Option B: Administer high-flow oxygen and observe the patient for improvement: Administering high-flow oxygen and observing the patient for improvement may be helpful, but it is not the most appropriate next step in managing the patient, as the worsening respiratory distress and hypotension suggest the possibility of a tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

Option D: Increase the suction on the ICD to remove more air from the pleural space: While increasing the suction on the intercostal drain may help remove more air from the pleural space, it is not the most appropriate next step in managing the patient, as the worsening respiratory distress and hypotension suggest the possibility of a tension pneumothorax, which requires immediate intervention.

questions.text: 35-year-old female with a history of inflammatory breast carcinoma presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and dyspnea. On examination, she has tachycardia and tachypnea, and her oxygen saturation is low. Chest X-ray given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Thoracentesis to drain the pleural effusion
Emergent mastectomy of the affected breast
Diagnostic biopsy of the pleural fluid

questions.solution:
• This patient is presenting with a potential complication of inflammatory breast carcinoma, which is pleural effusion. The pleural effusion is causing respiratory distress and hypoxemia, which requires immediate management. The most appropriate initial management is to perform a thoracentesis to drain the pleural effusion and relieve the symptoms.

Incorrect Choice

Option A: Administration of high-dose steroids (is not the appropriate management for this patient's condition. Although steroids may be used to treat inflammatory breast carcinoma, they are not indicated for the acute management of pleural effusion.

Option B: Emergent mastectomy of the affected breast is not the appropriate management for this patient's condition. A mastectomy is a treatment option for inflammatory breast carcinoma, but it is not indicated in this acute situation.

Option D: Diagnostic biopsy of the pleural fluid may be needed to confirm the diagnosis of pleural effusion and rule out other potential causes. However, it is not the initial management for this patient's acute symptoms.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female patient with Hashimoto's Thyroiditis presents to the emergency room with acute respiratory distress. On examination, the patient has a hoarse voice, stridor, and visible respiratory distress. The patient is immediately intubated, and CT scan shows a large goiter with tracheal compression. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• This scenario presents a medical emergency with acute airway obstruction due to tracheal compression from a large goiter. Immediate intervention is necessary to relieve the obstruction and prevent respiratory arrest. Intubation alone may not be sufficient, and a definitive surgical approach is required.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: A tracheostomy is a temporary measure that may not provide a definitive solution to the underlying problem. It is also associated with risks such as bleeding, infection, and tracheal stenosis.

Option C: High-dose corticosteroid therapy may reduce inflammation and edema but will not provide immediate relief of the tracheal obstruction. This treatment may be used in conjunction with other interventions, such as surgery.

Option D: Endotracheal tube repositioning may be necessary in some cases of intubation-related tracheal obstruction but is not appropriate for patients with a large goiter causing compression.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient is admitted to the emergency department with massive upper gastrointestinal bleeding. His blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, pulse rate is 120 beats per minute, and hemoglobin level is 6.5 g/dL. Endoscopy confirms active bleeding from a large gastric ulcer with an adherent clot. The patient's renal function is impaired, with a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

i) Immediate surgical intervention

ii) Endoscopic hemostasis with epinephrine injection

iii) Transcatheter arterial embolization

iv) Conservative management with blood transfusions and proton pump inhibitors
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • The patient in this scenario is presenting with massive upper gastrointestinal bleeding, hemodynamic instability (blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and pulse rate of 120 beats per minute), and anemia (hemoglobin level of 6.5 g/dL). Endoscopy confirms active bleeding from a large gastric ulcer with an adherent clot. Additionally, the patient has impaired renal function with a serum creatinine level of 2.5 mg/dL. The management strategy for this patient should be aimed at stopping the bleeding and stabilizing the patient's hemodynamic status.
  • Endoscopic hemostasis with epinephrine injection is a well-established and effective treatment for actively bleeding gastric ulcers. The injection constricts blood vessels, reducing blood flow to the site of the bleeding and allowing the clot to form. 

Incorrect choice 

Option A: Only (i) - Immediate surgical intervention may be considered in cases of massive bleeding with hemodynamic instability. However, endoscopic hemostasis with epinephrine injection is the first-line treatment for bleeding from gastric ulcers, and surgery may not be the best option for all patients. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option C: (iii) and (iv) - Transcatheter arterial embolization is a process that is generally used to block the blood supply to a tumor. In cases of GI bleeding, it may be considered in cases where endoscopic intervention is not successful. This technique involves injecting materials into the arteries supplying the bleeding vessel to block blood flow and stop bleeding. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D: Only (iv) - Conservative management with blood transfusions and proton pump inhibitors may be considered in patients who are not suitable candidates for more aggressive interventions or in cases of low-risk bleeding. However, given the severity of this patient's bleeding and his impaired renal function, immediate and effective management is crucial. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 60-year-old obese woman presents to the emergency department with severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, and jaundice. Ultrasound reveals thickened gallbladder wall with pericholecystic fluid and common bile duct (CBD) dilation. MRCP shows a filling defect in the CBD. After resuscitation, what is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Emergent laparoscopic cholecystectomy followed by endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
Emergent open cholecystectomy followed by ERCP
Emergent ERCP followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Emergent ERCP followed by open cholecystectomy

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Acute cholecystitis with choledocholithiasis is a medical emergency that requires urgent management. The initial management should focus on stabilizing the patient's condition and relieving the symptoms of cholecystitis. This includes resuscitation with intravenous fluids, pain control, and antibiotics.
  • The next step is to identify the cause of the choledocholithiasis and manage it appropriately. In this case, the filling defect in the CBD seen on MRCP suggests the presence of a stone. Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is the most appropriate modality to diagnose and treat CBD stones. It involves endoscopic visualization of the biliary tree and extraction of stones using various techniques.
  • Once the CBD stone is removed, laparoscopic cholecystectomy should be performed. It is the definitive treatment for acute cholecystitis and prevents the recurrence of choledocholithiasis.

Incorrect option:

Option A: Emergent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, followed by ERCP, is not the preferred initial approach. This is because the stone in the CBD needs to be addressed first to relieve the obstruction and decrease the risk of complications.

Option B: Emergent open cholecystectomy, followed by ERCP, is also not the preferred initial approach because an open cholecystectomy is associated with higher morbidity and longer hospital stay than laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which is the preferred approach for most cases of acute cholecystitis.

Option D: Emergent ERCP, followed by open cholecystectomy, is not the preferred approach because a laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred approach for most cases of acute cholecystitis due to its less invasive nature and is not followed by open cholecystectomy.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of hematemesis and melena. He has been suffering from abdominal discomfort and vomiting for many months. His blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and his pulse is 60/min. On physical examination, he is pale and thin. There are also swollen lymph nodes in the left supraclavicular region . On further evaluation with endoscopy and imaging modalities, the patient is diagnosed with a case of locally advanced gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is an investigation of choice to know the depth of cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - EUS:

  • EUS (endoscopic ultrasound) is a minimally invasive procedure to assess the digestive tract and nearby organs.
  • It uses a thin, flexible tube inserted into the gastrointestinal tract and a device that uses sound waves to create images.
  • This endoscopic tube also has a small needle to remove fluid or tissue samples for biopsy.
  • The best way to stage the tumour locally is via EUS, which gives fairly accurate (80%) information about the depth of tumour penetration into the gastric wall and can show enlarged (>5mm) perigastric and celiac lymph nodes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CECT:

  • CECT is Contrast-enhanced Computed tomography.
  • It is used for imaging the different structures, and the contrast helps to improve the visualisation.
  • In this procedure, a beam of x-ray moves all around the body and different images are taken to form a dimensional image.
  • During surgeries, it is used to place a needle at a specific point for biopsies or aspiration.
  • It helps to visualise the tumours or other diseases before or after treatment.

Option B - MRI:

  • MRI (magnetic resonance) is an imaging test that uses powerful magnets and radio waves.
  • These waves create images of the inside of the abdomen and do not use radiation.
  • Single MRI images are called slices stored on a computer and viewed on a monitor.
  • MRI is mainly used for brain and spinal cord injuries (stroke, tumour, aneurysms)
  • MRI of the abdomen is mainly used for the following:
    • Blood flow in the abdomen
    • Blood vessels in the abdomen
    • Lymph nodes
    • Masses in the liver, kidney, pancreas, and spleen.

Option C - Barium:

  • Different types of barium x-ray examinations are used to determine different parts.
  • A barium swallow is used to study the pharynx and esophagus.
  • A mixture of barium is swallowed in the supine position, and images are taken.
  • A barium meal is used to study the lower esophagus and stomach.
  • Barium follow-through is used to study the small intestine.
  • A barium enema is used to study the large intestine and rectum.
  • It is used for the following purposes:
    • Diagnosis of tumour
    • Location of tumour
    • Ulceration
    • Strictures

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy who is the second child in his family is brought to the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine with clots and a history of crying at each time of urination. The child's birth and developmental history are uneventful. On examination, the abdomen was soft and not tender, but at the right side of the abdominal wall, a mass is palpated, which is freely movable with smooth edges and did not extend over the midline.  CT scan showed a solid mass with cystic areas in the lower and upper quadrants arising from the right kidney. The hematologic assessment showed moderate microcytic anaemia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Wilms tumor

  • Clinical signs: In the scenario mentioned above, a 4-year-old boy has complained of blood in his urine with clots and a history of crying at each time of urination. Examination revealed a mass with freely movable and smooth edges and a solid mass with cystic areas on a CT scan associated with moderate microcytic anaemia. Young age, associated with a large unilateral mass with anaemia, is the typical presentation of a Wilms tumor.
  • Wilms tumor
  • Wilms Tumor: Most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 Years).
  • Wilms Tumor: 2nd most common malignant abdominal tumor in children (Most common is neuroblastoma).
  • Arise from the kidney, composed of three elements- Blastema, Epithelium & Stroma. (BESt).
  • The most common presenting feature is asymptomatic abdominal mass or swelling.
  • Other symptoms include hypertension, hematuria and weight loss.
  • Treatment involves surgery and chemotherapy.

Option A: Neuroblastoma

  • It is also a tumor presented in childhood.
  • However, it involves multiple sites and times of onset.
  • Presenting complaints include lumps under tissues, back pain, and proptosis.

Option B: Angiomyolipoma

  • It is a benign tumor of muscle or fat.
  • It is usually presented in adults.

Option D: Grawitz tumor

  • These are malignant adenocarcinomas of the kidney.
  • They are presented in adults of about 50-70 years of age.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with acute urinary retention and a fever of 102°F. He has a history of recurrent UTIs and has been on long-term prophylactic antibiotics. On examination, his prostate is enlarged and tender. A urine culture is positive for E. coli. An ultrasound shows evidence of a prostatic abscess. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) followed by antibiotics
Immediate surgical drainage of the prostatic abscess
Continue prophylactic antibiotics and monitor them closely

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • The prostatic abscess is a rare but severe complication of UTI, which can occur in patients with underlying risk factors such as an enlarged prostate, urinary tract obstruction, or immunocompromised state. The presence of fever, acute urinary retention, and positive urine culture with a prostatic abscess on ultrasound is a medical emergency and requires prompt intervention. Therefore, immediate surgical drainage of the prostatic abscess is preferred. This also has a low risk of complications.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) followed by antibiotics is not the appropriate management for a prostatic abscess. TURP is a surgical procedure to remove excess prostate tissue, which is not necessary in the case of a prostatic abscess. The priority is to drain the abscess to prevent complications such as sepsis, urinary tract obstruction, and fistula formation.

Option C: Prostate massage followed by antibiotics is not an appropriate management strategy for a patient with a prostatic abscess. Prostate massage may help to express the pus from the abscess, but it is not a definitive treatment and can lead to systemic infection.

Option D: Continuing prophylactic antibiotics and monitoring closely is not an appropriate management strategy for a patient with a prostatic abscess. The patient requires immediate surgical drainage of the abscess and appropriate antibiotic therapy to treat the underlying UTI.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of esophageal cancer underwent surgery and was placed on a nasogastric tube postoperatively. The tube was placed correctly, and the patient received nutrition and medication through the tube for 3 days without any issues. However, on the 4th day, the patient's condition deteriorated, and he developed abdominal distension, vomiting, and severe pain. On examination, the tube was found to be in the stomach, and a repeat X-ray showed that the tube tip had coiled in the stomach. What could be the reason for this complication, and how can it be prevented?

choices.text: The tube was too short and did not reach the small intestine. The length of the tube should be measured before insertion
The patient's condition deteriorated due to a secondary infection, which caused the tube to move out of position. Antibiotics should be given prophylactically
The patient might have pulled the tube accidentally, causing it to move out of position. The tube should be secured properly to prevent accidental dislodgment
The tube was inserted too deeply, causing it to coil in the stomach. The depth of insertion should be checked before the tube is secured

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the patient's nasogastric tube coiled in the stomach, causing complications such as abdominal distension, vomiting, and severe pain. This can happen when the tube is inserted too deeply, causing it to loop or coil in the stomach. The insertion depth should be checked before the tube is secured to prevent this complication. 
  • The correct length of the tube should be measured and marked before insertion. The tube should be inserted gently and slowly with the patient's head elevated. The insertion depth should be checked and confirmed by auscultating the epigastrium and checking for the presence of air. Once the tube is in the correct position, it should be secured properly to prevent accidental dislodgment.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: The tube was too short and did not reach the small intestine. The length of the tube should be measured before insertion. This option is incorrect because if the tube was too short, it would not have reached the stomach, let alone coiled in it.

Option B: The patient's condition deteriorated due to a secondary infection, which caused the tube to move out of position. Antibiotics should be given prophylactically. This option is incorrect because there is no indication that the patient had a secondary infection, and antibiotics would not prevent a nasogastric tube from coiling in the stomach.

Option C: The patient might have pulled the tube accidentally, causing it to move out of position. The tube should be secured properly to prevent accidental dislodgment. This option is incorrect because the tube was coiled in the stomach, indicating that it was not accidentally dislodged but rather inserted too deeply.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is undergoing surgery for a perforated peptic ulcer. During the procedure, the surgeon noticed that the patient had an allergy to silk sutures, which were the planned suture material. The surgical team needs to choose an alternative suture material to use. Which of the following suture materials would be the best alternative for the surgeon to use in this situation?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

  • In this situation, the surgeon needs to choose an alternative suture material that the patient is not allergic to. Silk sutures are natural suture materials made from the protein fibers of silkworms, and some patients may develop an allergy to them. Therefore, an alternative suture material needs to be selected.
  • Polydioxanone (PDS) is a synthetic, absorbable suture material that is commonly used for closing wounds and surgical incisions. It has been shown to have excellent tensile strength and to maintain its integrity for several weeks after surgery. PDS is not made of silk and, therefore, would be a good alternative suture material for a patient with a silk allergy.

Incorrect option:

Option B: Nylon is a synthetic, non-absorbable suture material that is also commonly used in surgery. It is strong and durable, and its smooth surface allows for easy passage through tissue. However, nylon is not a good alternative suture material for a patient with a silk allergy as it is also a synthetic material. Nylon sutures can cause tissue irritation and inflammation, and they are not absorbable, which means they need to be removed after a sufficient healing period. Therefore, nylon sutures are not an ideal alternative for silk sutures in this situation.

Option C: Vicryl is a synthetic absorbable suture material that is derived from a co-polymer of lactide and glycolide. While it is generally well-tolerated, it is not the best choice in this situation as it can also cause allergic reactions in some patients.

Option D: Stainless steel is a non-absorbable suture material that is commonly used in orthopedic and dental surgeries. In the given scenario, it is a 45-year-old patient who is undergoing surgery for a perforated peptic ulcer. Therefore, it is not a good choice in this situation as it can cause tissue damage and may not be easily removed.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever. On imaging, a type IV-A choledochal cyst is detected. Which of the following is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement
Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) with stent placement

questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

  • Choledochal cysts are rare congenital anomalies characterized by dilatation of the biliary tree. There are five main types of choledochal cysts, and the management approach varies depending on the type of cyst and the patient's symptoms.
  • Type IV-A cysts are characterized by the presence of multiple cystic dilations involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. This type of cyst is associated with a high risk of complications, including cholangitis, pancreatitis, and cholangiocarcinoma.
  • Surgical excision of the cyst is the most appropriate management option for patients with type IV-A choledochal cysts due to the risk of malignancy. This approach involves the complete excision of the cyst and reconstruction of the biliary tree. 

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stent placement: ERCP with stent placement can be used to relieve symptoms in patients with choledochal cysts, but it is not a curative option. In type IV-A choledochal cysts, the presence of multiple cystic dilations makes complete excision of the cyst necessary to prevent the risk of complications.

Option C: Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided drainage: EUS-guided drainage can be used to relieve symptoms in patients with choledochal cysts, but it is not a curative option. In type IV-A choledochal cysts, the presence of multiple cystic dilations makes complete excision of the cyst necessary to prevent the risk of complications.

Option D: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) with stent placement: PTC with stent placement can be used to relieve symptoms in patients with choledochal cysts, but it is not a curative option. In type IV-A choledochal cysts, the presence of multiple cystic dilations makes complete excision of the cyst necessary to prevent the risk of complications.

questions.text:
A natural disaster has occurred, and a triage team is set up at a local hospital to assess and prioritize patients. The team consists of a senior physician, a nurse, and a paramedic. The team is presented with five patients at once, all with different injuries.

Patient 1: A 45-year-old male with a severe head injury, unconscious and unresponsive.
Patient 2: A 20-year-old female with a fractured leg and bleeding wound.
Patient 3: A 30-year-old male with minor cuts and bruises.
Patient 4: A 70-year-old female with chest pain and shortness of breath.
Patient 5: A 10-year-old male with a broken arm.

What should the triage team do first?

choices.text: Assess patient 1 and provide immediate medical attention.
Assess patient 4 as she is elderly and may be experiencing a cardiac emergency.
Assess patient 5 as he is a child and may be more vulnerable to trauma.
Assess patient 2 as she has a life-threatening injury and needs immediate attention.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Assess patient 2 as she has a life-threatening injury and needs immediate attention. In the given scenario, patient 2 is a 20-year-old female presented with a fractured leg and bleeding wound. This patient has a fracture with bleeding, which is a priority injury in the triage process. The bleeding wound could lead to further complications and should be addressed immediately. Thus, patient 2 needs immediate attention.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Assess patient 1 and provide immediate medical attention - Although a severe head injury is a critical injury, the patient is unconscious and unresponsive, making it difficult to assess the severity of the injury. Therefore, the priority should be to attend to the patient with a life-threatening injury.

Option B: Assess patient 4 as she is elderly and may be experiencing a cardiac emergency - Although the patient is elderly and may be experiencing a cardiac emergency, the symptoms described are not definitive enough to indicate an immediate life-threatening situation. Thus, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Assess patient 5 as he is a child and may be more vulnerable to trauma - Although children may be more vulnerable to trauma but the 10-year-old presented is categorized as a walking wounded with only a broken arm. Therefore, he doesn’t need immediate attention.

questions.text: A 2-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department with a distended abdomen and poor feeding. On examination, he is found to have a palpable bladder, and a post-void residual volume of 40 mL is measured on ultrasound. Further imaging given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this neonate?

choices.text: Immediate insertion of a suprapubic catheter
Placement of a Foley catheter for urinary drainage

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The posterior urethral valve (PUV) is the most common congenital anomaly of the male urethra and is characterized by a thin membrane in the posterior urethra that obstructs the urinary flow. PUV is typically diagnosed prenatally or in the neonatal period and can present with a distended bladder, poor feeding, and urinary tract infections.
  • In this case, the most appropriate initial management for this neonate is to relieve the obstruction by inserting a Foley catheter for urinary drainage. This will help to decompress the bladder, prevent further renal damage, and allow for accurate monitoring of urine output. 

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Immediate insertion of a suprapubic catheter: Suprapubic catheterization may be considered if the urethra is completely obstructed, but in this case, the PUV is not completely obstructive, as evidenced by the post-void residual volume of 40 mL.

Option B: Initiation of intravenous antibiotics: Initiation of antibiotics is not indicated in this case unless there is a concurrent urinary tract infection, which should be treated with appropriate antibiotics.

Option D: Emergent cystoscopic valve ablation is a definitive treatment for PUV, but it is not the initial management. Valve ablation is typically performed after the initial stabilization of the patient and the relief of obstruction.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a left testicular mass that was found incidentally during a routine physical examination. Ultrasound of the scrotum shows a solid mass in the left testicle with areas of calcification. Blood tests reveal elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase. The patient undergoes orchiectomy, and pathology confirms a seminoma. Further imaging reveals no evidence of metastasis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• Seminoma is the most common type of testicular cancer and is sensitive to both radiation and chemotherapy. 
  • RPLND is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient because RPLND is a surgical procedure that removes the retroperitoneal lymph nodes to determine if there is any evidence of metastasis. This is particularly important in cases of seminoma, where the presence of retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis has significant implications for prognosis and treatment.

Incorrect Choices

Option A: Observation alone may be an option for low-risk stage I seminoma, but since this patient has elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein and lactate dehydrogenase, which indicate a higher risk of relapse, observation alone is not the most appropriate next step.

Option B: Adjuvant chemotherapy is not recommended for stage I seminoma, and even in higher stages, as the risk of relapse is low, and the side effects of chemotherapy may outweigh the benefits. RPLND is typically performed first to determine the extent of the disease.

Option C: Radiation therapy is another treatment option for stage I seminoma but is typically reserved for patients who are not candidates for RPLND or who refuse surgery.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presented with a 6-month history of a non-healing ulcer on the left side of the tongue. He has a history of tobacco use and occasional alcohol consumption. Examination revealed an ulcerated lesion measuring 2x2 cm on the left lateral border of the tongue with palpable left submandibular lymph nodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Oral cavity carcinoma is a type of head and neck cancer that requires a multimodal approach to management. Surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of these modalities may be used depending on the extent and stage of the disease. In the case presented, the patient has a biopsy-proven squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue with palpable lymph nodes, indicating at least stage III disease. Therefore, combined modality therapy can be considered the most appropriate next step in managing this patient. It includes surgery followed by radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Radiation therapy alone may be considered in patients with an early-stage disease or in combination with chemotherapy in more advanced cases. However, radiation therapy alone is not the most appropriate next step for the patient presented in this case. 

Option B: Chemotherapy alone is typically reserved for patients with metastatic disease or in combination with radiation therapy for locally advanced disease. It is not the most appropriate next step for the patient presented in this case. 

Option D: Supportive care only is not the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient because the patient has a potentially curable malignancy. Supportive care only may be considered in patients with advanced disease who are not candidates for curative treatment.

questions.text: A newborn is evaluated for 2 episodes of projectile vomiting, which started 5 hours after the delivery. Vomitus is green in color and half a cup in quantity. He was born at 35 weeks of gestation via caesarian section due to placental insufficiency causing fetal distress. The abdomen is distended. An X-ray abdomen image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Jejunal atresia

  • This is the case of jejunal atresia, a type of congenital visceral malformation due to any vascular accident in the uterus resulting in ischemia, atresia, and obstruction of the small bowel.
  • Risk factors given in the history above are prematurity, polyhydramnios, and a history of maternal drug abuse during pregnancy.
  • Jejunal atresia can be defined as the absence or obstruction of the jejunum and ileum. In this case, bilious vomiting, jaundice, and abdominal distention are the symptoms indicating jejunal atresia.
  • The X-ray above shows a triple-bubble sign (dilated loops of the small intestine due to distention of the stomach, duodenum, and jejunum). This confirms the diagnosis of jejunal atresia.

Option A: Duodenal atresia

  • Duodenal atresia is the complete/incomplete obstruction of the duodenal lumen with similar symptoms during the clinical presentation.
  • However, on X-ray a double-bubble sign is usually seen and is usually diagnostic.

Option C: Ileal atresia

  • In patient with ileal atresia, gestational age and birth weight is usually significantly lower than in patients with jejunal atresia.
  • It shows multiple air-fluid levels and distal obstructions, but the confirmation of the diagnosis of ileal atresia cannot be done without a contrast enema study.

Option D: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis

  • In Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, the symptoms usually develop after 2nd week of age. Moreover, the vomiting is usually non-bilious.
  • X-ray usually shows a single-bubble appearance along with string and beak signs.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female accompanied by her husband presents to Gynaecology OPD for contraceptive counselling. She has been married for 6 years, and her last childbirth was 1 year ago. She has 4 live children with one abortion. Also, she was concerned about limiting her family from having no contraindications for oral contraceptive pills. It has been explained that the failure rate of contraceptive pills is less than 1 per Hundred Woman Years. How can the failure rate be calculated?

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / number of women observed x Total months of contraceptive use.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Option A : The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate . Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932 The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women years (HWY) & calculated as

Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive

(1200 is the number of months in 100 years).

Another technique is the life-table method. It calculates the probability of pregnancy in successive months, which are then added over in a given interval.

Option B, C, D : These are all incorrect formulas.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with concerns about her recent pregnancy test results. She is 6 weeks pregnant and reports experiencing spotting and mild cramping. Her serum hCG levels were measured twice, 48 hours apart, with the second measurement showing a 35% increase compared to the first. Based on this information, which of the following conditions is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Ectopic pregnancy is the most likely condition in this scenario. In a normal intrauterine pregnancy, serum hCG levels are expected to double approximately every 48 hours during the early weeks of pregnancy. In this case, the woman's hCG levels increased by only 35% over 48 hours, which raises suspicion of an ectopic pregnancy. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of spotting and mild cramping are consistent with an ectopic pregnancy.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Normal intrauterine pregnancy is less likely in this scenario, as hCG levels typically double approximately every 48 hours during early pregnancy. The 35% increase over 48 hours is not consistent with a normal pregnancy.

Option B: Threatened miscarriage is a possibility, as the patient experiences spotting and cramping. However, the slow increase in hCG levels makes ectopic pregnancy more likely in this case.

Option D: Hydatidiform mole is characterized by abnormally high hCG levels, often much higher than those seen in a normal pregnancy. In this scenario, the patient's hCG levels increased at a slower rate than expected, making a hydatidiform mole less likely.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida woman at 26 weeks of gestation comes in for a routine antenatal visit. On clinical examination, her fundal height measures 30 cm. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: Normal fundal height for gestational age

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the woman's fundal height measures 30 cm at 26 weeks of gestation. Typically, fundal height in centimeters should correspond roughly to the gestational age in weeks (± 2 cm). Therefore, the expected fundal height for this patient would be around 24-28 cm. The larger fundal height of 30 cm suggests a possible explanation like polyhydramnios, which is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid surrounding the fetus.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Normal fundal height for gestational age is not likely because the measured fundal height of 30 cm is higher than the expected 24-28 cm for this gestational age.

Option C: Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is less likely, as IUGR typically presents with a fundal height that is smaller than the expected value for the gestational age.

Option D: Incorrect estimation of gestational age is possible, but without additional information, it is less likely than polyhydramnios, which can be associated with a larger fundal height. Further evaluation, such as an ultrasound, would be necessary to determine the cause of the discrepancy and confirm the correct gestational age.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman at 38 weeks of gestation with gestational diabetes is undergoing a non-stress test (NST) as part of her antenatal care. The cardiotocography (CTG) tracing shows a baseline fetal heart rate of 135 bpm, moderate variability, and three accelerations of at least 15 bpm lasting for 15 seconds within a 20-minute period. No decelerations are noted. How would you interpret these NST results?
questions.solution:
• A reactive non-stress test (NST) is characterized by a normal baseline fetal heart rate (110-160 bpm), moderate variability, and the presence of at least two accelerations of at least 15 bpm above the baseline, lasting for at least 15 seconds within a 20-minute period. In this scenario, the CTG tracing fulfills these criteria, indicating a reactive NST, which suggests that the fetus is not experiencing significant distress.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Non-reactive NST is incorrect because the CTG tracing demonstrates the required accelerations and variability for a reactive NST.

Option C: Indeterminate NST typically occurs when the tracing shows some characteristics of both reactive and non-reactive tests or when the tracing quality is inadequate for interpretation. This does not apply to the given scenario.

Option D: Abnormal NST is characterized by absent or minimal variability, recurrent late or variable decelerations, or bradycardia. None of these features are present in the given scenario, which makes this option correct.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents with a confirmed breech presentation to her healthcare provider. She has no significant medical history, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. Which of the following management options is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Trial of labor and vaginal delivery

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the most appropriate management option for a breech presentation at 37 weeks of gestation in an uncomplicated pregnancy is an external cephalic version (ECV). ECV is a procedure in which the healthcare provider attempts to manually turn the fetus into a head-down (vertex) position before labor. This increases the likelihood of successful vaginal delivery and reduces the need for cesarean delivery.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Immediate cesarean delivery is not warranted at this point because an ECV can be attempted first to facilitate vaginal delivery.

Option B: Trial of labor and vaginal delivery is generally not recommended for breech presentation due to the increased risk of complications, such as cord prolapse, fetal distress, and birth trauma. However, this option may be considered in certain circumstances and with an experienced healthcare provider.

Option D: Induction of labor with prostaglandins is inappropriate in this case, as it does not address the breech presentation. Induction in a breech presentation without first attempting an ECV could lead to a higher likelihood of cesarean delivery or complications.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with regular contractions. Her cervix is 4 cm dilated, and the contractions are occurring every 5 minutes. Four hours later, her contractions continue every 5 minutes, but her cervical dilation has only progressed to 5 cm. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor
Encourage ambulation and reevaluate in 2 hours

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the patient is in the active phase of the first stage of labor, with contractions occurring regularly and her cervix dilated to 4 cm. However, her cervical dilation has progressed slowly, with only 1 cm of dilation in 4 hours. This suggests that her labor may not be progressing as expected.
  • Oxytocin is a hormone that stimulates uterine contractions and can be used to augment labor when progress is slow. The augmentation of labor with oxytocin administration is the most appropriate course of action to facilitate cervical dilation and the progress of the labor.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Immediate cesarean delivery is not warranted at this point, as augmentation with oxytocin can be attempted to facilitate the progress of labor.

Option C: Encouraging ambulation and reevaluating in 2 hours may not adequately address the slow progress of labor. Augmentation with oxytocin is a more proactive approach to facilitating labor progression.

Option D: Administering epidural analgesia can provide pain relief but does not address the slow progression of labor. Augmentation with oxytocin is more appropriate for this situation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is admitted to the labor and delivery unit with regular contractions. The healthcare provider begins monitoring her labor progress using a partograph. Four hours after admission, her contractions occur every 5 minutes, and her cervix is 6 cm dilated. The fetal heart rate is normal, and the descent of the fetal head is progressing adequately. However, the patient's contractions cross the action line on the partograph. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Continue to monitor labor without intervention
Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor
Administer intravenous fluids and reevaluate in one hour

questions.solution:
• The partograph, also known as a partogram, is a graphical tool used to monitor labor progress and fetal well-being. It helps healthcare providers identify deviations from normal labor progression and guides management decisions. The partograph consists of several components, including cervical dilation, fetal descent, uterine contractions, and fetal heart rate.
  • In this scenario, the patient's contractions have crossed the action line on the partograph, indicating a potential issue with the strength or frequency of contractions. The most appropriate course of action is to administer intravenous fluids and reevaluate the labor progress in one hour. This approach aims to address potential dehydration, which can affect the quality of contractions, and to reassess the situation before deciding on further interventions.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Continuing to monitor labor without intervention may not adequately address the potential issue with contractions indicated by the partograph.

Option B: Administering oxytocin for augmentation of labor may not be necessary at this point, as addressing potential dehydration and reevaluating labor progress can help determine if further intervention is needed.

Option C: Immediate cesarean delivery is not warranted at this point, as the patient's cervical dilation and fetal descent are progressing adequately, and the issue with contractions can potentially be addressed with intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 39 weeks of gestation is in the second stage of labor. The fetal heart rate is normal, and the fetus is descending in the birth canal. The patient has been pushing for 1 hour, and the healthcare provider notices significant perineal stretching with a risk of perineal tearing. Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Continue to monitor labor without intervention
Administer oxytocin for augmentation of labor

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the healthcare provider notices significant perineal stretching and a risk of perineal tearing during the second stage of labor. The most appropriate course of action is to perform an episiotomy, which is a surgical incision made in the perineum (the area between the vagina and anus) to enlarge the vaginal opening and facilitate delivery. This procedure aims to prevent uncontrolled perineal tearing and reduce the risk of complications, such as postpartum hemorrhage and perineal pain.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Continuing to monitor labor without intervention may not adequately address the risk of perineal tearing and associated complications.

Option C: Administering oxytocin for augmentation of labor is not indicated in this situation, as the patient is already in the second stage of labor, and the issue at hand is perineal stretching and potential tearing.

Option D: Performing an immediate cesarean delivery is not warranted at this point, as an episiotomy can be performed to facilitate delivery and reduce the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to the labor and delivery unit with spontaneous rupture of membranes. On examination, the healthcare provider notices a loop of umbilical cord protruding from the vagina. The fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Manual reduction of the prolapsed cord
Administer tocolytics and continue to monitor the patient

questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the patient presents with umbilical cord prolapse, which is an obstetric emergency. The most appropriate course of action is an urgent cesarean delivery to minimize the risk of fetal hypoxia and possible fetal demise. Cord prolapse can lead to compression of the umbilical cord, which can compromise blood flow and oxygen supply to the fetus.

Incorrect options:

Option B: Manual reduction of the prolapsed cord is not the first-line management in this case, as it may not be successful or may only provide temporary relief. The priority is to deliver the baby as soon as possible to minimize the risk of complications.

Option C: Administering tocolytics is not indicated in this situation, as the priority is to deliver the baby as soon as possible due to the risk of fetal hypoxia. Tocolytics procedure is used to delay fetus delivery in women experiencing preterm contractions.

Option D: Awaiting spontaneous vaginal delivery is not appropriate in this case, as the risk of fetal hypoxia is significant, and prompt intervention is necessary to minimize complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida woman at 40 weeks of gestation is considered for induction of labor. The healthcare provider performs a cervical examination to calculate the Bishop's score. The following findings are noted: cervical dilation of 1 cm, effacement of 50%, station -1, consistency medium, and position posterior. What is the woman's Bishop's score, and what does it indicate regarding the success of labor induction?
questions.solution:
• The Bishop's score is a pre-labor scoring system used to evaluate the readiness of the cervix for induction of labor. The Bishop's score is calculated using the following findings: cervical dilation, effacement, station, consistency, and position. 
  • In this scenario, the woman's Bishop's score is 5 (1 point for dilation, 1 point for effacement, 1 point for station, 1 point for consistency, and 1 point for position). A Bishop's score of 5 is considered unfavorable for induction, indicating that the success of labor induction may be low, and there is an increased risk of cesarean delivery. 

Incorrect options:

Option A: The Bishop's score of 5 is considered unfavorable, not favorable, for induction.

Option B: The calculated Bishop's score is 5, not 7, and is considered unfavorable for induction.

Option D: The calculated Bishop's score is 5, not 7.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of heavy menstrual bleeding is diagnosed with a large intramural fibroid. She is nulliparous and desires to preserve her fertility. Which of the following treatment options would be the most appropriate for her?
questions.solution:
• In this scenario, the patient is nulliparous and wishes to preserve her fertility. Myomectomy is the most appropriate treatment option, as it involves surgically removing the fibroid while preserving the uterus. This procedure can help alleviate the patient's heavy menstrual bleeding and maintain her ability to conceive.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Hysterectomy, which involves the removal of the uterus, is unsuitable for this patient, as she desires to preserve her fertility.

Option C: Uterine artery embolization is a minimally invasive procedure used to treat fibroids by blocking their blood supply, causing them to shrink. However, this treatment may negatively impact fertility, making it a less suitable option for this patient.

Option D: Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist therapy can help shrink fibroids temporarily by suppressing the production of estrogen and progesterone. This treatment may be useful for symptom relief but does not provide a long-term solution, especially for a patient who desires to preserve fertility.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of irregular menstrual cycles, hirsutism, and obesity is diagnosed with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). She is not planning to conceive in the near future but is concerned about the long-term health consequences of PCOS. Which management strategies would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• In this case, the patient is not planning to conceive soon and is concerned about the long-term health consequences of PCOS. Lifestyle modifications, including weight loss through diet and exercise, are the first-line management strategy for PCOS, as they can improve insulin resistance, reduce androgen levels, and help regulate menstrual cycles. This approach addresses the patient's concerns and can positively impact her overall health.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Clomiphene citrate induces ovulation in women with PCOS who wish to conceive. It is not the most appropriate choice for this patient, as she is not planning to conceive in the near future.

Option B: Metformin may help improve insulin resistance and regulate menstrual cycles in some women with PCOS. However, lifestyle modifications should be tried first before considering pharmacological interventions.

Option C: Progesterone-only contraceptives can help regulate menstrual cycles but do not address the insulin resistance and other metabolic aspects of PCOS. Moreover, lifestyle modifications should be tried first before considering pharmacological interventions.

questions.text: 14-year-old girl presents with short stature, primary amenorrhea, and a webbed neck. Chromosomal analysis reveals a 45, X karyotype, confirming a diagnosis of Turner syndrome. The patient's mother is concerned about potential complications associated with Turner syndrome. Which of the following long-term complications has the highest prevalence in patients with Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Among the potential long-term complications associated with Turner syndrome, autoimmune thyroiditis has the highest prevalence, affecting around 30% of individuals with the condition. Hypothyroidism resulting from autoimmune thyroiditis is a common endocrine issue in Turner syndrome patients.

Incorrect Choices:
