Option A. Although Turner syndrome patients are at an increased risk for developing impaired glucose tolerance and type 2 diabetes, the prevalence is lower than autoimmune thyroiditis. Studies estimate that around 10-20% of individuals with Turner syndrome develop type 2 diabetes.

Option B. Hypertension is a common complication in Turner syndrome, but its prevalence is lower than autoimmune thyroiditis. Hypertension affects approximately 20-40% of Turner syndrome patients.

Option D. Osteoporosis is a long-term complication associated with Turner syndrome, particularly due to estrogen deficiency. However, its prevalence is lower than autoimmune thyroiditis, with studies estimating that around 20-30% of Turner syndrome patients develop osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female primigravida from poor socio-economic background comes to the OPD for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks gestation. Ultrasound revealed a gap in the fetal spine through which the spinal cord and meninges protrude. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient hails from a poor socio-economic background and presents for her first antenatal checkup at 20 weeks gestation. This shows that she hasn’t received proper antenatal care and is unlikely to have received folic acid supplementation. This puts her fetus at an increased risk of developing neural tube defects. 
Spina bifida is one such defect where the spinal canal's contents protrude through spine defects. Here, ultrasound shows protrusion of the spinal cord and meninges. Hence, myelomeningocele is the most likely answer. The risk of developing neural tube defects can be reduced significantly by supplementing the pregnant mother with folic acid.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Meningocele is a type of spina bifida where only the meninges protrude through the defect in the spine. The fetus in this question has a protrusion of both meninges and spinal cord, so this is unlikely to be the answer. 

Option C. Spina bifida occulta is the mildest form of spina bifida, with a gap in the spine’s vertebrae. The fetus in question has a more substantial defect with protrusion of the spinal cord and meninges. Hence, this is unlikely to be the answer.

Option D. It is a condition where part of the brain protrudes through a gap in the skull. The question mentions protrusion of the spinal cord and meninges through a gap in the spine. Hence, this is unlikely to be the answer.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl was presented to the OP for evaluation of primary amenorrhea. Clinical examination showed normally developed breasts and thin pubic hair. Examination revealed well-developed labia and a short vagina which ended blindly. Cervix was not visualized. She had a history of bilateral inguinal hernias, which were surgically repaired at the age of 2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given case is a presentation of complete androgen insensitivity syndrome or testicular feminization syndrome. The patient, although presenting with a female phenotype, is, in fact, a male with XY genotype. The bilateral inguinal hernias that occurred as a child were most probably testicular masses. Despite producing androgens, the child’s body is not able to utilize them properly because of defective androgen receptors.   

Incorrect options:

Option A: Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome (MRKHS) is a Mullerian duct anomaly. It can also present with primary amenorrhea and uterovaginal agenesis. However, the bilateral inguinal hernia that this patient had is more in line with the diagnosis of testicular feminization syndrome.

Option C: Complete Androgen Insensitivity syndrome is a type of mild androgen insensitivity syndrome. But the external genitalia in such patients is unambiguously male. Hence it cannot be the diagnosis here.

Option D: Reifenstein syndrome is a type of partial androgen insensitivity syndrome where the masculinization of external genitalia is less. It usually presents with hypospadias, micropenis, and gynecomastia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to the OP for evaluation of secondary amenorrhea. She had a history of incomplete abortion 4 years back, which was evacuated using D & C. She has been having oligomenorrhea for the past 2 years and is now presenting with amenorrhea. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
This patient had a history of dilatation & curettage (D&C) for incomplete abortion. Following this, her menstruation slowly reduced, and now she is presenting with amenorrhea. The most likely cause, in this case, is the development of adhesions in the uterus following D & C. This condition is known as Asherman’s syndrome. Trauma associated with D & C causes inflammation of the endometrium that results in the formation of adhesions. This can result in amenorrhea.
 

Incorrect choices

Option A) Sheehan’s syndrome is the necrosis of the anterior pituitary gland associated with significant postpartum bleeding. It usually presents in the post-partum period as nausea, weight gain, and lactational failure. Late presentations include adrenal crisis and hypothyroidism that may lead to amenorrhea. But this patient doesn’t exhibit any nausea, weight gain, and lactational failure. Also, she has a history of D&C, which makes Sheehan’s syndrome a less likely cause.

Option C) Fitz Hugh Curtis syndrome is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease resulting in inflammation of the liver capsule. It typically presents as right upper quadrant pain in women of the childbearing age group and not secondary amenorrhea like the current patient.

Option D) Amniotic band syndrome affects the fetus and its normal development. It occurs when the amniotic sac lining is destroyed during pregnancy, creating fine strands known as amniotic bands, which trap and entangle the developing fetal body parts. The mother usually doesn’t present any specific symptoms in this case.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female comes to the OP with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks back, and she is worried that she might get pregnant. Which of the following methods cannot be advised to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
In the given scenario, the 23-year-old female patient had her menstrual period 2 weeks back. If her menstrual cycles are regular, there is a high chance of pregnancy. As she doesn’t desire to get pregnant, emergency contraception has to be advised. Copper-containing IUDs, levonorgestrel, and ulipristal are all emergency contraceptive regimens as recommended by the WHO and can be given to this patient. Hence, the answer here is none of the above. 
 

Incorrect choices

Option A: Levonorgestrel is a hormonal medication used as a birth control method. It can be used as an emergency contraceptive and is recommended to use within 72 hours of unprotected sex. Therefore, it can be advised to the patient.

Option B: Copper-containing intrauterine contraceptive devices are non-hormonal IUDs. These are T-shape plastic frames inserted into the uterus and are advised for emergency contraceptive use within 5 days of unprotected sex. Therefore, this also can be advised to the patient.

Option C: Ulipristal acetate is also used as an emergency contraceptive. It is known to be more effective than levonorgestrel and has an efficacy of up to 5 days. Thus, it is also a method that can be advised to the patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady who is 37 weeks pregnant was complaining of headaches and visual disturbances. Her husband brought her to the hospital, where she had a seizure. On examination, her pulse rate was 94 beats per minute, and her BP was 150/100 mm of Hg. She was visibly edematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • The occurrence of a tonic-clonic seizure in a patient with pre-eclampsia is defined as eclampsia. It occurs rarely but is a serious condition and is considered an obstetric emergency.
  • In the given scenario, the patient was found to have hypertension and edema upon an examination which are signs of already existing pre-eclampsia. The patient was brought to the hospital after she had a seizure. Now, since the occurrence of a tonic-clonic seizure is observed in eclampsia, it can be concluded that the most likely diagnosis is eclampsia.

Incorrect choices

Option A: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia has high blood pressure but doesn’t experience seizures or coma. Since the patient, in this case, already has features of pre-eclampsia and was brought to the hospital after the development of seizures, it is indicative of eclampsia and not just pre-eclampsia.

Option C: HELLP syndrome. It is a complication of pre-eclampsia characterized with elevated liver enzymes, hemolysis, and low platelet count. Manifestations of these are not mentioned in the question, so this is unlikely to be the answer.

Option D: Gestational hypertension is a condition characterized by increased blood pressure that starts with pregnancy. However, it is not usually accompanied by edema or proteinuria. In the given scenario, the patient presents hypertension and edema. Therefore, it is an incorrect choice.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the OP with vaginal itching and profuse, greenish discharge for one week. She is sexually active and does not have the habit of using any form of contraception. Her last period was 2 weeks ago. A wet mount of the vaginal discharge shows the presence of motile flagellates.   

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient is sexually active and doesn’t use any form of contraception. This puts her at an increased risk of contracting sexually transmitted diseases. Many STDs present with itching and discharge from the genital region. The patient’s symptoms of profuse, green, frothy discharge, along with pruritus, are indicative of trichomonas infection. The saline wet mount of the vaginal discharge also shows motile flagellates. This is a typical description of the causative organism - Trichomonas vaginalis. 

Incorrect choices
Option A: Bacterial vaginosis is a form of inflammation that is observed in the vagina. It is caused by bacteria such as Mobiluncus and Prevotella. It usually doesn’t present with pruritus but with a grey/white discharge with a fishy odour. In the given scenario, the women present with vaginal itching and profuse, greenish discharge, which isn’t observed in the case of bacterial vaginosis. Therefore, it is an incorrect choice.

Option C: Gonorrhoea usually presents as pain or a burning sensation while urinating. Thick, cloudy, or bloody discharge and anal itching may also be present. The patient here doesn’t present with these symptoms. Also, Neisseria Gonorrhoea, the causative organism, is usually identified by culture. Hence, this is unlikely to be the correct answer.

Option D: Candidiasis is characterized by white, cheesy discharge. Candida albicans, the causative organism, is identified by KOH mount, which reveals pseudohyphae. As the patient here presented with vaginal itching and greenish discharge, and the causative organism was identified using a saline wet mount, therefore, candidiasis is unlikely to be the correct answer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is 27 weeks pregnant comes for a routine antenatal visit. There are no presenting complaints. On examination, her vitals were normal. She was asked to ingest 50 mg of glucose and have her blood glucose level checked after one hour. The report came in as 145 mg/dL. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Check her fasting blood glucose level

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Pregnant patients are routinely tested for gestational diabetes mellitus. This patient has had an uneventful pregnancy so far. Ingesting 50 g of glucose and checking blood sugar levels is a diabetic screening method known as a ‘glucose load test.’ This test is usually done between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy. If the values checked after 1 hour are above 140 mg/dL, the patient has to undergo an oral glucose tolerance test to confirm the diagnosis of gestational diabetes. Here, the patient’s value is 145 mg/dL, so she has to undergo an oral glucose tolerance test.

Incorrect choices

Option A: Initiating insulin therapy without a confirmed diagnosis of gestational diabetes is not advisable. The diagnosis has to be first confirmed using a glucose tolerance test. Hence this is not the next step in the management of this patient.

Option B: Oral hypoglycaemic drugs can be used in managing gestational diabetes, but only after a confirmed diagnosis. As the patient had an abnormal glucose load test value, a glucose tolerance test has to be performed to confirm the diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus before starting treatment.

Option C: Fasting blood glucose levels, that is, the blood sugar measured after an overnight fast, is not used to diagnose gestational diabetes. Hence, this is not the correct answer here.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with a history of osteoporosis and multiple vertebral fractures. She is currently taking bisphosphonates for the management of her condition. On laboratory investigation, it is found that the patient has developed hypocalcemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue bisphosphonates and initiate teriparatide therapy
Add calcium and vitamin D supplementation to the patient's regimen

questions.solution:
• Bisphosphonates are a class of drugs used for the management of osteoporosis by inhibiting bone resorption. Hypocalcemia is a known adverse effect of bisphosphonate therapy. The most appropriate next step in managing this patient is to add calcium and vitamin D supplementation to her regimen. This will help correct the hypocalcemia and reduce the risk of subsequent fractures. Discontinuation of bisphosphonates or increasing their dose is not recommended as they can increase the risk of fractures and other adverse effects.

Incorrect options

Option A: Teriparatide is a recombinant parathyroid hormone used for the treatment of osteoporosis. While it can increase bone mineral density, it is not the appropriate next step in managing hypocalcemia caused by bisphosphonate therapy.

Option B: Increasing the dose of bisphosphonates is not recommended as it can increase the risk of fractures and other adverse effects.

Option D: Denosumab is a monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of osteoporosis. While it can increase bone mineral density, it is not the appropriate next step in managing hypocalcemia caused by bisphosphonate therapy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus has an HbA1c level of 8.5% despite maximum tolerated doses of metformin and a sulfonylurea. Which of the following statements regarding DPP4 inhibitors is false?

choices.text: DPP4 inhibitors stimulate insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells
DPP4 inhibitors block the degradation of endogenous incretin hormones
DPP4 inhibitors have a low risk of causing hypoglycemia
DPP4 inhibitors increase the risk of pancreatic cancer

questions.solution:
• DPP4 inhibitors, also known as gliptins, are a class of medications used in the management of diabetes. DPP4 inhibitors have a low risk of causing hypoglycemia because they only stimulate insulin secretion in the presence of elevated blood glucose levels. In contrast, sulfonylureas can cause hypoglycemia by stimulating insulin secretion regardless of blood glucose levels.
  • There is no evidence to suggest that DPP4 inhibitors increase the risk of pancreatic cancer. Some studies have suggested a possible association between the use of incretin-based therapies (including DPP4 inhibitors) and an increased risk of pancreatitis, but the evidence is conflicting, and the overall risk appears to be low. The FDA has not issued any warnings regarding the use of DPP4 inhibitors and the risk of pancreatic cancer.

Incorrect options: 

Option A: This option is true. DPP4 inhibitors stimulate insulin secretion from pancreatic beta cells by blocking the degradation of incretion hormones such as glucagon-like peptide 1 (GLP-1) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP).

Option B: This option is true. DPP4 inhibitors block the degradation of endogenous incretin hormones, which increases their half-life and enhances their insulinotropic effect.

Option C: This option is true. DPP4 inhibitors have a low risk of causing hypoglycemia compared to other antidiabetic medications such as sulfonylureas.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is the preferred therapy for the long-term management of the panic disorder?
questions.solution:
Option D: Selective serotonin reuptake Inhibitor

  • The scenario mentioned above is a classical case of an acute episode of panic disorder characterized by transient symptoms of profuse sweating, shortness of breath, chest pain and weakness/numbness of the upper and lower extremities.
    • It must be differentiated from myocardial infarction, acute stroke or any other medical condition. If the signs and symptoms cannot be associated with any medical illness, then a diagnosis of panic disorder is made.
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are the drug of choice for the long-term management of panic disorders because of their efficacy, tolerability and general safety in overdose. 

Option A: Phenothiazine

  • Phenothiazine is a D2-dopamine receptor antagonist in the area postrema of the midbrain and is used to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis.

Option B: Azapirone

  • Azapirone is a new class of psychotherapeutic drugs mainly used as anxiolytics without any significant sedative side effects.

Option C: Beta blocker

  • Beta blockers are of no use for the long-term management of the panic disorder. However, beta blockers are limited for acute symptomatic control of panic disorder, including managing palpitations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with severe chronic kidney disease (CKD) has been prescribed a medication that undergoes significant first-pass metabolism in the liver. Which of the following factors is most likely to affect the drug's absorption in this patient?
questions.solution:
• In patients with severe CKD, the clearance of drugs can be significantly reduced due to decreased renal function. As a result, the drug may remain in circulation for a longer period, increasing the likelihood of it undergoing first-pass metabolism in the liver. 
  • First-pass metabolism refers to the process in which a drug is metabolized by the liver before it enters the systemic circulation. In this patient with severe CKD, the liver may be responsible for metabolizing a larger portion of the drug due to decreased renal clearance.
  • Protein binding is a crucial factor in drug absorption because it affects the amount of drug that is available for distribution and metabolism. Drugs that are highly protein-bound are less likely to be absorbed because they are unable to diffuse across cell membranes. In patients with CKD, the concentration of plasma proteins may be altered, which can affect drug binding and ultimately impact drug absorption.

Incorrect options

Option A: Gastric pH is not a significant factor in drug absorption in patients with CKD. Although it can affect the solubility and stability of some drugs, it is unlikely to have a significant impact on absorption in this patient.

Option B: Gastric emptying time is also not a significant factor in drug absorption in patients with CKD. While it can affect the rate at which drugs are absorbed, it is unlikely to have a significant impact on absorption in this patient.

Option D: Renal blood flow is an important factor in drug elimination, but it is not directly related to drug absorption. While decreased renal blood flow can reduce the clearance of drugs and lead to an increased concentration of the drug in circulation, it is unlikely to have a significant impact on drug absorption in this patient.

questions.text: A patient with liver disease is prescribed a new drug for their condition. The drug undergoes extensive metabolism in the liver through various phase reactions before being eliminated from the body. Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding drug metabolism and phase reactions in the liver of this patient?

choices.text: Phase I reactions involve the conversion of lipophilic drugs into more polar metabolites through oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis
Phase II reactions involve the conjugation of drugs with endogenous compounds, such as glucuronic acid, sulfate, and glutathione
In liver disease, phase II reactions are impaired while phase I reactions remain intact
The metabolism of drugs in the liver is affected by genetic polymorphisms in drug-metabolizing enzymes

questions.solution:
• Drug metabolism in the liver occurs in two phases: Phase I and Phase II reactions. Phase I reactions involve the conversion of lipophilic drugs into more polar metabolites through oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis. These reactions are catalyzed by a group of enzymes called cytochrome P450 (CYP) enzymes. Phase II reactions involve the conjugation of drugs with endogenous compounds, such as glucuronic acid, sulfate, and glutathione. These reactions are catalyzed by a group of enzymes called transferases.
  • In liver disease, both phase I and phase II reactions can be affected. However, the extent and type of the impairment depend on the specific disease and its severity. Option C) is not true regarding drug metabolism and phase reactions in the liver of this patient because it suggests that only phase II reactions are impaired in liver disease, which is not true. In fact, both phases of drug metabolism can be affected, and the impairment can vary depending on the specific disease and its severity.

Incorrect options

Option A: “Phase I reactions involve the conversion of lipophilic drugs into more polar metabolites through oxidation, reduction, and hydrolysis” is a true statement regarding phase I reactions.

Option B: “Phase II reactions involve the conjugation of drugs with endogenous compounds, such as glucuronic acid, sulfate, and glutathione” is a true statement regarding phase II reactions.

Option D: “The metabolism of drugs in the liver is affected by genetic polymorphisms in drug-metabolizing enzymes” is also true since genetic polymorphisms in drug-metabolizing enzymes can affect the metabolism of drugs in the liver, leading to variable drug response among individuals.

questions.text: Total body water in a normal adult weighing 70kgs is around

Which of the following drugs can be given without the need for therapeutic dose monitoring after calculating the required dose based on the patient's weight, unlike drugs with a narrow therapeutic index?
questions.solution:
Option B: Penicillin

Therapeutic index:

  • It is a quantitative measurement of the relative drug safety profile.
  • It is calculated as follows-
  • Therapeutic index=
  • Here, TD50 means median toxic dose, and ED50 means median effective dose.
  • A drug having a high therapeutic index possesses a favourable safety and efficacy profile.
  • Drugs with a narrow therapeutic index require close therapeutic dose monitoring as they possess a high risk of adverse events.
  • Penicillin has a wide therapeutic index and does not require therapeutic dose monitoring (TDM).
  • TDM is only for drugs with narrow therapeutic index, whose values cannot be monitored by simple laboratory parameters and have inconsistent/ erratic pharmacodynamics.

Option A: Amikacin

  • Amikacin is an aminoglycoside with a narrow therapeutic index
  • So, it requires close TDM.

Option C: Phenytoin

  • Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant with a narrow therapeutic window.
  • Therefore, it requires TDM.

Option D: Cyclosporine

  • Cyclosporine is a narrow therapeutic index drug that can cause kidney damage in high doses.
  • Hence, it requires close TDM.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and gastric ulcer is prescribed with a medication that needs to be administered via the oral route. However, the physician is concerned about the potential adverse effects of oral administration of the drug on the patient's gastric ulcer. The physician also wants to ensure optimal absorption of the drug into the systemic circulation. Which of the following routes of drug administration would be the most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Rectal suppository is a safe and effective option for this patient as it allows for the drug to bypass the stomach and be absorbed into the systemic circulation via the rectal mucosa. This route of administration is particularly useful for patients with gastrointestinal issues or nausea, as well as for medications that are not well absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • In conclusion, selecting the most appropriate route of drug administration requires a thorough understanding of the patient's medical history and drug properties. In this case, the rectal suppository is the best option for optimal drug absorption and avoiding potential adverse effects on the patient's gastric ulcer.

Incorrect options

Option A: Intramuscular injection is an injection of medication introduced directly into a muscle, typically to the thigh or upper arm. This route of administration can provide rapid onset of action as the medication is absorbed into the bloodstream via the muscle tissue. However, it is not suitable for all medications, as some drugs may not be well absorbed through muscle tissue. In this case, it may not be the best option as it bypasses the gastrointestinal tract and may not achieve optimal absorption, and it does not address the concern of potential adverse effects on the gastric ulcer.

Option B: Subcutaneous injection is an injection of medication introduced into the layer of tissue just below the skin. Like intramuscular injections, subcutaneous injections can provide rapid onset of action and are suitable for certain types of medication. However, it may not be the best option in this case as it bypasses the gastrointestinal tract and may not achieve optimal absorption, and it does not address the concern of potential adverse effects on the gastric ulcer.

Option C: Intravenous injection is an injection of medication directly into a vein, typically through a catheter. This route of administration can provide rapid onset of action as the medication is immediately delivered to the bloodstream. However, it is an invasive procedure and carries risks of adverse effects such as infection, embolism, and allergic reactions. It may not be the best option in this case as it is invasive and does not address the concern of potential adverse effects on the gastric ulcer.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from a severe liver disease, and the doctor has prescribed a medication with a half-life of 10 hours. The patient's condition is unstable, and the doctor wants to achieve steady-state levels of the drug as soon as possible. However, the doctor is concerned about the potential accumulation of the drug and its metabolites in the patient's body due to impaired drug clearance. What is the ideal dosing frequency, duration, and dose interval for this patient to achieve steady-state levels of the drug without causing toxicity?
questions.solution:
• The half-life of a drug is the time required for the concentration of the drug in the body to decrease by 50%. In this case, the drug has a half-life of 10 hours, which means that it takes 10 hours for half of the drug to be eliminated from the body.
  • To achieve steady-state levels of the drug, the dosing frequency, duration, and dose interval should be determined. Steady-state levels are achieved when the rate of drug administration is equal to the rate of drug elimination. In this patient, due to impaired drug clearance, it may take longer for the drug to be eliminated from the body, so the dosing regimen should be adjusted accordingly.

The ideal dosing frequency can be calculated using the following formula

Dosing frequency = (t1/2 x 5) / ln2

where t1/2 is the half-life of the drug, and ln2 is the natural logarithm of 2 (0.693). Multiplying t1/2 by 5 accounts for the fact that it takes approximately 5 half-lives to achieve steady-state levels.

Substituting the given half-life value into the formula:

Dosing frequency = (10 x 5) / 0.693 = 72.19 hours

This means that the drug should be administered every 72.19 hours to achieve steady-state levels. However, due to the patient's unstable condition, a longer duration between doses may not be appropriate. Therefore, a dosing frequency of twice daily (every 12 hours) is recommended.

The dose interval can be calculated using the following formula:

Dose interval = t1/2 x 1.44

Where 1.44 is a conversion factor that accounts for the fact that drug concentration changes are not linear.

Substituting the given half-life value into the formula:

Dose interval = 10 x 1.44 = 14.4 hours

This means that the drug should be administered every 14.4 hours.

The dose can be calculated using the following formula:

Dose = (Css x Cl x dosing interval) / F

Where Css is the desired steady-state concentration, Cl is the clearance of the drug, and F is the bioavailability of the drug.

Assuming a desired steady-state concentration of 10mg/L, a clearance of 50ml/min, and a bioavailability of 100%, the dose can be calculated as follows:

Dose = (10 x 50 x 14.4) / 1000 = 7.2mg

Therefore, the ideal dosing regimen for this patient is twice daily (every 12 hours) for a duration of 40 hours with a dose of 10mg. This regimen will achieve steady-state levels of the drug without causing toxicity.

Incorrect option

Option A: Once daily, 48 hours, 20mg is incorrect.

Option C: Thrice daily, 30 hours, 5mg  is incorrect.

Option D: Four times daily, 24 hours, 2.5mg is incorrect.

questions.text: Adverse drug reactions are unintended pharmacological effects on administering the drug. Which of the following examples refers to a type E adverse drug reaction?
questions.solution:
Option A: Withdrawal reaction

  • Adverse Drug Reactions are noxious or unintended effects produced by drugs. These may be classified as
    • Type A: Augmented pharmacologic effects - dose dependent and predictable, e.g. hypoglycemia caused by anti-hyperglycemic drugs like sulfonylureas
    • Type B: Bizarre effects (or idiosyncratic) - Dose independent and unpredictable, e.g. allergic reactions caused by penicillins
    • Type C: Chronic effects, e.g. peptic ulcer caused by chronic use of NSAIDs
    • Type D: Delayed effects, e.g. teratogenicity caused by thalidomide
    • Type E: End-of-treatment effects, e.g. withdrawal response to morphine
    • Type F: Failure of therapy

Option B: Teratogenesis

  • Teratogenesis refers to the type D adverse effects of a drug.

Option C: Augmented response

  • Augmented response belongs to type A adverse effects of a drug, including enhanced pharmacological effects that are dose-dependent and predictable. ,E.g. Dystonia caused by metoclopramide.

Option D: Toxicity

  • Toxicity belongs to type B (bizarre adverse effects) and type C (chronic effects) class of adverse effects.
  • The bizarre adverse effects are dose-dependent and unpredictable.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of chronic pain is being treated with opioids. The patient reports adequate pain relief but presents with severe respiratory depression. The physician decides to reduce the opioid dosage to prevent adverse effects. Which of the following opioids has the least potential for respiratory depression?
questions.solution:
• Opioids are potent analgesics commonly used to treat moderate to severe pain. However, their use is associated with several adverse effects, including respiratory depression, sedation, and addiction.
  • Methadone is a synthetic opioid that acts as a mu-opioid receptor agonist. It is commonly used in the treatment of chronic pain and opioid addiction. Compared to other opioids, methadone has a long half-life and slow onset of action, resulting in a lower risk of respiratory depression. Therefore, it is the preferred option in patients with a history of respiratory depression.

Incorrect options

Option A: Fentanyl is a synthetic opioid that is highly potent and rapidly acting. It is commonly used for the management of acute pain, such as during surgery or in cancer patients. While it is an effective analgesic, it carries a high risk of respiratory depression, particularly in patients who are opioid-naive or have renal impairment. Therefore, fentanyl is not the best choice in this situation.

Option B: Morphine is a natural opioid that is commonly used in the treatment of acute and chronic pain. It is effective in managing pain, but it has a high risk of respiratory depression, especially in patients who are opioid-naive or have renal impairment. Therefore, reducing the dosage of morphine may help prevent adverse effects, but it is not the best option in this situation

Option D: Oxycodone is a semi-synthetic opioid that is commonly used for the treatment of moderate to severe pain. It has a lower risk of respiratory depression than morphine but still poses a significant risk in susceptible patients. Therefore, reducing the dosage of oxycodone may help prevent adverse effects, but it is not the best option in this situation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with sepsis was started on intravenous amikacin for the treatment of gram-negative bacterial infection. After 3 days of therapy, the patient developed vertigo, tinnitus, and unsteady gait. On examination, the patient had bilateral papilledema and increased intracranial pressure. Which of the following adverse effects of aminoglycosides is responsible for the patient's presentation, and what is the underlying mechanism?

choices.text: Ototoxicity, due to accumulation of the drug in the inner ear
Nephrotoxicity, due to inhibition of protein synthesis in renal tubular cells
Neurotoxicity, due to blockage of calcium channels in neuronal tissue
Hematological toxicity, due to bone marrow suppression

questions.solution:
• Aminoglycosides, including amikacin, are known to have several adverse effects, including ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity. Neurotoxicity can lead to a variety of neurological symptoms, such as vertigo, tinnitus, and unsteady gait, as seen in the patient presented in the question.
  • The underlying mechanism of aminoglycoside-induced neurotoxicity is not completely understood, but it is believed to be due to the blockage of calcium channels in neuronal tissue, which can lead to an increase in intracellular calcium levels and subsequent neuronal damage. This mechanism can also explain the presence of bilateral papilledema and increased intracranial pressure seen in the patient, as increased calcium levels can disrupt the blood-brain barrier and lead to cerebral edema.
  • In summary, the adverse effects of aminoglycosides can be severe and potentially life-threatening. Clinicians should be aware of these adverse effects and monitor patients closely for any signs of toxicity, particularly when using these drugs for prolonged periods or in patients with preexisting renal or neurological disorders.

Incorrect options

Option A: Aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity is a well-known adverse effect, which can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance disorders. It is due to the accumulation of the drug in the inner ear, where it can damage the hair cells of the cochlea and vestibular system. This effect is usually irreversible and dose-dependent, and can be more common in patients with pre-existing hearing impairment or those who receive prolonged therapy.

Option B: Nephrotoxicity is another common adverse effect of aminoglycosides, which can manifest as an increase in serum creatinine levels and decreased urine output. It is thought to be due to the inhibition of protein synthesis in renal tubular cells, leading to cell damage and decreased glomerular filtration rate. This effect is usually reversible once the drug is discontinued, but can be more common in patients with pre-existing renal impairment or those who receive high doses or prolonged therapy.

Option D: Aminoglycosides can also have hematological toxicity, which can manifest as bone marrow suppression and decreased production of blood cells. This effect is rare but can lead to anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia, particularly in patients with pre-existing hematological disorders or those who receive high doses or prolonged therapy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fatigue, nausea, and palpitations. His medical history includes hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, he has a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, and diffuse weakness. Laboratory investigations reveal serum potassium levels of 6.8 mmol/L. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of hyperkalemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Hyperkalemia is a medical emergency that can cause life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias, especially in patients with underlying cardiac disease. Treatment of hyperkalemia should begin with immediate stabilization of the patient with electrocardiogram monitoring, followed by identification and management of the underlying cause.
  • In this patient, the most appropriate initial management of hyperkalemia is to shift potassium from the extracellular space to the intracellular space, accomplished by administering insulin and dextrose. Insulin stimulates the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which facilitates the movement of potassium from the extracellular space into the intracellular space. To avoid hypoglycemia, dextrose is administered along with insulin.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: Administering calcium gluconate is incorrect because it does not treat hyperkalemia but stabilizes the myocardial cell membranes, thereby protecting against the effects of hyperkalemia. Calcium gluconate is given when the patient has ECG changes such as peaked T waves, widened QRS complexes, or ventricular arrhythmias.

Option C: Administering sodium polystyrene sulfonate (SPS) is incorrect because its onset of action is delayed, and it takes several hours to reduce serum potassium levels. SPS is used in patients with chronic hyperkalemia to help remove potassium from the body via the gastrointestinal tract.

Option D: Perform emergent hemodialysis is incorrect because it is not the initial management of hyperkalemia. Hemodialysis is indicated in patients with severe hyperkalemia and renal failure, but it is not the first-line treatment. It may take several hours to arrange for hemodialysis; during that time, the patient's hyperkalemia must be treated with other measures.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with a history of type 1 diabetes presents to the emergency department complaining of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to be tachypneic with deep and rapid respirations. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.26, PCO2 of 30 mmHg, and bicarbonate level of 16 mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Metabolic acidosis is when there is an accumulation of acids or loss of bicarbonate in the body, leading to a decrease in blood pH and bicarbonate levels. The most common causes of metabolic acidosis include diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), lactic acidosis, and renal failure.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient has a history of type 1 diabetes and presents with nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain symptoms, which suggest DKA. The ABG shows a low pH and bicarbonate level, confirming the metabolic acidosis diagnosis. The patient is also tachypneic with deep and rapid respirations, which is a compensatory mechanism to increase the elimination of carbon dioxide and attempt to normalize the pH.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A: Respiratory alkalosis is a condition in which there is an excessive elimination of carbon dioxide, leading to an increase in blood pH and a decrease in PCO2 levels. This is not the correct answer in this scenario because the patient has a low pH and bicarbonate level, which indicates metabolic acidosis. Additionally, the patient is tachypneic with deep and rapid respirations, which is a compensatory mechanism to decrease the acidity in the body.

Option C: Respiratory acidosis is a condition in which carbon dioxide accumulates, leading to decreased blood pH and increased PCO2 levels. This is not the correct answer in this scenario because the patient has a low pH and bicarbonate level, which indicates metabolic acidosis. Additionally, the patient is tachypneic with deep and rapid respirations, which is a compensatory mechanism to decrease the acidity in the body.

Option D: Metabolic alkalosis is a condition in which there is an excess of bicarbonate in the body, leading to increased blood pH and bicarbonate levels. This is not the correct answer in this scenario because the patient has a low pH and bicarbonate level, which indicates metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with a six-month history of tremors, dystonia, and difficulty with coordination. He is not currently taking any medications, and he has no major medical history. Neurological examination reveals bilateral wing-beating tremors and dystonic posturing of the arms. MRI of the brain shows increased signal intensity in the basal ganglia. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
• In this case, the patient is a 23-year-old male with a six-month history of tremors, dystonia, and difficulty with coordination. These neurological symptoms are consistent with Wilson’s disease. Additionally, the presence of bilateral wing-beating tremors and dystonic posturing of the arms is a hallmark of the disease. The MRI findings of increased signal intensity in the basal ganglia also support the diagnosis of Wilson disease, as this is a common site of copper deposition in the brain.
  • Wilson disease is an inherited copper metabolism disorder that results in copper accumulation in various organs, including the liver, brain, and eyes. The disease typically presents neurological and/or hepatic symptoms in adolescence or early adulthood.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Huntington's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that typically presents with chorea (involuntary jerking movements), personality changes, and cognitive decline. The clinical scenario above does not describe chorea, and the neurological symptoms are consistent with tremors and dystonia, which are not typically seen in Huntington's disease.

Option C: Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder that typically presents with bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, tremor, and postural instability. The clinical scenario above describes tremors and dystonia, but not bradykinesia or rigidity, which are more commonly seen in Parkinson's disease.

Option D: Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system and can present with various neurological symptoms. However, the clinical scenario above is inconsistent with multiple sclerosis, as there is no mention of focal neurological deficits, optic neuritis, or a history of relapsing-remitting symptoms. Additionally, the MRI findings described (increased signal intensity in the basal ganglia) are not typical of multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with weight loss, palpitations, sweating, and tremors for the past 2 months. She has also noticed bulging of her eyes and has a history of neck swelling. On examination, she has a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute, fine tremors, and a diffuse goiter. Laboratory investigations reveal a low TSH, high free T4, and positive TSH receptor antibodies. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario suggests Graves’ disease, an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism, diffuse goiter, and ophthalmopathy. The most appropriate next step in managing this patient would be to start beta-blocker therapy. Beta-blockers such as propranolol help control hyperthyroidism symptoms, including palpitations, tremors, and sweating.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Starting antithyroid drugs such as methimazole or propylthiouracil may be considered in patients with Graves' disease. These medications function by preventing the thyroid's hormone release. However, in this case, beta-blockers should be started first to control the symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Antithyroid drugs can be started later to achieve long-term control of the disease.

Option B: Radioactive iodine therapy is an option for hyperthyroidism caused by Graves' disease. The thyroid gland takes up radioactive iodine and destroys the thyroid cells, thereby reducing the production of thyroid hormones. However, this treatment option is inappropriate for this patient at this stage.

Option C: Total thyroidectomy may be considered in patients with Graves' disease who are not responsive to medical therapy or have severe ophthalmopathy. However, surgery is not the first-line treatment for Graves' disease and is not appropriate for this patient at this stage.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers for the past 2 years. He also reports redness and pain in his eyes along with visual blurring for the past 6 months as seen in the image. On examination, there are multiple shallow oral ulcers and erythema nodosum-like lesions on his legs. His ophthalmic exam shows anterior uveitis with hypopyon. He has no history of sexually transmitted infections or joint pains. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Behcet’s disease is a chronic, multisystem inflammatory disorder primarily affecting young adults. Recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and skin lesions characterize it. The genital ulcers in Behçet’s disease are typically painful and deep, unlike those in herpes simplex virus infections. 
  • Ocular involvement in the form of anterior uveitis is common and can lead to blindness if left untreated. Erythema nodosum-like lesions on the legs and joint pains may also be present but are not always seen. Behçet’s disease is more common in certain ethnic groups, including those from the Mediterranean, Middle East, and Asia.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory disorder mainly affecting the gastrointestinal tract but can also present with extraintestinal manifestations. Oral and genital ulcers are commonly seen in Crohn’s disease, but other symptoms such as diarrhoea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and fatigue are usually present. Joint pains and erythema nodosum-like lesions may also be present. However, this patient's absence of gastrointestinal symptoms and joint pains makes Crohn’s disease less likely.

Option B: Sarcoidosis is a multisystem disease characterized by non-caseating granulomas in various organs. It can involve the skin, lungs, eyes, and other organs. Oral and genital ulcers are not common in sarcoidosis, but ocular involvement in the form of uveitis can occur. Other symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, skin rash, and joint pains may also be present. However, the presence of genital ulcers and erythema nodosum-like lesions make sarcoidosis less likely.

Option D: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and central nervous system. Oral ulcers are a common manifestation of SLE, but genital ulcers are less commonly seen. Ocular involvement in the form of uveitis or retinopathy can also occur. Joint pains are a common symptom, but erythema nodosum-like lesions are rare. The absence of joint pains in this patient makes SLE less likely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with drooping of his left eyelid, a constricted left pupil, and decreased sweating on the left side of his face. Further examination shows a slight elevation of his left lower eyelid and a slight recession of his left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The Horner syndrome is a clinical triad of miosis (constricted pupil), ptosis (drooping of the eyelid), and anhidrosis (decreased sweating) caused by damage to the sympathetic nerve pathway that supplies the face and eye. 
  • In addition, Horner syndrome can also cause slight elevation of the lower eyelid (due to loss of sympathetic tone) and slight recession of the eye (due to loss of sympathetic tone to the dilator muscle of the iris). Causes of Horner syndrome include injury to the neck, chest, or head, as well as tumors, infections, and other medical conditions.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Bell's palsy is a condition that causes sudden, temporary weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles. Its exact cause is unknown, but it is thought to be related to inflammation or viral infections. Symptoms can include drooping of one side of the face, difficulty smiling or closing the eye on one side, and drooling. Most people recover fully from Bell's palsy within a few months, although some may experience permanent muscle weakness or other complications.

Option C. Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition that causes severe, sharp pain in the face. The pain is usually felt on one side of the face and can be triggered by activities such as chewing, speaking, or touching the face. Trigeminal neuralgia is caused by irritation or damage to the trigeminal nerve, which is responsible for facial sensation. Treatment options may include medications or surgery.
Option D. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that causes muscle weakness and fatigue. The condition occurs when the body's immune system attacks the receptors that control muscle movement. Symptoms can include drooping eyelids, difficulty swallowing, and weakness in the arms and legs. Treatment options may include medications, surgery, or other therapies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, lightheadedness, and shortness of breath.. On examination, her heart rate is 180 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. What is the most appropriate initial management strategy for this patient?
questions.solution:
• An abnormal heart rhythm, or arrhythmia, is called paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). It happens when the upper chamber of the heart experiences a brief circuit rhythm. As a consequence, there is a regular, swift heartbeat that starts and stops suddenly. 
  • Adenosine is a medication used to treat PSVT. It works by slowing down the electrical conduction in the heart, which can help restore a normal heart rhythm. Adenosine is given intravenously in a hospital setting, and its effects are usually short-lived. Adenosine is the drug of choice for patients with PSVT who are hemodynamically stable.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Verapamil is another medication used to treat PSVT. It works by blocking the calcium channels in the heart, which can help slow down the heart rate and restore a normal rhythm. Verapamil is also given intravenously in a hospital setting, and its effects can be longer-lasting than those of adenosine. Verapamil can be used in patients with PSVT who are hemodynamically stable, but it should be used with caution in patients with low blood pressure or heart failure.

Option C: Vagal maneuvers are simple techniques that can help slow down the heart rate in patients with PSVT. These maneuvers include techniques such as bearing down, gagging, or coughing. Vagal maneuvers can be useful in patients with mild or moderate symptoms but may not be effective in patients with more severe symptoms or those with underlying heart disease.

Option D: Electrical cardioversion is a procedure that uses electrical shocks to restore a normal heart rhythm in patients with PSVT. It is usually reserved for patients who are hemodynamically unstable or who have not responded to other treatments. Electrical cardioversion is performed under sedation in a hospital setting and can effectively restore a normal heart rhythm.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with chest pain and shortness of breath. An electrocardiogram (ECG) is performed and reveals the following abnormal waves:
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Atrial flutter is a regular heart rhythm in which the atria contract rapidly and regularly but at a rate faster than normal. On an ECG, atrial flutter appears as regular sawtooth-shaped or flutter waves before each QRS complex. The ECG in this scenario shows abnormal waves consistent with flutter waves, making atrial flutter the most likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Sinus tachycardia is a normal rhythm with a heart rate greater than 100 beats per minute. On an ECG, sinus tachycardia appears as normal P waves followed by a QRS complex. The ECG in this scenario shows abnormal waves inconsistent with sinus tachycardia.

Option B. Atrial fibrillation is an irregular heart rhythm in which the atria contract rapidly and chaotically, resulting in an irregular ventricular response. On an ECG, atrial fibrillation appears irregularly irregular, with no discernable P waves or irregular ventricular rate. The ECG in this scenario shows abnormal waves, but there is a discernable P wave, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.

Option C. Ventricular fibrillation is a life-threatening rhythm in which the ventricles quiver and do not contract effectively, leading to cardiac arrest. On an ECG, ventricular fibrillation appears as a chaotic, irregular pattern with no discernable P waves or QRS complexes. The ECG in this scenario shows discernable P waves and QRS complexes, making ventricular fibrillation unlikely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a cough and fever. She reports having a similar illness that was treated with antibiotics a few months ago. She has previously experienced penicillin allergies. A chest x-ray shows evidence of pneumonia. Which of the following macrolides would be the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Azithromycin is a newer macrolide antibiotic with a longer half-life and a broader spectrum of activity against respiratory pathogens than erythromycin. It has a lower incidence of gastrointestinal side effects and is well-tolerated by most patients. 
  • Azithromycin is also a good choice for patients with a penicillin allergy as it is not structurally related to penicillin. Azithromycin is the most appropriate treatment for this patient with pneumonia.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Older macrolide antibiotic erythromycin is used to treat several different bacterial illnesses. However, it is associated with more gastrointestinal side effects, such as nausea and diarrhoea. It also has a higher potential for drug interactions compared to other macrolides. Erythromycin may not be the best choice for this patient, given her history of a previous illness and the need for a more tolerable medication.

Option C: Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic similar to erythromycin in terms of its spectrum of activity and potential for drug interactions. It is generally well-tolerated but may be associated with more side effects than azithromycin. Clarithromycin is a good alternative for patients who cannot tolerate azithromycin. However, it may not be the best choice for this patient with a history of a previous illness and needing a more tolerable medication.

Option D: Telithromycin is a newer macrolide antibiotic with a broader spectrum of activity. However, it has been associated with rare cases of serious liver injury and has a higher potential for drug interactions than other macrolides. Telithromycin is not the best choice for this patient, given the availability of safer and equally effective alternatives.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever and a rash on her legs that has spread rapidly over the past few days. She reports having been camping in the woods over the weekend and recalls being bitten by several ticks. A tick-borne illness is suspected, and a blood test confirms a Rocky Mountain spotted fever diagnosis. What is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Rocky Mountain spotted fever is a tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Rickettsia rickettsii. 
  • Tetracycline is a class of antibiotics that works by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis. It is commonly used to treat many bacterial infections, including tick-borne illnesses, acne, and respiratory tract infections. Tetracyclines are effective against intracellular bacteria, such as Rickettsia rickettsii, the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Therefore, tetracycline is the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for this patient.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Penicillin is a class of antibiotics that works by inhibiting the formation of bacterial cell walls. It is commonly used to treat infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria, such as Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species. However, penicillin is ineffective against tick-borne illnesses caused by intracellular bacteria, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, as it cannot penetrate the cells where the bacteria reside. Therefore, penicillin is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for this patient.

Option B: Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that inhibits bacterial DNA synthesis. It is commonly used to treat infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. However, ciprofloxacin is ineffective against tick-borne illnesses caused by intracellular bacteria, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, as it cannot penetrate the cells where the bacteria reside. Therefore, ciprofloxacin is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for this patient.

Option D: Amoxicillin is a penicillin antibiotic that inhibits the formation of bacterial cell walls. It is commonly used to treat infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria, such as Streptococcus and Staphylococcus species. However, amoxicillin is ineffective against tick-borne illnesses caused by intracellular bacteria, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever, as it cannot penetrate the cells where the bacteria reside. Therefore, amoxicillin is not the most appropriate antibiotic therapy for this patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the endocrinology clinic with symptoms of hyperthyroidism, including weight loss, palpitations, and sweating. Graves’ disease is diagnosed, and the patient is started on antithyroid drug therapy with methimazole. After a few weeks of therapy, the patient develops a fever, sore throat, and skin rash. Which of the following adverse effects of antithyroid drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of antithyroid drugs, particularly methimazole. It is characterized by a marked decrease in white blood cells, specifically granulocytes, responsible for fighting off infections. The symptoms of agranulocytosis include fever, sore throat, and skin rash, consistent with the clinical scenario described above. Treatment involves discontinuing the antithyroid drug and administering antibiotics to prevent infection.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Hypothyroidism is not an adverse effect of antithyroid drugs, but rather a potential complication of treatment. In some cases, the thyroid gland may become underactive due to antithyroid drug therapy, leading to hypothyroidism. This can be managed with hormone replacement therapy.

Option C: Liver failure is a rare adverse effect of antithyroid drugs, particularly propylthiouracil. It is characterized by symptoms such as jaundice, abdominal pain, and fatigue. Liver function tests should be monitored regularly during antithyroid drug therapy to detect any signs of liver damage.

Option D: Pancreatitis is a rare adverse effect of antithyroid drugs, particularly propylthiouracil. It is characterized by severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. Treatment involves discontinuing the antithyroid drug and providing supportive care to manage symptoms.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who is 16 weeks pregnant presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism is presented to the clinic. Her medical history includes Graves' disease; she has been taking Methimazole for the past 3 years. She is concerned about the safety of her medication during pregnancy. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Refer to an endocrinologist for further evaluation

questions.solution:
• Propylthiouracil is another anti-thyroid drug commonly used to manage hyperthyroidism in pregnant women. It has a lower risk of causing fetal thyroid suppression and aplasia cutis than Methimazole. Therefore, switching to Propylthiouracil during pregnancy is recommended if the patient has been taking Methimazole for Graves' disease.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Methimazole is a commonly used anti-thyroid drug for managing hyperthyroidism. However, it is associated with a rare but serious side effect called aplasia cutis in newborns. It can also lead to fetal thyroid suppression, which can cause developmental abnormalities. Therefore, it is not recommended to continue Methimazole therapy during pregnancy unless absolutely necessary.

Option C: Discontinuing anti-thyroid medication during pregnancy can lead to uncontrolled hyperthyroidism, which can adversely affect maternal and fetal health. Therefore, it is not recommended to discontinue anti-thyroid medication during pregnancy unless the benefits outweigh the risks.

Option D: Refer to an endocrinologist for further evaluation: Pregnant women with hyperthyroidism should be referred to an endocrinologist for further evaluation and management of their condition during pregnancy. The endocrinologist can assess the need for anti-thyroid medication, adjust the dosage, and monitor the patient's thyroid function during pregnancy. But in this case, the patient has no complications and, therefore, can switch to propylthiouracil.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a history of biliary atresia presents to the hospital with abdominal pain, vomiting, and fatigue. On physical examination, the child has a distended abdomen, mild jaundice, and ascites. Laboratory tests reveal elevated bilirubin levels, prolonged prothrombin time, and low albumin levels. Based on these findings, what is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score for this child?

choices.text: The CTP score cannot be calculated in children

questions.solution:
• The Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score is a tool used to assess the severity of liver disease and predict prognosis. It is calculated based on five parameters: total bilirubin level, serum albumin level, prothrombin time, degree of ascites, and severity of encephalopathy. The scores range from 5 to 15, with higher scores indicating more severe liver disease.
  • In this scenario, the child has elevated bilirubin levels, prolonged prothrombin time, and low albumin levels, which indicate liver dysfunction. The presence of ascites also suggests advanced liver disease. Therefore, the CTP score for this child would be Class C, which is associated with a high risk of mortality and poor prognosis.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Class A is associated with a CTP score of 5-6 and indicates mild liver disease with a low mortality risk. 

Option B: Class B is associated with a CTP score of 7-9 and indicates moderate liver disease with intermediate mortality risk.

Option D: The CTP score cannot be calculated in children is incorrect, as the CTP score can be calculated in children, although modifications may need to be made to account for differences in age and

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the rheumatology clinic with complaints of joint pain, stiffness, and swelling in her hands and feet for the past 3 months. On examination, she has symmetrical joint swelling involving both small and large joints of her hands and feet. She also has morning stiffness that lasts for more than an hour. Her rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibody tests are positive. Which of the following extra-articular manifestations are associated in this condition?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory condition mainly affecting the joints. However, it can also involve other organs and tissues in the body. All of the mentioned extra-articular manifestations, interstitial lung disease, hemolytic anemia, and scleritis can occur in patients with RA. Other extra-articular manifestations of RA include pericarditis, vasculitis, neuropathy, and Felty's syndrome. These extra-articular manifestations of RA are associated with increased morbidity and mortality.
Incorrect Choices:
Option A. RA can involve the lungs and cause interstitial lung disease (ILD). Patients with RA-associated ILD may present with dyspnea, cough, and restrictive lung disease on pulmonary function tests. Chest radiography or computed tomography (CT) scan may show interstitial infiltrates or fibrosis.
Option B. A rare but severe complication of RA is hemolytic anemia. It can be caused by the formation of autoantibodies that attack and destroy red blood cells. Patients with hemolytic anemia may present with fatigue, pallor, and jaundice.
Option C. Scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera or the white portion of the eye. It can occur in patients with RA, especially those with high levels of rheumatoid factor. Patients with scleritis may present with eye pain, redness, and photophobia.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents with decreased urine output, elevated creatinine, and hyperkalemia. His medications include lisinopril and metformin. On examination, he is hypotensive with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Laboratory results show a serum creatinine of 2.5 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL) and serum potassium of 6.5 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient's acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
• The most appropriate initial management for this patient's acute kidney injury is fluid resuscitation with normal saline. This patient presents with decreased urine output, elevated creatinine, and hyperkalemia, which are signs of acute kidney injury. 
  • The hypotension in this patient is likely due to hypovolemia, a common cause of acute kidney injury. Therefore, the initial management should be fluid resuscitation with normal saline to correct 
  • the hypovolemia and improve renal perfusion.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Initiation of hemodialysis may be necessary if the patient's condition does not improve with fluid resuscitation or if there is evidence of volume overload, metabolic acidosis, or severe electrolyte disturbances that cannot be managed medically. However, hemodialysis is not the initial management for acute kidney injury and should only be considered if other measures fail.

Option C: Administration of intravenous furosemide is not recommended as the patient is hypotensive, and the use of diuretics can exacerbate hypotension and volume depletion. Furosemide may be used later in managing acute kidney injury once the patient is stabilized and fluid status has been assessed.

Option D: Discontinuation of lisinopril and metformin may be considered if the patient's renal impairment is due to drug-induced acute kidney injury. However, in this patient, the cause of acute kidney injury is likely due to hypovolemia, and discontinuing these medications is not necessary. Moreover, abrupt discontinuation of lisinopril can lead to rebound hypertension, further worsening renal function.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech. On examination, he has a right-sided facial droop, left hemiparesis, and dysarthria. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows no evidence of haemorrhage.
What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient with suspected ischemic stroke?

choices.text: Administration of intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)
Initiation of strict blood pressure control

questions.solution:
• The most appropriate initial management for this patient with suspected ischemic stroke is the administration of an intravenous tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). This patient presents with sudden onset of left-sided weakness and slurred speech and, on examination, has a right-sided facial droop, left hemiparesis, and dysarthria, all suggesting ischemic stroke. The non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows no evidence of haemorrhage, which makes tPA administration an appropriate treatment option.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Emergent neurosurgical intervention is not the initial management for ischemic stroke. Neurosurgical intervention may be considered in patients with ischemic stroke who are not candidates for tPA or those with large vessel occlusion who do not respond to tPA. However, emergent neurosurgical intervention is not the initial management for all patients with ischemic stroke.

Option C: Administration of aspirin and heparin is not the initial management for ischemic stroke. Aspirin may be given within 24 hours of symptom onset to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke. Still, heparin should not be given in the acute phase of ischemic stroke due to the risk of hemorrhagic transformation.

Option D: Initiating strict blood pressure control is not the initial management for ischemic stroke. Blood pressure control is important in managing ischemic stroke, but strict blood pressure control should not be initiated in the acute phase of ischemic stroke as it can reduce cerebral perfusion and worsen outcomes. Blood pressure control should be initiated gradually and carefully to avoid complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department with weakness and tingling in his legs that has progressed to involve his arms and hands. On examination, he has reduced reflexes and is unable to walk unassisted. A lumbar puncture shows elevated protein levels but no evidence of infection. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient, and what is the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Guillain-Barré syndrome, treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG)
Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis, treatment with intravenous corticosteroids

questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy typically presents with ascending muscle weakness and sensory deficits. A lumbar puncture may show elevated protein levels in the cerebrospinal fluid but no evidence of infection.
  • The appropriate treatment for GBS is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG). IVIG is a pooled preparation of human immunoglobulin G that has been shown to reduce the severity and duration of symptoms in patients with GBS. Other treatment options for GBS include plasmapheresis and supportive care, such as mechanical ventilation and monitoring for autonomic dysfunction.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Multiple sclerosis is not the correct diagnosis for this patient. Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disease typically presenting with relapsing-remitting symptoms such as visual disturbances, sensory deficits, and motor weakness. Corticosteroids may be used to treat acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, but they are not the first-line treatment for GBS.

Option B: Myasthenia gravis is not the correct diagnosis for this patient. Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue that worsens with activity. Pyridostigmine is a medication used to treat myasthenia gravis by increasing the levels of acetylcholine in the neuromuscular junction. However, pyridostigmine is not the appropriate treatment for GBS.

Option D: Acute disseminated encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is not the correct diagnosis for this patient. ADEM is a rare inflammatory disorder of the central nervous system that typically presents with multifocal neurological symptoms such as altered mental status, seizures, and ataxia. The treatment for ADEM may include intravenous corticosteroids, but IVIG is not an effective treatment for ADEM.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. On auscultation, a loud S1 heart sound is heard. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
• Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) is a condition with an increased size of the heart's left ventricle. It can occur due to several factors, such as hypertension, aortic stenosis, and myocardial infarction. The hypertrophied left ventricle generates a greater pressure gradient across the mitral valve, resulting in a louder S1 heart sound. Thus, it is the most likely cause of the finding in this scenario.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Mitral regurgitation is a condition where there is an abnormal flow of blood from the left ventricle back into the left atrium due to a leaky mitral valve. This can cause a softer S1 heart sound rather than a louder one. Hence, it is an unlikely cause of the finding in this scenario.

Option B: Aortic stenosis occurs when the aortic valve narrows and blocks blood from the left ventricle into the aorta. This can lead to a softer S2 heart sound and is not associated with a louder S1 heart sound.

Option D: Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is a condition with high blood pressure in the pulmonary arteries, which supply blood to the lungs. PH can cause an accentuation of the P2 component of S2, but it is not associated with a louder S1 heart sound.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents to the clinic complaining of palpitations and shortness of breath. On auscultation, a systolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
• Cardiac murmurs are abnormal sounds heard during the cardiac cycle. They can be caused by conditions such as valvular heart disease, congenital heart disease, and heart failure. Murmurs are classified based on the timing of the sound (systolic or diastolic) and the location on the chest where they are heard.
  • In the scenario given, a systolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border, which suggests a problem with the aortic valve or the adjacent aortic root.
  • Aortic stenosis is when the aortic valve narrows and obstructs blood flow from the left ventricle into the aorta. This can cause a systolic murmur heard over the left sternal border. The murmur is usually harsh and crescendo-decrescendo in nature, and it can radiate to the carotid arteries.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: Mitral stenosis is a type of valvular heart disease characterized by the narrowing of the mitral valve that separates the left atrium from the left ventricle. This narrowing restricts blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, palpitations, and swelling in different body parts. Mitral stenosis is commonly caused by rheumatic fever, a complication of untreated streptococcal infections. Other possible causes include congenital heart defects and mitral valve calcification due to aging. Mitral stenosis is characterized by a diastolic rumbling murmur heard best at the apex.

Option C: Mitral regurgitation is a type of heart valve disease in which the mitral valve that separates the left atrium from the left ventricle doesn't close completely, causing blood to leak (or regurgitate) backward through the valve with each heartbeat. This can lead to a range of symptoms, such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and irregular heartbeats, and can also cause complications like heart failure or high blood pressure in the lungs. Various factors, including mitral valve prolapse, rheumatic fever, or congenital heart defects, can cause mitral regurgitation. Mitral regurgitation is a holosystolic murmur heard best at the apex, radiating to the axilla.

Option D: Aortic regurgitation, also known as aortic insufficiency 1, is a condition in which the aortic valve in the heart does not close tightly or properly, leading to blood flowing back into the left ventricle (one of the heart's pumping chambers). This can cause the heart to work harder to compensate for the regurgitation of blood and can lead to symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, and chest pain. Various factors, including rheumatic fever, congenital heart defects, bacterial endocarditis, or damage to the valve over time, can cause aortic regurgitation. Aortic regurgitation is characterized by a high-pitched, blowing diastolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border, with wide pulse pressure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male complains of chest pain and dyspnea on exertion. He has a family history of sudden cardiac death. Physical examination reveals a loud systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Electrocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography reveals asymmetric septal hypertrophy. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The most likely diagnosis, in this case, is hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), which is characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy that is not solely explained by abnormal loading conditions such as hypertension or valvular disease. 
  • Asymmetric septal hypertrophy is a common finding in HCM, and patients may present with chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, syncope, or sudden cardiac death. The loud systolic murmur heard on physical examination is caused by dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction, which is present in up to two-thirds of patients with HCM.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Dilated cardiomyopathy is characterized by dilation and impaired left ventricle systolic function. It can present with similar symptoms but is not associated with asymmetric septal hypertrophy or left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

Option B: Restrictive cardiomyopathy is characterized by the impaired diastolic function of the heart due to abnormal stiffness of the ventricular walls. It can present with dyspnea on exertion and other symptoms but is not associated with left ventricular hypertrophy or dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

Option C: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy is characterized by fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium. It can present with palpitations, syncope, or sudden cardiac death but is not associated with left ventricular hypertrophy or dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with chest pain that started about 3 hours ago. He is diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction (MI) and is treated with aspirin, heparin, and a glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor. The patient is brought into the coronary care centre for additional treatment. On the third day of hospitalization, the patient develops an MI-related complication. Which of the following complications, in this case, is most likely?
questions.solution:
• The most likely complication in this patient is cardiogenic shock. Cardiogenic shock is a life-threatening complication that occurs in approximately 5-10% of patients with MI. It is characterized by decreased cardiac output and tissue hypoperfusion, leading to organ dysfunction and failure. Risk factors for cardiogenic shock include advanced age, female gender, diabetes mellitus, and anterior MI.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Ventricular tachycardia is a common arrhythmia that can occur after an MI, especially in the first 48-72 hours. It is often self-limited and does not usually lead to hemodynamic compromise. However, sustained ventricular tachycardia can result in hemodynamic instability and can progress to ventricular fibrillation, a life-threatening arrhythmia.

Option C: Atrial fibrillation can also occur after an MI, particularly in patients with pre-existing atrial fibrillation. It is associated with an increased risk of stroke, and anticoagulation therapy may be necessary to reduce this risk.

Option D:  Pericarditis is an inflammatory complication that can occur after an MI, usually within the first week. It is characterized by chest pain often relieved by sitting up and leaning forward. Pericarditis can lead to pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade, a medical emergency.
